feedback: La exportación de pesticidas tóxicos revela un doble rasero. Los pesticidas peligrosos están prohibidos en Europa por su relación con el cáncer, los problemas reproductivos y las enfermedades neurodegenerativas, así como con la muerte de las abejas. Además, se sabe que algunos provocan daño cerebral infantil y durante el embarazo. Si no usamos estos pesticidas por ser demasiado peligrosos, ¿cómo podemos permitir que se exporten? La prohibición de exportar pesticidas tóxicos fomentaría la innovación y animaría a Europa y al resto del mundo a utilizar técnicas fitosanitarias más sostenibles. Mantener en el mercado pesticidas obsoletos y peligrosos nos priva de un futuro más verde y de unas prácticas agrícolas más ecológicas. Queremos un futuro de bienestar para el planeta, nuestro hogar.
englishfeedback: The export of toxic pesticides reveals double standards. Hazardous pesticides are banned in Europe because of their relationship with cancer, reproductive problems and neurodegenerative diseases, as well as the death of bees. In addition, some are known to cause brain damage for children and during pregnancy. If we do not use these pesticides because they are too dangerous, how can we allow them to be exported? A ban on the export of toxic pesticides would encourage innovation and encourage Europe and the rest of the world to use more sustainable plant protection techniques. Keeping obsolete and dangerous pesticides on the market deprives us of a greener future and greener farming practices. We want a future of well-being for the planet, our home.

feedback: La exportación de pesticidas tóxicos revela un doble rasero. Los pesticidas peligrosos están prohibidos en Europa por su relación con el cáncer, los problemas reproductivos y las enfermedades neurodegenerativas, así como con la muerte de las abejas. Además, se sabe que algunos provocan daño cerebral infantil y durante el embarazo. Si no usamos estos pesticidas por ser demasiado peligrosos, ¿cómo podemos permitir que se exporten? La exportación de pesticidas tóxicos es una cuestión de derechos humanos, ya que atentan contra la salud. Cada año, miles de personas que viven de la agricultura mueren por exponerse a estos peligrosos pesticidas. Numerosos estudios demuestran sus efectos nocivos. La exportación de pesticidas tóxicos perjudica a las abejas, la biodiversidad y el planeta. Los datos no mienten: los neonicotinoides y otros pesticidas tóxicos matan a las abejas. Por eso están prohibidos en Europa. ¿Cómo podemos permitir que se exporten a otros países? La industria de los pesticidas tóxicos se lucra con los países de normativas menos estrictas. Europa tiene que dar ejemplo y no permitir que sus empresas se aprovechen de una legislación más permisiva. ¿Cómo se nos puede tomar en serio si exportamos unos productos químicos que envenenan a las personas y la naturaleza? La prohibición de exportar pesticidas tóxicos fomentaría la innovación y animaría a Europa y al resto del mundo a utilizar técnicas fitosanitarias más sostenibles. Mantener en el mercado pesticidas obsoletos y peligrosos nos priva de un futuro más verde y de unas prácticas agrícolas más ecológicas.
englishfeedback: The export of toxic pesticides reveals double standards. Hazardous pesticides are banned in Europe because of their relationship with cancer, reproductive problems and neurodegenerative diseases, as well as the death of bees. In addition, some are known to cause brain damage for children and during pregnancy. If we do not use these pesticides because they are too dangerous, how can we allow them to be exported? The export of toxic pesticides is a human rights issue, as they harm health. Every year, thousands of people living in agriculture die from exposure to these dangerous pesticides. Numerous studies demonstrate its harmful effects. The export of toxic pesticides harms bees, biodiversity and the planet. The data do not feel: neonicotinoids and other toxic pesticides kill bees. This is why they are banned in Europe. How can we allow them to be exported to other countries? The toxic pesticide industry is profitable with countries with less stringent regulations. Europe needs to lead by example and not allow its businesses to take advantage of more permissive legislation. How can we be taken seriously if we export chemicals that poisonate people and nature? A ban on the export of toxic pesticides would encourage innovation and encourage Europe and the rest of the world to use more sustainable plant protection techniques. Keeping obsolete and dangerous pesticides on the market deprives us of a greener future and greener farming practices.

feedback: La exportación de pesticidas tóxicos perjudica a las abejas, la biodiversidad y el planeta. Los datos no mienten: los neonicotinoides y otros pesticidas tóxicos matan a las abejas. Por eso están prohibidos en Europa. ¿Cómo podemos permitir que se exporten a otros países?
englishfeedback: The export of toxic pesticides harms bees, biodiversity and the planet. The data do not feel: neonicotinoids and other toxic pesticides kill bees. This is why they are banned in Europe. How can we allow them to be exported to other countries?

feedback: Hallo, EU, aus gutem Grund sind die bekannten Chemikalien in der EU verboten. Das fordere ich auch für den Export außerhalb Europas! MfG Hans Queisser
englishfeedback: Hallo, EU, for good reason, the known chemicals are banned in the EU. I call for this also for exports outside Europe! MFG Hans Queisser

feedback: L'esportazione di pesticidi tossici mette in luce un doppio standard: I pesticidi pericolosi sono stati vietati in Europa dopo essere stati collegati a cancro, problemi riproduttivi e malattie neurodegenerative, nonché alla morte delle api. Alcuni di questi pesticidi sono vietati in Europa perché collegati a danni cerebrali nei bambini e nei neonati. Se questi pesticidi sono troppo pericolosi per noi, come possiamo che vengano esportati allestero? L'esportazione di pesticidi tossici è una questione di diritti umani, poiché questi pesticidi tossici danneggiano le persone: Ogni anno, migliaia di agricoltori muoiono per l'esposizione di pesticidi pericolosi. Esistono innumerevoli studi che dimostrano gli effetti dannosi sulle persone dei pesticidi esportati. L'esportazione di pesticidi tossici è dannosa per le api, la biodiversità e il pianeta. Le prove sono chiare: i neonicotinoidi e altri pesticidi velenosi uccidono le api. Ecco perché sono vietati in Europa. Perché continuiamo a permettere che vengano esportati in Paesi uccidendo le api e decimando la biodiversità? L'esportazione di pesticidi tossici sfrutta i paesi con leggi più permissive. L'Europa ha un ruolo da svolgere nel mondo: non si deve permettere alle sue aziende di approfittare dei paesi con una regolamentazione più debole. Come possiamo essere presi sul serio se spediamo le nostre sostanze chimiche pericolose all'estero, avvelenando le persone e la natura in paesi dove le norme di sicurezza sono più deboli e meno rigorose? Un divieto di esportazione dei pesticidi tossici sarebbe un vantaggio per l'innovazione e aiuterebbe l'Europa e il mondo intero verso pratiche agricole più sostenibili. Mantenere sul mercato pesticidi vecchi e pericolosi ci priva di un futuro più verde e di pratiche agricole più sostenibili. Un parere legale del Centro di diritto ambientale internazional (Center for International Environmental Law), pubblicato nel 2022, dimostra che le esportazioni dell'UE di pesticidi vietati verso l'Africa e l'America centrale violano gli obblighi legali internazionali dell'UE e i diritti umani.
englishfeedback: The export of toxic pesticides highlights a double standard: Hazardous pesticides have been banned in Europe after being linked to cancer, reproductive problems and neurodegenerative diseases, as well as to the death of bees. Some of these pesticides are banned in Europe because they are linked to brain damage in children and infants. If these pesticides are too dangerous for us, how can they be exported abroad? The export of toxic pesticides is a human rights issue, as these toxic pesticides harm people: Every year, thousands of farmers die from exposure of hazardous pesticides. There are countless studies demonstrating the harmful effects of exported pesticides on people. The export of toxic pesticides is detrimental to bees, biodiversity and the planet. The evidence is clear: neonicotinoids and other poisonous pesticides kill bees. This is why they are banned in Europe. Why do we continue to allow them to be exported to countries by killing bees and deciding on biodiversity? The export of toxic pesticides exploits countries with more permissive laws. Europe has a role to play in the world: its companies should not be allowed to take advantage of countries with weaker regulation. How can we be taken seriously if we ship our hazardous chemicals abroad, poisoning people and nature in countries where safety standards are weaker and lower? A ban on the export of toxic pesticides would benefit innovation and help Europe and the world towards more sustainable farming practices. Keeping old and hazardous pesticides on the market deprives us of a greener future and more sustainable farming practices. A legal opinion of the Center for International Environmental Law, published in 2022, shows that EU exports of banned pesticides to Africa and Central America violate the EU’s international legal obligations and human rights.

feedback: Dear Commission, Thank you to listen to citizens and other stakeholders. I believe this initiative it is not a clever move from the EU and that: 1. European operators will be replaced by non-EU ones to supply those markets. We are exporting European jobs and expertise with this initiative. 2. We will see R&D moving away from EU. Seeing how many times bans are decided without proper justification, by expediency using the Precautionary Principle rather than having political courage to explain complex situations and balanced risk management, it means that not all bans in Europe are undisputable and doing good. Having lost the internal EU market for these substances, I dont think that the R&D linked to them will remain long in Europe if their EU production has to cease too (because it cant be used in Europe and cant be exported anymore). What does it mean for sectors where Europe used to have world-class actors like pesticides and biocides ? Do we think that multinationals like Bayer, Syngenta etc. will continue to run R&D poles in Europe ? It was easy for the EU to ban DDT and other effective mosquito killers: we dont have malaria anymore (it was endemic until the 1970s in Europe, and is in the recent years limited to cases linked with travel). So we didnt care anymore. This illness infects 300+ millions people/year and kills ~1 million / year. Who has the moral ground: those who are banning the use of useful pesticides to fight this and other worldwide calamities, or those who produce and exports the banned pesticides ? I also believe that we will have reasons to regret some of those bans in the years to come, due to climate change: We see now the resurgence of it locally, with the increasing presence of the mosquitoes responsible for the transmission. It is indeed expected that those mosquitoes are moving north and to higher altitudes due to climate change. So malaria will be a problem again in Europe. Hopefully, well be able to import the pesticides from China and elsewhere at that moment. We can find other examples in agriculture where EU regretfully rules out very useful tools under the influence of fear-mongering by extremists. In these fields also, European companies are at the top of R&D and will suffer from those bans. So this initiative may look like the right thing to do when looking at it superficially and emotionally. I believe that it will actually destroy welfare and lives worldwide, including in Europe. So I dispute that this is morally the adequate choice. Thanks for having taken the time to read these views. A concerned citizen.

L'empoisonnement aux pesticides n'est pas un phénomène nouveau La réalité tragique de l'empoisonnement aux pesticides chez les enfants en Inde est qu'il ne s'agit pas d'un événement nouveau ou récent. Une étude rétrospective menée à l'hôpital public pour enfants de Srinagar a révélé que 15 % des enfants des admissions pédiatriques pour empoisonnement de 1983 à 1988 étaient dues aux pesticides. 9 Une autre étude de l'hôpital Cooper du Maharashtra a révélé que les pesticides étaient responsables de 9,6 % des admissions pédiatriques de 1986 à 87.10 En 1997 un hôpital de Patna, en Inde, a signalé 20 cas d'empoisonnement au phosphure d'aluminium hautement toxique chez des enfants de 7 ans à 12 au cours d'une seule année.11 Une étude plus approfondie de 8 hôpitaux différents publiée dans l'Indian Journal of Pediatrics en 1998 a révélé que les pesticides, les insecticides et les rodenticides contribuaient de 1,2 % à 15 % au total des empoisonnements pédiatriques.12. L'empoisonnement aux pesticides est toujours un problème Au tournant du millénaire, une tendance continue d'empoisonnement aux pesticides dans la population pédiatrique a été documentée. Certaines des meilleures preuves à cet effet proviennent du Centre national d'information sur les poisons (NPIC) de l'Institut indien des sciences médicales à New Delhi. Entre avril 1999 et mars 2002, on a constaté que 9,1 % des appels téléphoniques pour des cas pédiatriques étaient dus à une intoxication par des pesticides agricoles.6,7 C'est en plus des pesticides ménagers, qui comprenaient des pyréthrinoïdes (20,3 %), des rodenticides (11,3 %) et des organophosphorés. 7 Une autre étude rétrospective du NPIC a montré que plus de 36 % des appels téléphoniques pour empoisonnement aux pesticides entre 1999 et 2012 concernaient des enfants de moins de 16 ans5. 57 % des appels téléphoniques pour intoxication domestique aux pesticides concernaient des patients de moins de 18 ans.8 Des études menées dans d'autres institutions en Inde ont également montré que les cas pédiatriques d'intoxication aux pesticides étaient importants. Parallèlement aux études du NPIC, une étude rétrospective de 30 cas d'empoisonnement au phosphure d'aluminium chez des enfants de moins de 14 ans entre 2008 et 2013 a été publiée par le Postgraduate Institute of Medical Science, Haryana, Inde.13 Cette étude illustre l'impact dévastateur de un seul pesticide provenant d'un hôpital sur une période de 5 ans, car 14 des 30 cas examinés concernaient des patients qui n'ont pas survécu, ce qui représente un taux de létalité extrêmement élevé de 46,6 %. Une autre étude rétrospective de Mangalore, en Inde, a identifié 31 cas (38,2 % du total) d'empoisonnements pédiatriques par des pesticides de 2010 à 2011, qui comprenaient des organophosphorés, du paraquat, des pyréthrinoïdes et des rodenticides.14 Lorsqu une étude pareille se réalise au Bénin, les résultats seraient similaires ou plus inquiétants du fait de la grande faiblesse des politiques de gestion des pesticides des pays africains y compris le Bénin. Une liste de 82 pesticides et produits chimiques extrêmement dangereux est interdite dutilisation dans les pays de lUE pour sa grave nuisance sur la santé humaine et la biodiversité. Paradoxalement tous les produits de cette liste sont souvent produits et exportés vers les pays en développement comme ceux dAfrique ( Bénin) (Chlorpyrifos, Atrazine). Il urge que le Commission de lUE protège la santé des enfants des pays en développement y compris ceux dAfrique par une règlementation audacieuse.
englishfeedback: Pesticide poisoning is not a new phenomenon. The tragic reality of pesticide poisoning among children in India is that it is not a new or recent event. A retrospective study carried out at Srinagar’s public children’s hospital found that 15 % of children in paediatric admissions for poisoning from 1983 to 1988 were due to pesticides. 9 another study by the Hospital Cooper du Maharashtra found that pesticides were responsible for 9.6 % of paediatric admissions from 1986 to 87.10 In 1997 a hospital in Patna, India, reported 20 cases of highly toxic aluminium phosphide poisoning in children aged 7 to 12 in a single year.11 A more in-depth study of 8 different hospitals published in the Indian Journal of Pediatrics in 1998 revealed that pesticides, insecticides and rodenticides contributed between 1.2 % and 15 % in total paediatric poisons.12. Pesticide poisoning is still a problem At the turn of the millennium, a continuous trend of pesticide poisoning in the paediatric population has been documented. Some of the best evidence to this effect comes from the National Poison Information Centre (NPIC) of the Indian Institute of Medical Sciences in New Delhi. Between April 1999 and March 2002, 9.1 % of telephone calls for paediatric cases were found to be due to poisoning by agricultural pesticides. 6,7 In addition to household pesticides, which included pyrethrinoids (20.3 %), rodenticides (11.3 %) and organophosphorus. 7 another retrospective NPIC study showed that more than 36 % of telephone calls for pesticide poisoning between 1999 and 2012 involved children under 16 years5. 57 % of telephone calls for domestic pesticide poisoning concerned patients under 18 years.8 Studies in other institutions in India also showed that paediatric cases of pesticide poisoning were significant. In parallel to the NPIC studies, a retrospective study of 30 cases of aluminium phosphide poisoning in children under 14 years between 2008 and 2013 was published by the Postgraduate Institute of Medical Science, Haryana, Inde.13 This study illustrates the devastating impact of a single pesticide from a hospital over a period of 5 years, as 14 of the 30 cases examined concerned patients who did not survive, representing an extremely high lethal rate of 46.6 %. Another retrospective study by Mangalore in India identified 31 cases (38.2 % of the total) of paediatric poisoning with pesticides from 2010 to 2011, which included organophosphorus, paraquat, pyrethrinoids and rodenticides.14 When such a study is carried out in Benin, the results would be similar or more worrying due to the very weak pesticide management policies of African countries including Benin. A list of 82 highly hazardous pesticides and chemicals is banned in EU countries for its serious nuisance to human health and biodiversity. Paradoxically, all products in this list are often produced and exported to developing countries such as those in Africa (Benin) (Chlorpyrifos, Atrazine). He urged the EU Commission to protect the health of children in developing countries, including those in Africa, with bold rules.

feedback: Je absolutně nepřípustné, aby se na smrtící pesticidy uplatňoval dvojí metr - že to co je špatné pro použití v EU se stále může vyvážet do jiných zemí. Příroda, živočichové a lidé se nesmí vědomě vraždit nikde na světě jen v zájmu profitu nenasytných nadnárodních firem vyrábějících toxické chemikálie. Je dokázáno, že tyto pesticidy hubí včely a člověk bez opylovačů nepřežije. A jsou vražedné pro celé ekosystémy a biodiverzitu. Prodej a používání těchto smrtících koktejlů porušuje lidská práva a vydělává na nedostatečné legislativě v zemích (nejen) třetího světa. Navíc se i nám Evropanům toto zlo vrací jako bumerang v podobě dovážených surovin a plodin ze zemí kam pesticidy vyvážíme. DOST BYLO JEDŮ!!!
englishfeedback: It is absolutely unacceptable to apply double metres to lethal pesticides – what is wrong for use in the EU can still be exported to other countries. Nature, animals and people must not knowingly be murdered anywhere in the world for the benefit of unsaturated multinational toxic chemicals companies. It is proven that these pesticides kill bees and humans do not survive without pollinators. They are deadly for whole ecosystems and biodiversity. The sale and use of these lethal cocktails violates human rights and benefits from inadequate legislation in countries (not only) of the third world. In addition, this fracture is returning to Europeans as a bumerang in the form of imported raw materials and crops from the countries where we export pesticides. THERE WERE ENOUGH POISONS!

feedback: Ich finde es schändlich, Pestizide, die hier verboten sind, weil sie zu gefährlich und schädlich sind, in andere Teile der Welt zu exportieren, um damit Geld zu verdienen. Dies bedeutet, dass uns egal ist, wenn andere Menschen und die Natur Schaden nehmen, Hauptsache wir verdienen. Es wirft kein gutes Licht auf die EU. Die Menchen dort könnten das Gefühl bekommen, sie sind Menschen 2. Klasse, weil ihre Gesundheit nicht so wichtig ist wie unsere. Deshalb fordere ich die Kommision auf, den Export von Pestiziden, die hier verboten sind, ebenfalls zu verbieten.
englishfeedback: I find it reluctant to export pesticides that are banned here because they are too dangerous and harmful to other parts of the world in order to earn money. This means that we don’t matter if other people and nature are harmed, we deserve the most. It does not shed a good light on the EU. They could feel that they are people 2nd class because their health is not as important as ours. I therefore call on the Commission to also ban the export of pesticides, which are prohibited here.

feedback: Der Export von in Europa verbotenen Pestiziden muß endlich verboten werden! Diese Pestizide stehen in Verdacht: * Krebs zu erzeugen * Hirnschäden bei Kindern und ungeborenen Babys zu verursachen * die Fruchtbarkeit zu beeinträchtigen * neurodegenerative Krankheiten hervorzurufen * zum Bienensterben beizutragen * usw. Das kein Jahr alte Rechtsgutachten des "Center for International Environmental Law" (CIEL) kommt zu dem Schluß, daß die EU mit dem Export verbotener Pestizide nach Afrika und Mittelamerika gegen internationale rechtliche Verpflichtungen und die Menschenrechte verstößt, siehe: https://www.ciel.org/reports/the-export-of-banned-pesticides-to-africa-and-central-america/ Wir Europäer sollten uns schämen, daß wir diese Pestizide exportieren - Schluß damit!
englishfeedback: The export of pesticides banned in Europe must finally be banned! These pesticides are suspected: * Cause cancer * cause brain damage in children and unborn babies * impair fertility * induce neurodegenerative diseases * contribute to bee mortality * etc. The no-year-old legal opinion of the Centre for International Environmental Law (CIEL) concludes that the EU is in breach of international legal obligations and human rights by exporting banned pesticides to Africa and Central America, see: https://www.ciel.org/reports/the-export-of-banned-pesticides-to-africa-and-central-america/ We Europeans should be ashamed that we export these pesticides – the conclusion is!

feedback: Women Engage for a Common Future, WECF, is an international network of over 170 eco- feminist organizations who are active in 70 countries around the world. We are committed to building a healthy environment and moving towards a toxic free future for all. WECFs vision aligns with the goal set by the European Green Deal for a toxic-free environment and the zero-pollution ambition. WECF urges EU authorities to stop the export of toxic chemicals and pesticides to developing countries and should take the lead to stop such practices worldwide. Allowing differing levels of protection for EU and non-EU citizens is not only unethical but also contradicts principles of human rights. WECF work is dedicated to strengthening global and national policies on chemicals and waste, especially from a gender perspective to achieve a better protection from harmful chemicals and strive to build within in our network, including the Women Major Group where WECF is a co-facilitator, a global movement for a future free from toxic substances. The United Nations General Assembly has recognized, through Resolution A/76/L.75, that the unsound management of chemicals and waste has negative implications for the effective enjoyment of human rights. These consequences are particularly felt by vulnerable populations, including women and girls. In our scoping studies undertaken amongst others in Nigeria, Kenia, Indonesia, and Tunisia we found women, pregnant women and children suffering from diseases linked with harmful chemicals, also from those which use is restricted in Europe. Scientists as well as the World Health Organization associate exposure to hazardous chemicals with the development and increase in illnesses in women such as breast cancer, an increase in reproductive disorders. Chemical exposure is linked to developmental disorders in the embryo, preterm births, miscarriages, low birth weight, brain damage, birth defects and neurological diseases. In many developing countries where the EU exports banned and restricted chemicals, there is a lack of basic national chemicals management systems. These countries are less equipped to handle the use of chemicals that have been deemed to pose unacceptable risks in the EU. Low- and middle-income countries are net importers of chemicals, often without adequately considering their health and environmental impacts. Stopping these exports would have multiple benefits, including protecting the environment, biodiversity, and the lives of women and of at-risk populations. Moreover, it would decrease the availability of hazardous chemicals and create stronger incentives for the adoption of safer alternatives. We learned from our case studies that especially women are agents of change in substituting the use of these chemicals with innovative technical and non-chemical and safe alternatives. There is evidence e.g in the agricultural sector that replacing hazardous pesticides with cost-effective alternatives can yield health, environmental, and biodiversity advantages without compromising crop yields. The chemical industry, however, frequently relies on unsubstantiated claims that reducing access to highly hazardous pesticides would threaten food security. In reality, farmers who lack the necessary knowledge and resources to manage the dangers associated with these chemicals are consistently exposed to harm. Acute pesticide poisonings affect around 385 million people annually, primarily in low- and middle-income countries where significant portions of the population are engaged in agriculture or reside in pesticide-use areas. According to the Pesticide Action Network, up to 85 percent of workers being involved in pesticide application on commercial farms and plantations are women. An estimated 30,000 women in Malaysia spray pesticides on an average of 262 days per year. In some countries, 85 per cent of pesticide applicators on commercial farms are women, often without protective clothing ...read more in attached pdf
organization: Women Engage for a Common Future, WECF
attachementDocumentIds: [{'documentId': '090166e5ff735314', 'fileName': 'Submission WECF Ban export of hazardous chemicals.pdf'}]

feedback: Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, ich halte es für äußerst wichtig, dass in Bezug auf Pestizide nicht mit zweierlei Maß gemessen wird. Was bei uns in Europa nicht zugelassen ist, darf auch in anderen Teilen der Erde nicht angewendet werden!W Wir dürfen nicht einerseits uns schützen und andererseits sehenden Auges andere gefährden! Vielen Dank für Ihr offenes Ohr. Mit freundlichen Grüßen Cornelia Osterhorn
englishfeedback: Ladies and gentlemen, I consider it extremely important that no double standards are applied to pesticides. What we are not allowed to do in Europe must not be used in other parts of the world!Where we do not protect us, we must not put other eyes at risk! Thank you very much for your open ear. Yours sincerely, Cornelia Osterhorn

feedback: Estimados miembros de la Comisión europea, en base a mi experiencia en el ámbito de la cooperación internacional y la educación ambiental, les suplico que aprueben esta legislación y que sea lo más ambiciosa posible. Si estas sustancias químicas están prohibidas en la Unión europea es porque la ciencia ha probado con numerosos estudios sus graves perjuicios. En el mundo globalizado que vivimos, queda claro que somos interdependientes, no podemos escapar a lo que ocurre en otros lugares del mundo, con lo cual si distribuimos tales sustancias, de un modo u otro acabará perjudicándonos aquí. Pero además, nuestra buena ética y moral debe quedar por encima del interés económico, ¡qué hipócritas somos al vender a otros lo que nosotros no queremos ni de lejos! Hemos contaminado nuestro planeta hasta tal punto que estamos expuestos a grandes cantidades de muy diversos tóxicos y hemos deteriorado gravemente la naturaleza. Greenpeace tiene numerosos estudios al respecto, por ejemplo, sobre la contaminación del agua, ¡incluso subterránea! Hay millones de casos que argumentarían a favor de esta legislación, aquí va uno de ellos que tenemos bastante cerca. En Francia, existe un gran problema de sobrecrecimiento de cianobacterias que impide el baño en ríos y lagos debido a su toxicidad. Y la razón de ese sobrecrecimiento es principalmente humana. Esas bacterias crecen sobremanera con los fosfatos y otros productos empleados en la agricultura. Esos productos están permitidos y aun así causan enormes estragos, no solo en la zona cercana a los campos de cultivo, sino en numerosas regiones por las que se distribuyen las distintas corrientes de agua. Si esto sucede con fosfatos y otros, ¡imaginen los efectos de las sustancias tóxicas que ya están prohibidas! Vamos tarde y todo lo que podamos hacer es poco, de ahí la gran importancia de avanzar cuanto antes en propuestas como esta legislación. No podemos cerrar los ojos, vivimos en un momento de grandes crisis y está en riesgo nuestra propia supervivencia. Muchas gracias por actuar en beneficio del ser humano y todos los seres vivos de este planeta. Información sobre uno de los casos de cianobacterias: https://france3-regions.francetvinfo.fr/nouvelle-aquitaine/vienne/poitiers/interdiction-de-baignade-pourquoi-les-cyanobacteries-proliferent-elles-2815928.html
englishfeedback: Dear Members of the European Commission, based on my experience in the field of international cooperation and environmental education, I ask you to adopt this legislation and to be as ambitious as possible. If these chemicals are banned in the European Union, it is because science has proven its serious harm with numerous studies. In the globalised world we live, it is clear that we are interdependent, we cannot escape what is happening elsewhere in the world, so if we distribute these substances, in one way or another, you will end up harming us here. But in addition, our good ethics and morals must go beyond the economic interest, what we are when selling to others what we do not want by far! We have polluted our planet to such an extent that we are exposed to large amounts of very diverse toxic substances and we have seriously damaged nature. Greenpeace has numerous studies on water pollution, including underground water pollution, for example! There are millions of cases that would argue in favour of this legislation, here is one of them that we have quite close to us. In France, there is a major overgrowth problem of cyanobacteria which prevents bathing in rivers and lakes due to their toxicity. The reason for this overgrowth is mainly human. These bacteria grow dramatically with phosphates and other products used in agriculture. These products are permitted and still cause enormous rainfall, not only in the area close to the fields, but also in many regions where the different water streams are distributed. If this happens with phosphates and others, imagine the effects of toxic substances that are already banned! We are late and everything we can do is little, hence the great importance of making progress on proposals such as this legislation as soon as possible. We cannot close our eyes, we live at a time of major crises and our own survival is at risk. Thank you very much for acting for the benefit of humans and all living beings on this planet. Information on one of the cyanobacteriaceae cases: https://france3-regions.francetvinfo.fr/nouvelle-aquitaine/vienne/poitiers/interdiction-de-baignade-pourquoi-les-cyanobacteries-proliferent-elles-2815928.html

feedback: Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, ich arbeite in einem Handelsunternehmen für Chemiekalien. Insofern weiß ich ein kleines bisschen etwas über die Schädlichkeit gewissern Chemikalien und warum sie in der EU verboten wurden. Insofern kann ich schlichtweg nicht nachvollziehen, warum solche Chemikalien noch hergestellt und auch noch exportiert werden dürfen. Sind denn die Menschen und die natur außerhalb der EU nicht ebenso schützenswert wie innerhalb der EU?!? Deswegen meine Bitte an Sie: Setzen Sie den Schutz der Umwelt und der Menschheit höher an als den Profit einzelner Unternehmen und verbieten Sie die Herstellung und Ausfuhr aller in der EU verbotenen Chemikalien. Danke. Mit freundlichen Grüßen D. V. Mayer
englishfeedback: Ladies and gentlemen, I work in a chemistry company. So I know a little bit about the harmfulness of certain chemicals and why they have been banned in the EU. In this respect, I simply fail to understand why such chemicals may still be manufactured and exported. Because people and nature outside the EU do not deserve the same protection as inside the EU?! For this reason, I would ask you: Protect the environment and humanity higher than the profits of individual companies and prohibit the production and export of all chemicals banned in the EU. Thanks. Yours sincerely, D.V. Mayer

feedback: Chemikalien, die in der EU verboten wurden, sind erwiesenermaßen gefährlich. Diese Gefahr für Menschen, Tiere oder die Umwelt besteht auch außerhalb der EU. Aus gutem Grund verbotene Stoffe an Länder außerhalb der EU zu verkaufen, kann nur den Grund haben Geld zu verdienen. Hier wird Geld innerhalb der EU verdient andere Menschen, Tiere oder die Umwelt wissentlich zu schaden. Das kann nicht im Sinne der EU sein. Ich kann so etwas nicht unterstützen. Als weiteres kommen diese Chemikalien über Warenströme wieder zu uns zurück und diese Waren von außerhalb der EU müssen mit viel Mühe und Geld analysiert werden. Geld muss ausgegeben werden, da Chemiefirmen mit diesen innerhalb der EU verbotenen Chemikalien Geld verdienen wollen. Nicht erkannte Produkte schaden Menschen in der EU. Daher muss auch im Sinne des Schutzes der Menschen innerhalb der EU die Herstellung und Ausfuhr der verbotenen Chemikalien nicht erlaubt sein. Ich bitte Sie für Chemikalien, deren Verwendung in der EU verboten ist, auch die Herstellung und Ausfuhr zu verbieten.
englishfeedback: Chemicals banned in the EU are proven to be dangerous. This threat to humans, animals or the environment also exists outside the EU. For good reason, selling banned substances to countries outside the EU can only earn money. Here, money within the EU earns knowingly harm to other people, animals or the environment. This cannot be in the spirit of the EU. I cannot support this. In addition, these chemicals come back to us via flows of goods, and these products from outside the EU have to be analysed with great effort and money. Money needs to be spent as chemical companies want to earn money from these chemicals banned within the EU. Unrecognised products harm people in the EU. Therefore, in order to protect people within the EU, the production and export of the banned chemicals need not be allowed. I would ask you to ban the production and export of chemicals whose use is prohibited in the EU.

feedback: Bonjour L'exportation de pesticides toxiques profite des pays où la réglementation est moins stricte. L'UE a un rôle à jouer dans le monde - ses entreprises ne devraient pas être autorisées à profiter des pays où la réglementation est plus faible. Comment pouvons-nous être pris au sérieux si nous expédions nos produits chimiques dangereux à l'étranger, empoisonnant ainsi les populations et la nature dans des pays où les règles de sécurité sont plus faibles et moins strictement appliquées ? Cordialement Dominique Gouhenant Besançon
englishfeedback: Hello The export of toxic pesticides benefits countries with less stringent regulations. The EU has a role to play in the world – its businesses should not be allowed to benefit from countries with weaker regulation. How can we be taken seriously if we send our hazardous chemicals abroad, poisoning people and nature in countries where safety rules are weaker and less strictly enforced? Cordially Dominique Gouhenant Besançon

feedback: Al prohibirse productos irremplazables las plantaciones de banano se eliminarán por falta de competitividad. En el caso de Ecuador existen 8000 productores entre pequeños, medianos y grandes que se verían afectados.
englishfeedback: By banning irreplaceable products, banana plantations will be eliminated due to lack of competitiveness. In the case of Ecuador, there are 8000 producers between small, medium and large that would be affected.

feedback: Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, wir sind fassungslos von diesem Spätkolonialismus - wir haben festgestellt, dass verschiedene Chemikalien schädlich sind und somit zurecht verboten wurden. Was gibt uns das Recht, diese nachweislich schädlichen Chemikalien weiterhinzu produzieren, um sie ins Ausland zu verschiffen. Sind die Menschen dort weniger wert? Richten die Chemikalien dort weniger Schaden an? Bitte beenden Sie dieses skrupellose Vorgehen und verbieten Sie diese Chemikalien generell! Viele Grüße, Markus Enderle
englishfeedback: Ladies and Gentlemen, we are unconscious of this late colonialism – we have found that various chemicals are harmful and therefore rightly banned. What gives us the right to continue producing these proven harmful chemicals to ship them abroad. Are people worth less there? Are the chemicals less harmful there? Please put an end to this unscrupulous approach and ban these chemicals in general! Many greetings, Markus Enderle

feedback: Sehr geehrte Mitglieder der EU Kommission, Sie beraten aktuell über die Ausfuhr von Pestiziden, die in der Europäischen Union verboten sind. Es hat einen triftigen Grund, dass diese Pestizide hier nicht mehr verwendet werden dürfen, denn sie sind schädlich für Mensch, Tier und Umwelt. Was für eine Doppelbödigkeit, diese Pestizide in andere Länder zu verkaufen, wo sie z.T. ohne Schutzstandards einzuhalten ausgebracht werden. Ich bitte inständig darum, dass Sie Redlichkeit und Gewissen vor Profit stellen und die Ausfuhr endlich komplett und ohne Hintertürchen für die chemische Industrie verbieten. Ich danke Ihnen für Ihren Einsatz und hoffe sehr auf eine positive Entscheidung Andrea Betz
englishfeedback: Dear Commissioners, you are currently discussing the export of pesticides banned in the European Union. There is a valid reason why these pesticides can no longer be used here because they are harmful to humans, animals and the environment. What is in favour of a double-style selling of these pesticides to other countries, where they are sometimes applied without protection standards. I urge you to put good faith and conscience to profit and finally ban exports completely and without backdoors for the chemical industry. Thank you for your commitment and I very much look forward to a positive decision by Andrea Betz.

feedback: Je demande l'interdiction définitive et immédiate de l'exportation par l'union européenne de pesticides interdits sur le territoire de l'Union. L'exportation de pesticides toxiques révèle une politique de deux poids deux mesures : Les pesticides dangereux sont interdits en Europe après avoir été associés à des cancers, des problèmes de reproduction et des maladies neurodégénératives, ainsi qu'à la mort des abeilles. Certains de ces pesticides sont même interdits en Europe en raison de leur lien avec des lésions cérébrales chez les enfants et les bébés à naître. Si ces pesticides sont trop dangereux pour nous, comment pouvons-nous autoriser leur exportation ? Un avis juridique du Center for International Environmental Law publié en 2022 montre que les exportations européennes de pesticides interdits vers l'Afrique et l'Amérique centrale violent les obligations juridiques internationales de l'UE et le droit relatif aux droits humains. L'exportation de pesticides toxiques est une question de droits humains , car ces pesticides sont nocifs pour notre santé : Chaque année, des milliers d'agriculteurs meurent des suites dune trop forte exposition à ces pesticides dangereux. Les pesticides exportés font l'objet d'innombrables études qui confirment leurs effets néfastes sur les humains. L'exportation de pesticides toxiques est néfaste pour les abeilles, la biodiversité et la planète en général. Les preuves sont claires : les néonics et autres pesticides dangereux tuent les abeilles. C'est pourquoi ils sont interdits en Europe. Pourquoi autorisons-nous encore leur exportation vers des pays où la réglementation est moins stricte, alors quils continueront de tuer les abeilles et décimer la biodiversité ? L'exportation de pesticides toxiques profite des pays où la réglementation est moins stricte. L'UE a un rôle à jouer dans le monde - ses entreprises ne devraient pas être autorisées à profiter des pays où la réglementation est plus faible. Comment pouvons-nous être pris au sérieux si nous expédions nos produits chimiques dangereux à l'étranger, empoisonnant ainsi les populations et la nature dans des pays où les règles de sécurité sont plus faibles et moins strictement appliquées ? L'interdiction d'exporter des pesticides toxiques serait une opportunité unique pour l'innovation et aiderait l'Europe et le monde à évoluer vers des méthodes de protection des plantes plus durables. Le maintien sur le marché de pesticides anciens et dangereux nous prive d'un avenir plus vert et de pratiques agricoles plus durables.
englishfeedback: I call for a definitive and immediate ban on the export by the EU of pesticides banned from EU territory. The export of toxic pesticides reveals a double standard policy: Hazardous pesticides are banned in Europe after being associated with cancer, reproductive problems and neurodegenerative diseases, as well as bee death. Some of these pesticides are even banned in Europe because of their link to brain damage in children and born babies. If these pesticides are too dangerous for us, how can we authorise their export? A legal opinion of the Center for International Environmental Law published in 2022 shows that European exports of banned pesticides to Africa and Central America violate the EU’s international legal obligations and human rights law. The export of toxic pesticides is a human rights issue, as these pesticides are harmful to our health: Every year, thousands of farmers die as a result of excessive exposure to these hazardous pesticides. Exported pesticides are subject to countless studies confirming their adverse effects on humans. The export of toxic pesticides is harmful to bees, biodiversity and the planet in general. The evidence is clear: neonics and other hazardous pesticides kill bees. This is why they are banned in Europe. Why do we still allow their export to countries with less stringent regulation, while they will continue to kill bees and decay biodiversity? The export of toxic pesticides benefits countries with less stringent regulation. The EU has a role to play in the world – its businesses should not be allowed to benefit from countries with weaker regulation. How can we be taken seriously if we send our hazardous chemicals abroad, poisoning people and nature in countries where safety rules are weaker and less strictly enforced? Banning the export of toxic pesticides would be a unique opportunity for innovation and would help Europe and the world to move towards more sustainable plant protection methods. Keeping old and dangerous pesticides on the market deprives us of a greener future and more sustainable agricultural practices.

feedback: Sind Leben und Gesundheiut von Menschen in der südlichen Hemisphere weniger schützenswert? Für den Profit der Konzerne würde ein unmoralisches Menschenbild greifen... Deshalb: setzen sie sich ein für ein EXPORTVERBOT FÜR GIFTIGE PESTIZIDE! Danke Christoff Guttermann und Familie
englishfeedback: Are the lives and healthy marriages of people in the southern hemisphere less worthy of protection? For the profits of the groups, an immoral image of people would be used... Therefore: they are in favour of a ban on exports for GIFITAL PESTIZIDE! Thanks Christoff GUTTERMANN and family

feedback: Une précision : je souhaite qu'après une étude de la question, une dérogation puisse être accordée aux produits qui sont jugés nécessaires pour lutter contre les formes aiguës du Paludisme, même s'ils sont dangereux à long termes.
englishfeedback: A clarification: I would like to see an exemption for products that are deemed necessary to combat acute Paludism shapes, even if they are dangerous in the long term, following a study of the issue.

feedback: The South African People's Tribunal is a voluntary collaboration of people in South Africa who are affected by agrotoxins, including farm workers, small scale farmers, workers unions and consumers. Also amongst us are support NGOs, academic experts and legal practitioners. We share information amongst our networks regarding our real-lived experiences with pesticides and are in solidarity with each other's campaigns. We aim to expose the human rights violations that many of us experience daily due to exposure to dangerous agrochemicals, leading to chronic illness and death, as well as an attack on our dignity and right to a safe environment. Through our documentation of the violations of our health and rights, and through our sharing of lived experiences, we have agreed that the agrotoxin industry epitomises the brutality or our industrialised food system, in which grossly skewed power relations impact on the health, rights and agency of workers, smallholders, society's most vulnerable and citizens in general. Further, the agrotoxin industry is allowed to act with impunity in South Africa, with negligible safeguards enforced to protect us, while similarly, there is little oversight over farm bosses and the way agrotoxins are used on their private property. We respectfully request the EU to consider our health and our rights by ensuring that the same respect for health, rights and environment that is applied in your territory with regard to the sale and trade of highly hazardous pesticides (HHPs) is extended to ours. We ask for an end to double standards in the trade of these substances. We note with alarm the incidents of vested interests threatening the South African government with legal actions as well as other forms of intimidation aimed at the government and citizens who call for an end to harmful pesticides, and demand social justice and corporate accountability. Amongst us is the Women on Farms Project (WFP), which has documented the extensive health impacts of agrotoxins on women farm-workers and farm dwellers, including cancers and respiratory problems, as well as the human rights injustices on farms. These include lack of training, protective gear, washing and ablution stations and access to medical care and workers compensation. WFP is therefore calling for an end to the import of all pesticides banned in the EU into South Africa, as well as, amongst other things, a transition to alternative, safe agricultural practices. Farm worker union CSAAWU has delved into the serious health problems created by exposure to agrotoxins in the Cape winelands and exposed the many human rights violations that accompany this. Citizens campaigning network, UnPoison is amongst other activities, creating reporting mechanisms for pesticide poisonings for farm workers and recording the impact of pesticide drift on communities adjacent to industrial farms. We also note that an agrochemical warehouse was set on fire during protests in 2021 (the Cornubia Fire), in which over 700 chemicals burned. Some of these are banned in the EU and US, and were imported and stored in contravention to the Rotterdam Convention. Fragmented government legislation and lack of preparedness for such an event led to a public health disaster. The company opened a mobile clinic which was under-resourced and has not provided sufficient care. The adjacent river, previously used by the community including for irrigation is no longer safe. A study is now under way by the University of Cape Town, to determine the impacts of this disaster on children's health and development as well as community response and agency. We are of the strong opinion that the best way to safeguard our health, rights and environment is to stop these highly hazardous pesticides at the source and to begin efforts to transform out of related agricultural practices altogether.

A Anipla não concorda com uma abordagem de proibição. O regulamento PIC deve ser reforçado, de modo a que a segurança de transporte e utilização dos produtos, os programas de formação nos países terceiros e as necessidades que outras geografias têm destes produtos, pela sua diferente caracterização climática, quer ao nível agrícola, quer ao nível da saúde. Assim, apelamos a uma abordagem de reforço do regulamento PIC que contemple as medidas enumeradas de seguida: Alargar a obrigação de os países importadores consentirem explicitamente todas as importações e fornecerem informações pormenorizadas sobre a utilização final de uma determinada substância no país; Introduzir uma declaração de utilização para os produtos químicos importados, tal como está atualmente em vigor para as medidas anti-dumping e suspensões/certificados de tarifas, que permitirá as exportações dessas utilizações não restringidas na UE; Introdução de referências às práticas de utilização segura a serem aplicadas no país importador no formulário de consentimento explícito; Criação de um sistema de gestão e rastreio de incidentes para os produtos químicos enumerados nos anexos PIC. A harmonização da documentação digital fornecida pelas empresas para garantir o cumprimento das normas de segurança nas exportações. Sublinhamos que uma proibição só levará a que as rigorosas condições de fabrico praticadas em solo europeu, possam deixar de ser uma garantia se as produções forem deslocalizadas. As cadeias de informação, transparência e transmissão de boas práticas de segurança podem ficar comprometidas. A um nível mais prático, estamos a colocar em causa a utilização de produtos que são essenciais para o controlo de vetores de doenças, de controlo de pragas, doenças e infestantes agrícolas que não se encontram em solo europeu, mas que são aí consumidos, colocando em causa a sobrevivência destas cadeias de valor. Por outro lado, esta é uma oportunidade para reforçar a adoção de boas práticas de segurança e ambientais nos países terceiros, através do reforço dos acordos de exportação no âmbito do PIC, de acordo com os postos já enumerados anteriormente.
surname: Associação Nacional da Indústria para a Proteção das Plantas
englishfeedback: ANIPLA does not agree with a prohibition approach. The PIC Regulation should be strengthened so that the safe transport and use of products, training programmes in third countries and the needs of other geographies of these products, due to their different climatic characteristics, be it agricultural or health. We therefore call for an approach to strengthening the CIP Regulation that includes the measures listed below: Extend the obligation for importing countries to explicitly consent to all imports and to provide detailed information on the end-use of a given substance in the country; Introduce a declaration of use for imported chemicals, as currently in force for anti-dumping measures and tariff suspensions/certificates, which will allow exports of such unrestricted uses in the EU; Introduction of references to safe use practices to be applied in the importing country in the explicit consent form; Establishment of an incident management and tracking system for chemicals listed in the PIC Annexes. Harmonisation of digital documentation provided by companies to ensure compliance with export security standards. We stress that a ban will only mean that strict production conditions on European soil can no longer be guaranteed if production is relocated. Information chains, transparency and the transmission of good security practices may be compromised. At a more practical level, we are calling into question the use of products that are essential for vector control, control of agricultural pests, diseases and weeds that are not on European soil but consumed there, jeopardising the survival of these value chains. On the other hand, this is an opportunity to enhance the adoption of good safety and environmental practices in third countries by strengthening export agreements under the CIP, in line with the posts already listed above.

feedback: Agrarkonzerne wie BASF und Bayer-Monsanto machen riesige Gewinne mit dem Export giftiger Pestizide nach Afrika und Südamerika. Damit gefährden sie das Leben der Menschen, die dort in der Landwirtschaft arbeiten und vergiften den Planeten. In Europa sind diese Pestizide verboten. Warum? Weil sie zu gefährlich sind. Daher möchte ich nicht, dass in Europa verbotene Pestizide außereuropäisch verkauft werden! Mit welcher Logik kann das überhaupt erlaubt sein? Einfach nur zynisch!
englishfeedback: Agricultural groups such as BASF and Bayer-Monsanto make huge profits from exporting toxic pesticides to Africa and South America. As a result, they threaten the lives of people working in agriculture and poisoning the planet. These pesticides are banned in Europe. Why? Because they are too dangerous. So I do not want pesticides banned in Europe to be sold outside Europe! What logic can this be allowed at all? Just cynical!

feedback: Please find below Cefics feedback to the call for evidence on the European Commission initiative Hazardous chemicals prohibiting production for export of chemicals banned in the European Union". Cefic understands the reasons and the intent behind this initiative, that is why it is important to address it through the most effective policy instrument. We ask that the action is implemented in a way that substantially contributes to both the protection of health and the environment, particularly in third countries while ensuring a global level playing field. The following suggestions and recommendations can help to achieve these goals: 1. Global issues should be tackled with global solutions: given the global nature of trade, only global initiatives like the better implementation of the Rotterdam Convention can tackle the issue. This will help to ensure adequate regulation while providing a level playing field. 2. Cefic supports the review and improvement of the EU Prior Informed Consent (PIC) regulation 3. Production and export bans should be considered as measures of last resort for chemical substances banned in the EU 4. There is a need for clear definitions, processes, and case-by-case decisions 5. Compliance with World Trade Organisation (WTO) law and the Rotterdam Convention needs to be ensured More detailed views can be found in attachment to this submission. Please also note Cefic's reponse to the public consultation that is occuring in parallel.
attachementDocumentIds: [{'documentId': '090166e5ff7209a1', 'fileName': '20230731_ Cefic view paper on European Commission initiative_“Hazardous chemicals – prohibiting production for export of chemicals banned in the European Union”.pdf'}]

feedback: Cosmetics Europe is the trade association representing the interests of the European cosmetics, toiletry and perfumery industry. Our members include cosmetics and personal care manufacturers as well as associations representing our industry at national level, right across Europe. Whilst welcoming the objectives of the European Commissions Chemicals Strategy for Sustainability (CSS) for a robust chemicals policy framework that protects consumers and the environment, we highlight that it needs to ensure the European industrys competitiveness and innovation capacity. The EU is the worldwide largest manufacturer and exporter of cosmetic products. The impact of a production-for-export ban of cosmetic products would largely depend on the scope and nature of the substances concerned, as well on the function within a certain product (category) which may be specific to certain needs in third countries/other continents. CE is concerned that the public consultation misguidedly mixes two very different scenarios, when proposing export bans of substances due to their hazardous properties and/or unacceptable risks to human health or the environment. CE supports export restrictions of substances (or products containing them) which are banned in the EU based on a risk assessment that has shown an unacceptable risk. To our understanding, this approach applies to all substances currently included in the Rotterdam Convention. We believe that this approach should be continued and can be refined under the PIC Regulation. However, Cosmetics Europe cannot agree to a similar approach for substances solely based on hazard classification. Whether or not a hazardous substance poses an unacceptable risk depends on its use and can only be assessed by a risk assessment. A wide extension of the PIC regulation would inevitably lead to export bans/restrictions of safe cosmetic products and thereby seriously damage the EU industrys global competitiveness. The EU Scientific Committee for Consumer Safety has on repeated occasions declared the use of cosmetic ingredients as safe, despite their chemical hazard classification. It must be reminded that the EU Cosmetic Products Regulation is based on a risk approach which requires every product to undergo an in-depth assessment by a qualified Safety Assessor who takes into consideration the toxicological profile as well as the consumer exposure of each ingredient. Based on this requirement EU cosmetic products are considered as a global reference for safe cosmetic products. Indeed, the safety assessment methodology developed in the EU has been copied in many regions around the globe. The environmental safety of cosmetic products is governed by the requirements of REACH whose environmental risk assessment under the Chemical Safety Report ensures environmental safety of cosmetic products placed on the market. It is unlikely that other global regions would follow the EU in banning cosmetic products that fulfill all required high safety standards simply because of a hazard classification of certain ingredients. Manufacturing and supply of these safe products will still take place in the future it will simply no longer be taking place in the EU but in regions where the human and environmental/safety requirements for manufacturing may be different than in the EU. The socio-economic impact of such move should not be underestimated. Whilst possibly strengthening the credibility of the EU at international level, this would come at the cost of forcing EU cosmetic companies to move their manufacturing basis to third countries to be able to continue providing international customers with safe products. There is no prospect that, in the longer term, such manufacturing would be brought back into the EU.

Jako obywatelka Europy, jako człowiek, który chce żyć i przekazać przyszłym pokoleniom Ziemię zdatną do życia, nie chcę uczestniczyć w procederze pozyskiwania szkodliwych pestycydów w krajach poza Europą. To krótkoterminowy i okrutny bonus, na którym wszyscy tracą. Jest to nieetyczne i szkodliwe dla naszej teraźniejszości i przyszłości. Ne zgadzam się na to. Chcę zakazu tego procederu. Anna Rau (Polska)
englishfeedback: As a European citizen, as a person who wants to live and pass on a viable earth to future generations, I do not want to participate in the sourcing of harmful pesticides in countries outside Europe. It is a short-term and cruel bonus where everyone loses. This is unethical and detrimental to our present and future. I do not agree with this. I want to ban this practice. Anna Rau (Poland)

feedback: Aucun être humain ne devrait être confronté à l'utilisation de pesticides dangereux pour sa santé. A ce titre, il n'y a aucune raison pour que les produits dont l'utilisation est interdite dans l'Union Européenne soient utilisés au-delà des frontières de celle-ci. Il est temps que l'être humain prenne globalement conscience des dangers et des impacts à court, moyen et long terme sur les êtres vivants humains et non humains. Au bénéfice d'une meilleure qualité de vie sur Terre et de la préservation de la biodiversité.
englishfeedback: No human being should be confronted with the use of pesticides that are harmful to their health. There is therefore no reason why products whose use is prohibited in the European Union should be used beyond its borders. It is time for humans to become generally aware of the short-, medium- and long-term hazards and impacts on human and non-human living beings. For the benefit of a better quality of life on Earth and the preservation of biodiversity.

feedback: Chemical Industry Federation Finland supports the comments by Cefic. Additionally, we would like to emphasize the following: Chlorates, including sodium chlorate are banned in the EU as pesticides, and hence they are included in the PIC-regulation restricted chemicals list and part of the prior informed concent procedure for exports. Sodium chlorate is used in pulp industry in the EU and it is also exported for that use. When considering the export ban, we thing it would not be logical to set additional requirements for export of a substance which has safe uses in the EU and also outside the union. The EU regulation (EU) 649/2012 concerning the export and import on hazardous chemicals (PIC-regulation) covers much wider selection of chemicals compared to the Rotterdam Convention. Therefore, the prior informed concent, the requirement to provide safety data sheet and the requirements for packaging and labeling are also in place for this wide set of chemicals when exported. The prior informed concent help the receiving countries authorities keep record when these chemicals enter the country and for which uses and users they are imported. The users benefit from SDS and other safety measures required by the EU PIC Regulation. If the EU exports are banned, and the market is replaced by non-EU suppliers, the receiving countries would not necessarily have the same possibilities to prohibit the import or receive any information on the import of chemicals, which are not part of the Rotterdam Convention, but are included in the EU PIC regulation. The same is true for the users, it may be, that SDS or classification or packaging requirements are not as extensive as in the EU exports. This might affect the overall safety in countries, which do not have their own production of these chemicals. Should you wish to have more detailed info on the above, we are pleased to give further information.
Please find Eurometaux's response to this initiative in attachment.

En tant que français nous avons eu à connaître les scandales dûs â la fabrication et l'utilisation du chlordecone, aussi suis je opposé à la fabrication et l'utilisation de tout produit chimique qui pourrait avoir des conséquences sur l'humain, la flore et la faune où que ce soit sur ou sous la terre ou la mer
englishfeedback: As a French, we have been aware of the scandals about the manufacture and use of chlordecone, and I am against the manufacture and use of any chemical that could have an impact on humans, flora and fauna, whether on or under the land or the sea.

feedback: Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, Die Ausfuhr gefährlicher Chemikalien oder jeglicher anderer Produkte, welche in Europa als zu riskant für den Verbrauch gesehen werden, ist heuchlerisch. Darüberhinaus untergräbt die EU damit auch jegliche eigene Ziele, wie nachhaltige Landwirtschaft, Eindämmung des Artensterbens und Flucht durch Kontaminierung oder Verlust des Lebensraums. Mit hoffnungsvollen Grüßen
englishfeedback: Ladies and Gentlemen, The export of dangerous chemicals or any other product that is considered to be too risky for consumption in Europe is worried. In addition, the EU also undermines any of its own objectives, such as sustainable agriculture, halting species extinction and escape through contamination or habitat loss. Hopefully,

feedback: Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, nicht ohne Grund verbieten wir in Europa gefährliche Chemiekalien und Pestizide. Ich finde es absolut desaströs, dass Firmen und Konzerne genau diese Chemikalien aus der EU in andere Länder exportieren dürfen, nur weil diese nicht so strenge Vorschriften beim Einsatz dieser Mittel haben. Hier geht es mal wieder nur um das Geld und nicht um das Wohl von Natur und Menschen! Wenn diese Gewinnmaximierung der Hersteller von diesen Chemikalien auf Kosten der Landwirte und der Natur in den ärmeren Ländern immer so weiter geht, werden wir uns im Bereich Umweltschutz, Artensterben und Menschenrechte nie verbessern. Bitte verbieten Sie also die Herstellung und Ausfuhr von Chemikalien, die in der EU verboten sind! Mit freundlichen Grüßen Sylva Schubert
englishfeedback: Ladies and gentlemen, not without reason, we are banning hazardous chemicals and pesticides in Europe. I find it absolutely disastrous that companies and groups are allowed to export exactly these chemicals from the EU to other countries, just because they do not have such strict rules on the use of these resources. Once again, it is just about money, not about the well-being of nature and people! As this profit maximisation of producers of these chemicals continues at the expense of farmers and nature in poorer countries, we will never improve environmental protection, species extinction and human rights. So please prohibit the production and export of chemicals that are banned in the EU! Yours sincerely, Sylva Schubert

feedback: BUND für Umwelt und Naturschutz Deutschland e.V. (BUND) calls for an export ban of hazardous chemicals and pesticides that are prohibited or severely restricted in the EU. In 2021, chemicals governed by the PIC Regulation were exported from 24 EU Member States to more than 125 non-EU countries. A total of 791,157 tonnes of exports from 532 EU-based companies were reported. Of those, industrial chemicals made up 560,381 tonnes, examples being nonylphenols (NPs) and nonylphenol ethoxylates (NPEs). The EU suspects NPs and NPEs to cause embryonic damage and negatively affect reproductive capacity. Outside the EU, they are widely used in the garment industry and impact water quality by entering the aquatic environment after washing processes. They are also detectable in parts of the environment within the EU, not least because the EU is importing textiles which contain NPs and NPEs. For the sake of the environment and human health, we need to put an end to the double standard which allows the export of chemicals banned at domestic level. This requires an export ban which applies to all chemicals that are banned under the PIC Regulation as well as robust measures to ensure compliance. We thus call, with utmost urgency, on the European Commission to uphold its commitment to a Green Deal and table, without further delay, a legislative proposal to prohibit the export of all pesticides and other hazardous chemicals that are banned or severely restricted within the EU, to put an end to double standards, and to ensure a level-playing field for the industry and harmonization between national legislations. A EU-wide export ban will promote a global transition away from dangerous chemicals and towards more sustainable practices and safer alternatives, whilst sending a signal to governments and companies worldwide that hazardous pesticides and chemicals should not be tolerated anywhere.
organization: Bund für Umwelt und Naturschutz Deutschland e.V.

feedback: PAN Germany explicitly welcomes the European Commission's initiative to prohibit production and/or export of hazardous chemicals that are banned in the EU with the objective to increase protection for human health and the environment globally and to apply uniform measures in all EU countries. Prohibiting the export of banned pesticides to third countries is an overdue and indispensable step to end harmful double standards in pesticide trade, to overcome the undermining of human rights by exported toxic pesticides and to reduce barriers towards an achievement of the UN Sustainable Development Goals. With the justified non-approval of pesticides, the EU fulfils its protection obligations towards its farmers, its population in general, the environment and biodiversity. This protection currently ends at the EU's external borders: Pesticide companies in the EU export thousands of tonnes of pesticides not approved in the EU to third countries. Among the exported pesticides that are pesticides that have high acute toxicity (WHO Category 1B), recognised health hazards (EU Category 1B for genotoxicity, carcinogenicity, or reproductive toxicity), are water contaminants or highly hazardous to bees. Those pesticides cause harm wherever they are applied whether in high-income, middle-income or low-income countries. The fact that many importing countries have weaker pesticide laws, precarious conditions of use, people are often inadequately informed and protected and poisoning centres are rare, engraves the situation. The current mechanisms at global and EU level that regulate pesticide trade or global bans are highly insufficient. EU Regulation No 649/2012 (EU PIC-Regulation) has perhaps increased information sharing regarding pesticides that needs export notifications, but it has not solved the problem of poisonings by EU-banned pesticides. There is multiple proof that pesticides that are exported by EU companies are causing harm in third countries. Two examples out of many are Cyanamide causing unintentional poisonings in New Zeeland and sever health damage in African farmers and Fipronil, leading to bee deaths in Brazil, South Africa and Mexico, where indigenous bee keeper suffer from the environmental and economic blow. PAN Germany welcomes that the EU, in line with its environmental policy objectives, does not wish products produced within the EU and then being exported to third countries to cause such harm. With this initiative, the EU is taking a necessary and appropriate step towards implementing its Chemicals Strategy and to fulfil its obligation of securing the human right to a clean, healthy and sustainable environment. According to UN Special Rapporteur on toxics and human rights the export of pesticides or toxic substances which are banned in the country of origin exacerbate environmental injustice and constitute discriminatory practice and this practice undermine EUs leadership in the chemical and waste cluster as well as the effectiveness of its efforts at international cooperation. This practice also contributes to keeping harmful outdated pesticides on the market and preventing innovation that is needed to booster more sustainable alternatives. The Commissions main objective is to increase the protection of human health and the environment in the Union and globally from hazardous chemicals and to set an example as one of the global leaders. There is a broad support from civil society, unions and trade organisations from around the world for the EU to prohibit the production and export of hazardous EU-banned chemicals.

feedback: Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, Danke dass Sie uns bei dieser Umfrage beteiligen. Mir ist es ein großes Anliegen, dass keine giftigen Pestizide in andere Länder ausgeführt werden. Es kann nicht sein, dass was bei uns als giftig erkannt wurde, anderen Menschen zugemutet wird. Das finde ich mehr als respektlos. Außerdem müssen wir davon ausgehen, dass vergiftete Lebensmittel über den Import wieder zu uns gelangen. Mit freundlichen Grüßen Petra Langguth
englishfeedback: Dear Sir/Madam, thank you for participating in this survey. I am very concerned that no toxic pesticides are exported to other countries. It cannot be that what has been identified as toxic in us is expected to other people. I find this more than disrespectful. We also have to assume that poisoned food will come back to us via import. Yours sincerely, Petra Langguth

feedback: Desde SEO/BirdLife consideramos positiva la iniciativa de la Comisión Europea para introducir una prohibición a la fabricación de productos químicos peligrosos (poniendo el foco en los plaguicidas) que no estén aprobados o estén prohibidos para su comercialización y/o uso en la UE y proponemos algunas consideraciones para mejorar su propuesta legislativa (ver archivo adjunto).
