feedback: Please see our feedback in the attached position paper.

Dear EU representatives, Many Scientists have alerted on the facts that chemical pollution and dissemination is already growing and spreading on all ecosystems beyond control all around the world. Biodiversity is already suffering from it, particularly insects, birds and aquatic life all around the world. This planetary limit has been already largely exceeded. Even in the EU, only few chemical products have already been fully tested regarding damages that can occur on ecosystems and human health with respects to the vast amount of diverse chemical products that are being sold. The effect of all the rest is largely unknown, environmental/ecotoxicological data is often missing. there are so many chemical cocktails, predicting all the effects is very challenging. We can still find in EU environment many traces of products that have been banned many years ago, even in our bodies through food. If we are serious about protecting environment and biodiversity, the products that are already been identified as hazardous, persistent or damaging to the environment and forbidden in the EU should not been allowed to be exported and fall under severe restriction of use. Independant research should be conducted on all the others to characterize their potential to harm environment and human health. Until then, the precaution principle should apply. As a citizen, I am particularly worried that this insidious pollution will translate into many cancers and other bad side effects on human health and biodiversity losses, if we continue like this. Developing countries are particularly vulnerable with this respect and lack proper chemical products management system. We need ambitious laws to reduce these risks Sincerely yours

Es gibt einen guten Grund, warum bestimmte Chemikalien in der EU nicht zugelassen sind. Es gibt keine Veranlassung zu glauben, dass diese Chemikalien im Ausland weniger Schaden anrichten als in der EU selbst. Auch Mensch und Umwelt in anderen Bereichen der Welt sind schützenswert - zumal es naiv ist zu glauben, die Chemikalien würden sich von Ländergrenzen aufhalten lassen und nicht wieder in die EU zurückkehren - sei es in Form von Nahrungsmitteln oder Produkten aus dem Ausland, sei es durch Wasser und Luft, die sich nicht an Ländergrenzen halten. Es ist klar, dass monetäre Interessen alleine dafür gesorgt haben, dass diese Chemikalien weiterhin ins Ausland exportiert werden dürfen. Im Interesse der Gesundheit aller EU- und nicht-EU-Bürger sollte diese Praxis auf jeden Fall überdacht werden. Die Grenzen, innerhalb derer ein sicherer Umgang mit kritischen Chemikalien weltweit gewährleistet werden konnte, sind bereits deutlich überschritten. Wir dürfen uns und kommenden Generationen nicht noch mehr Kontamination aufbürden als bereits bisher geschehen.
englishfeedback: There is a good reason why certain chemicals are not authorised in the EU. There is no reason to believe that these chemicals cause less damage abroad than in the EU itself. Human beings and the environment in other parts of the world are also worthy of protection – especially as it is naive to believe that chemicals would be kept at national borders rather than returning to the EU, whether in the form of food or products from abroad, or through water and air that do not adhere to national borders. It is clear that monetary interests alone have ensured that these chemicals can continue to be exported abroad. In the interests of the health of all EU and non-EU citizens, this practice should in any case be reconsidered. The limits within which safe handling of critical chemicals could be guaranteed worldwide have already been significantly exceeded. We must not burden ourselves and future generations with more contamination than we have done so far.

feedback: Wer klar denken kann und keine Klientelpolitik verfolgt, muss gegen Herstellung und Ausfuhr von in der EU verbotenen Chemikalien sein!
englishfeedback: Anyone who can think clearly and does not pursue a client policy must be opposed to the production and export of chemicals banned in the EU!

feedback: Cégünk egy magyarországi középvállalat, amely növényvédő szer hatóanyagokat és készítményeket gyárt, köztük olyan hatóanyagokat is, amelyek a PIC rendelet I. mellékletében szerepelnek. Igy közvetlenül érintettek vagyunk a kérdésben, és van rálátásunk az export tilalom lehetséges hatásaira. A tilalom bevezetésével sérülne az Unión kívüli országok joga, hogy dönthessenek arról, milyen vegyi anyagokat importáljanak, ill. honnan szerezzék be azokat. Az igény megvan ezekre a hatóanyagokra, ha szűkül a kínálatuk, az pl. növényvédő szerek esetében növényegészségügyi problémákhoz vezethet. Ha pedig más, nem EU-s forrásból beszerezhetőek lesznek, akkor a nem uniós országok ugyanúgy ki lesznek téve bizonyos vegyi anyagok káros hatásainak. Sok esetben az EU-n kívül olyan hatásterületen alkalmazzák az Unióban betiltott hatóanyagokat, amelyre az európai kockázat értékelés nem terjedt ki. Tehát esetenként a helyi hatóságok tájékozottabbak lehetnek az adott felhasználás kockázataival kapcsolatban, mint az európai szervezetek. Az exportőröket is jelentős hátrányok érhetik. Miután itt szinte kivétel nélkül szabadon gyártható (szabadalommal már nem védett) hatóanyagokról van szó, a nem uniós országokban jelentkező piaci igényt Európán kívüli gyártóhelyek ki tudják, és ki is fogják elégíteni. Így Európa versenyhátrányba kerülne az EU-n kívüli gyártókkal szemben. Európán belül pedig azok a közép- vagy kisvállalatok kerülnének hátrányba a multinacionális vállalatokkal szemben, amelyek nem tudják kihelyezni gyártásukat harmadik országbeli leányvállalatokhoz, gyáregységekhez. Vállalatunknak sem állna módjában kihelyezni a gyártását, ami esetünkben a munkahelyek számának jelentős (25-50%-os) csökkenéséhez vezetne. A javaslat globális előnyös hatása tehát megkérdőjelezhető. Az export tilalom bevezetésével az exportőr és az importőr érdekei is sérülnének, továbbá kétséges, hogy harmadik országokban csökkennének a vegyi anyagok okozta káros hatások. Úgy gondoljuk, hogy a cél megvalósítása komplex megoldást igényel. Elsősorban a PIC rendeletre kell alapozni, annak megerősítésével, hatékonyabb alkalmazásával. Fontos, hogy megbízható információs rendszer álljon rendelkezésre, hogy az EU-n kívüli országok felelős döntést hozhassanak a termékek használatáról. Ennek az átlátható, megbízható rendszernek a kialakításában valóban élen járhat az Unió.
englishfeedback: Our company is a medium-sized company in Hungary that manufactures active substances and preparations of plant protection products, including active substances listed in Annex I to the PIC Regulation. We are directly involved in the issue and we have an insight into the possible effects of the export ban. The ban would undermine the right of non-EU countries to decide which chemicals should be imported and sourced from. There is a need for these active substances if their supply is reduced, e.g. in the case of plant protection products, it may lead to plant health problems. And if they are available from other non-EU sources, non-EU countries will be equally exposed to the adverse effects of certain chemicals. In many cases, active substances banned in the EU are used outside the EU in an area of action not covered by the European risk assessment. In some cases, local authorities may therefore be better informed about the risks of specific uses than European organisations. Exporters may also suffer significant disadvantages. As these are almost all freely manufactured active ingredients (no longer protected by patents), the market demand in non-EU countries can and will be met by production sites outside Europe. This would put Europe at a competitive disadvantage vis-à-vis non-EU manufacturers. Within Europe, medium-sized or small companies that are unable to outsource their production to subsidiaries and factories in third countries would be at a disadvantage compared to multinational companies. Nor would our company be in a position to locate its production, which would lead to a significant reduction in the number of jobs (25-50 %) in our case. The overall benefit of the proposal is therefore questionable. The introduction of an export ban would harm both the interests of the exporter and the importer and it is doubtful that the adverse effects of chemicals in third countries will be reduced. We believe that achieving this goal requires a complex solution. It should primarily be based on the PIC Regulation by strengthening it and applying it more effectively. It is important to have a reliable information system in place to enable countries outside the EU to make responsible decisions on the use of products. Indeed, the EU can be at the forefront of this transparent, reliable system.

feedback: Em vez de proibir o fabrico e comércio destas substâncias, a UE deve trabalhar na partilha das suas boas práticas bem estabelecidas em matéria de segurança, avaliação dos riscos dos produtos químicos e transparência. Analisando todas as evidências, a proibição da exportação de produtos químicos não aprovados para venda na Europa seria prejudicial para os países terceiros, para o ambiente e para a economia europeia. Sendo a UE líder mundial relativamente à regulamentação em matéria de substâncias químicas, acreditamos que a estreita colaboração entre a indústria (como a rede CropLife em todo o mundo) e as autoridades, a nível internacional, terá mais sucesso em melhorar a segurança de utilização e a transparência das substâncias exportadas e aplicadas em países terceiros. Tendo em conta o objetivo prosseguido pela CE, a APOSOLO considera que o reforço do Regulamento PIC (Reg (UE) n.º 649/2012) será a forma mais eficaz de o alcançar. A UE deve trabalhar em conjunto com a indústria para apoiar países terceiros e organizações como a OCDE e a FAO a estabelecer as melhores práticas de transparência e rastreabilidade da informação, dando o exemplo e transferindo as rigorosas normas de segurança europeias. A UE conseguirá garantir um sistema transparente e claro para a cadeia de abastecimento mundial de produtos químicos e melhorar a utilização segura de produtos químicos perigosos, por todas as partes interessadas, se reforçar a aplicação do PIC. Lembramos que algumas substâncias são registadas e utilizadas em países terceiros por razões diferentes às da não proteção das culturas, como o controlo de vetores; e que os produtos considerados são exportados para satisfazer necessidades específicas e de agricultores fora da UE com necessidades diferentes - as condições agronómicas e edafoclimáticas variam entre regiões. Nos climas tropicais e subtropicais, por exemplo, a pressão de pragas e doenças tende a ser mais elevada devido à combinação de calor e humidade, resultando em diferentes infestantes, pragas e doenças. Tal é evidenciado igualmente na Europa, quando se consideram diferentes zonas para a avaliação de risco ao abrigo do Reg. 1107/2009. Chamamos a atenção que a proibição das exportações de produtos químicos a partir da UE aumentaria ainda o risco de utilização de pesticidas ilegais e contrafeitos, e comprometeria a competitividade da UE, o emprego e o investimento na inovação no sector. E consequentemente resultará provavelmente na deslocação da produção para outras regiões como a China e a Índia. Outra dificuldade é perceber o que pode estar implícito, uma vez que não existe uma definição do significado de "substâncias proibidas". Na UE, existem numerosas substâncias não autorizadas para uma determinada utilização (por exemplo, uso de pesticidas), mas que são plenamente válidas ao abrigo de outro regime da UE (por exemplo, medicina veterinária). Outro impacto é a disponibilidade e acesso a PPP para tratamentos de sementes, que deveriam ser exportadas para países terceiros. Ao abrigo do Pacto Ecológico Europeu certamente existirá um aumento do número de substâncias/utilizações não aprovadas. Entendemos que qualquer avaliação de impacto deve procurar ser tão prospetiva quanto possível acautelando futuras necessidades. Recomendamos a CE a realizar uma avaliação de impacto exaustiva antes de apresentar qualquer proposta. A ter em consideração elementos como: a informação proveniente do exterior da UE (por exemplo, por que razão uma substância é necessária num determinado país, quais as medidas colocadas em prática para garantir a segurança, quais os fluxos comerciais que seriam afetados num determinado país de acolhimento, etc); e, que se devem considerar os sistemas de homologação e registo de outros países, que são igualmente robustos, como o americano e canadiano. Lembramos que a gestão de produtos desempenha um papel fundamental no apoio à transição sustentável da Europa.
organization: APOSOLO - Associação Portuguesa de Mobilização de Conservação do Solo
englishfeedback: Instead of banning the manufacture and trade of these substances, the EU should work on sharing its well-established best practices on safety, chemical risk assessment and transparency. Looking at all the evidence, banning the export of chemicals not approved for sale in Europe would be detrimental to third countries, the environment and the European economy. As the EU is the world leader in regulating chemicals, we believe that close collaboration between industry (such as the CropLife network around the world) and authorities at international level will be more successful in improving the safety of use and transparency of substances exported and applied in third countries. In view of the objective pursued by the EC, APOSOLO considers that strengthening the PIC Regulation (Reg. (EU) No 649/2012) will be the most effective way to achieve it. The EU should work together with industry to support third countries and organisations such as the OECD and FAO to establish best practices for transparency and traceability of information, leading by example and transferring high European safety standards. The EU will be able to ensure a transparent and clear system for the global chemical supply chain and improve the safe use of hazardous chemicals by all stakeholders by strengthening the implementation of the PIC. Note that some substances are registered and used in third countries for reasons other than crop protection, such as vector control; and that the products considered are exported to meet specific needs and of farmers outside the EU with different needs – agronomic and soil and climate conditions vary between regions. In tropical and subtropical climates, for example, pest and disease pressure tends to be higher due to the combination of heat and moisture, resulting in different weeds, pests and diseases. This is also highlighted in Europe when considering different areas for risk assessment under Reg. 1107/2009. We note that banning exports of chemicals from the EU would further increase the risk of using illegal and counterfeit pesticides, and undermine EU competitiveness, jobs and investment in innovation in the sector. As a result, production is likely to shift to other regions such as China and India. Another difficulty is to understand what may be implicit, as there is no definition of the meaning of ‘prohibited substances’. In the EU, there are numerous substances that are not authorised for a particular use (e.g. use of pesticides) but are fully valid under another EU regime (e.g. veterinary medicine). Another impact is the availability of and access to PPPs for seed treatments, which should be exported to third countries. Under the European Green Deal, there will certainly be an increase in the number of non-approved substances/uses. We believe that any impact assessment should aim to be as forward-looking as possible by addressing future needs. We recommend the EC to carry out an extended impact assessment before submitting any proposal. To take into account elements such as: information from outside the EU (e.g. why a substance is needed in a given country, what measures have been put in place to ensure security, what trade flows would be affected in a given host country, etc.); and that the type-approval and registration systems of other countries, which are equally robust, such as the American and Canadian, should be considered. We recall that product management plays a key role in supporting Europe’s sustainable transition.

feedback: Interdire des produits considérés comme toxiques pour notre santé et notre environnement au sein de l'UE est totalement louable et nous ne pouvons que nous en réjouir. Mais encore en autoriser la production pour l'exportation hors UE: - c'est faire passer une nouvelle fois les questions d'éthique, de santé de l'humanité et de la biosphère après les profits financiers - c'est ignorer l'impact de ces substances en retour lors de nos importations au sein de l'UE - c'est minimiser le coût économique que représente l'utilisation de telles substances sur les systèmes de santé et les problèmes environnementaux qui en découlent en E et hors E et ce probablement sur plusieurs générations et décennies - c'est une faille dans notre système de prévention et dans l'application du principe de précaution
englishfeedback: Banning products that are considered toxic to our health and environment in the EU is entirely commendable and we can only welcome them. But still allow it to be produced for export outside the EU: it is a loophole in our prevention system and in the application of the precautionary principle to bring the issues of ethics, human health and biosphere once again after financial gains – ignoring the impact of these substances back on our imports into the EU – minimising the economic cost of using such substances on health systems and the resulting environmental problems in E and non-E, probably over several generations and decades.

feedback: Most rural farmers using agrochemicals in most developing countries (including Nigeria) don't even know much about hazardous chemicals that are under ban in EU countries so as to avoid buying them from the market. So, the most sure way to prevent the use of these hazardous chemicals is to ban their exportation from the countries of origin.

El Ecuador, es un país exportador de banano, inclusive a la Unión Europea, en el que se usa el fungicida Mancozeb para el control de la enfermedad de la sigatoka negra. De acuerdo a un cálculo realizado para este informe, basados en datos de fitosanitarios que trabajan para empresas de aero fumigación y con el apoyo de ASTAC, en 2017 se arrojaron 14.225 toneladas de Mancozeb en los plantaciones banano sin considerar los ingredientes inertes, aceites agrícolas, cada uno con su propia toxicidad. A través del Reglamento de Ejecución (UE) 2020/2087 de la Comisión Europea, del 14 de diciembre de 2020 establece que no se renueva la aprobación de la sustancia activa mancoceb con arreglo a lo dispuesto en el Reglamento (CE) No. 1107/2009 del Parlamento Europeo y del Consejo, relativo a la comercialización de productos fitosanitarios, y por el que se modifica el anexo del Reglamento de Ejecución (UE) No. 540/2011 de la Comisión. El Ecuador y Colombia envían una notificación a la Organización Mundial de Comercio, a través de la cual presentaron sus comentarios y preocupaciones por la medida notificada por la Unión Europea mediante la no renovación de la aprobación de uso de la sustancia activa Mancozeb. A pesar de su prohibición en la UE, empresas de este bloque comercial importa banano que ha sido fumigado con Mancozeb. Algunas empresas de países europeos importan banano certificado por organizaciones como Rainforest Alliance, que otorga un sello que significa que el producto o ingrediente certificado se elaboró utilizando métodos que respaldan los tres pilares de la sostenibilidad: social, económica y ambiental. Bajo la Política sobre uso Excepcional de Rainforest Alliance, Excepciones otorgadas y sus condiciones para emplear plaguicidas prohibidos por Rainforest Alliance. Rainforest Alliance certifica fincas que aplican Mancozeb para el control de la enfermedad de la sigatoka negra, porque concede excepción de uso en bananos del Mancozeb en Camerún, Colombia, Costa Rica, Ecuador, Guatemala, Honduras, Costa de Marfil y Filipinas hasta el 30 de junio 2024, con la condición de que se implementen en su totalidad los requisitos de manejo de riesgos de la sección 3.6.1. Requisitos para el manejo de los riesgos de sustancias con toxicidad aguda y crónica, que incluye disposiciones que no se cumplen necesariamente, como que las mujeres menores de 50 años no aplican estos plaguicidas y no están presentes o cerca de las áreas de aplicación. Testimonios de mujeres trabajadoras muestran lo contrario, al igual que las condiciones laborales a las que están expuestas. Ver por ejemplo, https://library.fes.de/pdf-files/bueros/quito/19562-20220927.pdf https://www.naturalezaconderechos.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/BANANO-Y-AGROTOXICOS1.pdf Rainforest seguirá certificando fincas, 18 meses después de la entrada en vigencia de la prohibición europea, y si se toma en cuenta que la prohibición de uso del Mancozeb, estableció, como medida transitoria, que el 4 de julio 2021 era la fecha límite para retirar las autorizaciones de los productos que contengan Mancozeb, estamos hablando de 42 meses. Es preocupante los resultados del estudio de la organización ambientalista GLOBAL 2000 de Austria, produjo un estudio sobre la presencia de plaguicidas prohibidos en la UE, en alimentos importados de países que no conforman parte de la UE, donde estos plaguicidas no están prohibidos. https://rewe-group.at/en/newsroom/2023/03/rewe-group-and-global-2000-working-together-to-reduce-pesticides-for-over-20-years Para alcanzar un desarrollo justo y sustentable en el mundo rural, no sólo en el ámbito europeo, sino y también en los países productores de alimentos, se debe incluir las prohibiciones y restricciones de plaguicidas, a los alimentos importados por la UE, y de esa manera proteger las condiciones laborales de quienes producen esos alimentos, y la sustentabilidad ambiental de los países productores.
englishfeedback: Ecuador is a banana exporting country, including to the European Union, in which the fungicide Mancozeb is used to control black sigatoka disease. According to a calculation made for this report, based on data on plant protection products working for fumigation aero companies and with the support of ASTAC, 14.225 tonnes of Mancozeb were produced in banana plantations in 2017 without considering the inert ingredients, agricultural oils, each with its own toxicity. By European Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2020/2087 of 14 December 2020, the approval of the active substance mancozeb is not renewed, in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council concerning the placing of plant protection products on the market, and amending the Annex to Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) No 540/2011. Ecuador and Colombia send a notification to the World Trade Organisation, through which they submitted their comments and concerns about the measure notified by the European Union by not renewing the approval of the use of the active substance Mancozeb. Despite its ban in the EU, companies from this trading bloc import bananas that have been fumigated with Mancozeb. Some companies in European countries import bananas certified by organisations such as Rainforest Alliance, which gives a stamp that means that the certified product or ingredient was produced using methods that support the three pillars of sustainability: social, economic and environmental. Under the Rainforest Alliance’s Exceptional Use Policy, derogations granted and their conditions for using pesticides banned by Rainforest Alliance. Rainforest Alliance certifies farms applying Mancozeb for the control of black sigatoka disease, because it grants a derogation for use in bananas of Mancozeb in Cameroon, Colombia, Costa Rica, Ecuador, Guatemala, Honduras, Côte d’Ivoire and the Philippines until 30 June 2024, provided that the risk management requirements of Section 3.6.1 are fully implemented. Requirements for the management of the risks of substances with acute and chronic toxicity, including provisions that are not necessarily met, such as women under 50 years of age not applying these pesticides and not present or close to the areas of application. Testimonies from working women show the opposite, as do the working conditions to which they are exposed. See for example https://library.fes.de/pdf-files/bueros/quito/19562-20220927.pdf https://www.naturalezaconderechos.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/BANANO-Y-AGROTOXICOS1.pdf Rainforest will continue to certify properties, 18 months after the entry into force of the European ban, and if one takes into account that the ban on the use of Mancozeb established, as a transitional measure, that 4 July 2021 was the deadline for withdrawing authorisations for products containing Mancozeb, we are talking about 42 months. Worryingly, the results of the study by the Austrian environmental organisation GLOBAL 2000 produced a study on the presence of pesticides banned in the EU in foods imported from non-EU countries, where these pesticides are not banned. https://rewe-group.at/en/newsroom/2023/03/rewe-group-and-global-2000-working-together-to-reduce-pesticides-for-over-20-years To achieve fair and sustainable development in rural areas, not only at European level but also in food-producing countries, bans and restrictions on pesticides on food imported by the EU should be included, thus protecting the working conditions of those producing these foods and the environmental sustainability of producing countries.

feedback: Please see the attached document for comments from the American Chemistry Council. Thank you.

feedback: L'exportation de pesticides toxiques est une question de droits humains , car ces pesticides sont nocifs pour notre santé : Chaque année, des milliers d'agriculteurs meurent des suites dune trop forte exposition à ces pesticides dangereux. Les pesticides exportés font l'objet d'innombrables études qui confirment leurs effets néfastes sur les humains. De plus, leur exportation est néfaste pour les abeilles, la biodiversité et la planète en général. Les preuves sont claires : les néonics et autres pesticides dangereux tuent les abeilles. C'est pourquoi ils sont interdits en Europe. Pourquoi autorisons-nous encore leur exportation vers des pays où la réglementation est moins stricte, alors quils continueront de tuer les abeilles et décimer la biodiversité ? Cette exportation profite des pays où la réglementation est moins stricte. L'UE a un rôle à jouer dans le monde : ses entreprises ne devraient pas être autorisées à profiter des pays où la réglementation est plus faible. Comment pouvons-nous être pris au sérieux si nous expédions nos produits chimiques dangereux à l'étranger, empoisonnant ainsi les populations et la nature dans des pays où les règles de sécurité sont plus faibles et moins strictement appliquées ? Enfin, un avis juridique du Center for International Environmental Law publié en 2022 montre que les exportations européennes de pesticides interdits vers l'Afrique et l'Amérique centrale violent les obligations juridiques internationales de l'UE et le droit relatif aux droits humains !
englishfeedback: The export of toxic pesticides is a human rights issue, as these pesticides are harmful to our health: Every year, thousands of farmers die as a result of excessive exposure to these hazardous pesticides. Exported pesticides are subject to countless studies confirming their adverse effects on humans. Moreover, their export is harmful to bees, biodiversity and the planet in general. The evidence is clear: neonics and other hazardous pesticides kill bees. This is why they are banned in Europe. Why do we still allow their export to countries with less stringent regulation, while they will continue to kill bees and decay biodiversity? This export benefits countries with less stringent regulation. The EU has a role to play in the world: its businesses should not be allowed to benefit from countries with weaker regulation. How can we be taken seriously if we send our hazardous chemicals abroad, poisoning people and nature in countries where safety rules are weaker and less strictly enforced? Finally, a legal opinion of the Center for International Environmental Law published in 2022 shows that European exports of banned pesticides to Africa and Central America violate the EU’s international legal obligations and human rights law!

feedback: Geachte heren, Simpel, hetgeen waartegen we ons willen beschermen als vernietigend en ongezond moet voor alle mensen gelden. Met vriendelijke groeten.
englishfeedback: Dear Mr Simpel, what we want to protect us as devastating and unhealthy for all people. I would like to thank you very much.

feedback: Les ruego procedan a prohibir de inmediato la producción para la exportación de sustancias químicas prohibidas en la EU. Como muy bien saben son nocivas para cualquier ser humano, por tanto tampoco deberían permitir intoxicar a las poblaciones de otros continente. Actuen ya! Muchas gracias.
englishfeedback: I would ask you to immediately ban the production for export of chemicals banned in the EU. As they know they are harmful to any human being, they should therefore not allow poisoning of populations on other continents either. Do now! Thank you very much.

feedback: We shall not export dangerous pesticides that are banned in Europe to other countries. They are banned for a reason, they are linked cancer and other serious diseases as well as doing harm for our nature and the bees. If these pesticides are too dangerous for us, how can we allow them to be exported? Shall we allow companies to earn more money through exporting life threatening pesticides to other countries which have less hard regulations. Let us take our responsibility in the EU and not make harm to other human beings and countries

Slovenia welcomes this initiative of European Commission which is an important step to increase the protection of human health and the environment also globally. It is important to stress that population in many countries like South Africa, South American countries and others is more vulnerable due to more reasons. And anyone who is vulnerable can be much easier abused. And we need to have a mechanism which prevents abuses. At our opinion an impact assessment needs to examine a few different options including an option business as usual and assess their benefits and costs. Adding new substances on potential list of banned substances for export should not be necessary automatic, but to be dealt on case by case basis.
organization: Chemicals Office of the Republic of Slovenia

feedback: COSMED warns on the disproportionate consequences that such intention could have in harming EU industries global competitiveness and more specifically SMEs in the event the manufacture and export of cosmetic substances and products would be prohibited without proper risk assessment while authorized outside EU. In contrast, COSMED will support any initiative at EU level aimed at stimulating cosmetic market to develop safe, sustainable and efficient alternatives, to strengthen the credibility and values of EU cosmetic industry while avoiding export ban that would be damaging to the social economy, the environment and even the safety of workers. Please find our full contribution in attachment.

feedback: The Chemicals Strategy for Sustainability was adopted on 14 October 2020, prohibiting the production for export of hazardous chemicals banned in the EU. Furthermore, in October 2020, the EC committed to lead by example, and, in line with international commitments, ensure that hazardous chemicals banned in the European Union are not produced for export. On 8 May 2023, the EC opened a public consultation on prohibiting production for export of chemicals banned in the European Union. As a general note, the Fair Trade Advocacy Office (FTAO) welcomes the Commissions initiative, as an European export ban of hazardous chemicals already banned in the EU would be a significant and meaningful step toward addressing the worldwide problem of hazardous pesticide usage. However, an EU export ban alone will still leave space for actors in countries outside the EU to produce and/or access hazardous chemicals in different ways which in turn means that pesticides banned in the EU would find their way back to EU consumers. To address these concerns, the FTAO emphasizes the need for EU supportive measures for Fair Trade farmers, which would enable a shift towards agroecological practices. Which in turn would shield them from the negative repercussions of the EU hazardous chemicals export ban, by altogether reducing the use of these substances. In this sense, the European Union has programs, other financial and non-financial instruments and a framework of policies to assist smallholder farmers in transitioning to safer pest control methods and converting to sustainable agriculture practices. As a major global actor, the European Union has the economic and political clout to strive toward a global transition to phase out harmful pesticides and their use worldwide. The FTAO would like to submit its research on support measures for reducing use of pesticides and transition towards agroecological practices.

Thor unterstützt die Ziele der Chemikalienstrategie für Nachhaltigkeit und das Ziel der Europäischen Kommission, die Sicherheit von Menschen und Umwelt auf der ganzen Welt zu verbessern. Dennoch erscheint Thor der derzeit gewählte Ansatz als zu allgemein. Es werden bestimmte Produkte exportiert, um spezifische Bedürfnisse in Nicht-EU-Ländern zu erfüllen: Ein Verbot ihrer Produktion und Ausfuhr würde wahrscheinlich zum einen zu einem Umsatz- und Arbeitsplatzverlust für europäische Unternehmen führen, da ein solches Verbot nicht für Unternehmen aus Nicht-EU-Ländern gelten würde, wodurch für diese ein Wettbewerbsvorteil entsteht. Für manche Stoffe, die von einem Exportverbot betroffen wären, besteht trotzdem ein Bedarf in Nicht-EU-Ländern, der gegebenenfalls durch eine Produktion vor Ort gedeckt werden müsste, wenn ein Import aus der EU nicht mehr möglich wäre. Dies sehen wir kritisch, da in manchen dieser Länder die Sicherheitsvorschriften geringer sind und weniger streng durchgesetzt werden. Dadurch könnte es bei der Herstellung der Stoffe in diesen Ländern zu einer möglichen Gefährdung von Menschen und der Umwelt kommen. Dies würde dann letztlich keine Verbesserung der Situation vor Ort darstellen, denn aktuell findet die Herstellung in der EU unter den weltweit höchsten Standards hinsichtlich Arbeitssicherheit, Arbeitsschutz und Umweltschutz statt. Daher schlägt Thor vor, dass diese bewährten Best Practices in den Bereichen Sicherheit, Risikobewertung chemischer Produkte, Transparenz und Rückverfolgbarkeit exportiert werden sollten, um den Umgang mit Chemikalien auf der ganzen Welt sicherer zu gestalten.
englishfeedback: THOR supports the objectives of the Chemicals Strategy for Sustainability and the European Commission’s objective to improve the safety of people and the environment around the world. Nevertheless, Thor appears to be too general in the current approach. Certain products are exported to meet specific needs in non-EU countries: On the one hand, a ban on their production and exports would likely lead to a loss of turnover and jobs for European companies, as such a ban would not apply to companies from non-EU countries, giving them a competitive advantage. For some substances that would be subject to an export ban, there is still a need in non-EU countries, which might have to be covered by local production if imports from the EU were no longer possible. We are critical of this, as in some of these countries safety rules are lower and enforcement is less stringent. This could potentially endanger humans and the environment during the manufacture of the substances in these countries. This would ultimately not be an improvement in the situation on the ground, as production in the EU is currently among the highest standards in the world in terms of occupational safety, health and safety and environmental protection. Thor therefore proposes that these best practices in the areas of safety, risk assessment of chemical products, transparency and traceability should be exported in order to make the management of chemicals more secure around the world.

Exported pesticides are subject to countless studies confirming their adverse effects on humans.

feedback: Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, es sollte selbstverständlich sein, dass Pestizide, die in Europa aus gutem Grund verboten sind, nicht in andere Teile der Welt exportiert werden. Ich bitte Sie also, ein Exportverbot zu erlassen.
englishfeedback: Ladies and Gentlemen, it should be self-evident that pesticides that are banned for good reason in Europe are not exported to other parts of the world. I would therefore ask you to impose an export ban.

feedback: Bonjour, Voici quelques raisons pour lesquelles nous avons besoin dinterdire les pesticides dangereux : - L'exportation de pesticides toxiques révèle une politique de deux poids deux mesures : Les pesticides dangereux sont interdits en Europe après avoir été associés à des cancers, des problèmes de reproduction et des maladies neurodégénératives, ainsi qu'à la mort des abeilles. Certains de ces pesticides sont même interdits en Europe en raison de leur lien avec des lésions cérébrales chez les enfants et les bébés à naître. Si ces pesticides sont trop dangereux pour nous, comment pouvons-nous autoriser leur exportation ? - L'exportation de pesticides toxiques est une question de droits humains , car ces pesticides sont nocifs pour notre santé : Chaque année, des milliers d'agriculteurs meurent des suites dune trop forte exposition à ces pesticides dangereux. Les pesticides exportés font l'objet d'innombrables études qui confirment leurs effets néfastes sur les humains. - L'exportation de pesticides toxiques est néfaste pour les abeilles, la biodiversité et la planète en général. Les preuves sont claires : les néonics et autres pesticides dangereux tuent les abeilles. C'est pourquoi ils sont interdits en Europe. Pourquoi autorisons-nous encore leur exportation vers des pays où la réglementation est moins stricte, alors quils continueront de tuer les abeilles et décimer la biodiversité ? En espérant avoir retenu votre attention, Bien cordialement Un citoyen inquiet
englishfeedback: Hello, A few reasons why we need to ban hazardous pesticides: — The export of toxic pesticides reveals a double standard policy: Hazardous pesticides are banned in Europe after being associated with cancer, reproductive problems and neurodegenerative diseases, as well as bee death. Some of these pesticides are even banned in Europe because of their link to brain damage in children and born babies. If these pesticides are too dangerous for us, how can we authorise their export? — The export of toxic pesticides is a human rights issue, as these pesticides are harmful to our health: Every year, thousands of farmers die as a result of excessive exposure to these hazardous pesticides. Exported pesticides are subject to countless studies confirming their adverse effects on humans. — The export of toxic pesticides is harmful to bees, biodiversity and the planet in general. The evidence is clear: neonics and other hazardous pesticides kill bees. This is why they are banned in Europe. Why do we still allow their export to countries with less stringent regulation, while they will continue to kill bees and decay biodiversity? Hoping to have received your attention, well a worried citizen

feedback: En tant que citoyen européen, je trouve vraiment inacceptable que nous produisions et exportons des produits chimiques dont il est clair qu'ils sont toxiques pour les hommes et l'environnement. Ne recommençons pas l'erreur irréversible du Chlordécone en Martinique chez les autres ! On ne pourra pas dire qu'on ne savait pas....
englishfeedback: As a European citizen, I find it very unacceptable that we produce and export chemicals that are clearly toxic to humans and the environment. Let’s not repeat the irreversible error of Chlordecone in Martinique among others! It cannot be said that you did not know....

feedback: Pestizide, die in Europa mit Recht untersagt sind, dürfen selbstverständlich auch in Länder, die Pestizide von europäischen Firmen ordern, nicht geliefert werden. Mit den importierten Lebensmitteln u.a. bekommen wir sonst die untersagten und gefährlichen Pestizide zurück. Das kann ja wohl nicht der Sinn eines Pestizidverbotes sein,dass man gefährliche Pestizide hinterrücks wieder in Europa zurück bekommt ! Ein Irrwitz und absolut unlogisch! Lassen Sie sich nicht von der Chemielobby "über den Tisch ziehen"! Es gibt überhaupt keinen Grund (auch keinen finanziellen oder unternehmerischen) die Gesundheit der europäischen oder andersländischer Bevölkerung zu gefährden oder bewusst zu untergraben.Mit unserem christlichen Ideen-Hintergrund hat Europa eine ethische und moralische Verantwortung! Ein Pestizidverbot in der Europäischen Union ist gewissenhaft geprüft und hat seine Berechtigung.
englishfeedback: It goes without saying that pesticides that are rightly banned in Europe should not be supplied to countries that order pesticides from European companies. With the imported food, we will otherwise get back the banned and dangerous pesticides. This does not seem to be the sense of a pesticide ban, so that hazardous pesticides are returned back in Europe! An irrwice and absolutely illogical! Don’t let the chemical lobby “move the table”! There is no reason at all to endanger or deliberately undermine the health of the European or other population (even financial or entrepreneurial). With our Christian background to ideas, Europe has ethical and moral responsibility! A ban on pesticides in the European Union has been carefully assessed and justified.

feedback: Dear European Commission Decision Makers, The destruction of nature has reached proportions that threaten the existence of human beings among other species. It is against any reason and caution that more toxic chemicals be produced and dispersed in the environment - anywhere on Earth. Please use your mandate to prohibit production for export of chemicals banned in the European Union. Yours respectfully, Kristiina Mod

Sehe geehrte Damen und Herren, Ich bin sehr für ein Ausfuhrverbot von in der EU verbotenen Pestiziden. Was soll ein Verbot im "kleinen" Europa diese Pestizide zu verbieten um sie dann in Afrika, Asien usw. zu verwenden. Nicht nur, dass wir sie über eingeführte Lebensmittel wieder bekommen, auch zeigt es wie egal es den Industrienationen ist,wenn hier schlecht ausgerüstete Arbeiter mit den Pestizieden in Berührung kommen und erkranken oder sterben.
englishfeedback: Ladies and gentlemen, I am very much in favour of banning the export of pesticides banned in the EU. What is a ban in “small” Europe to ban these pesticides in Africa, Asia, etc. Not only do we get them back through imported food, but it also shows how the developed nations are when poorly equipped workers come into contact with the pesticides and get ill or die.

feedback: We support the initiative to ban the export of hazardous pesticides produced in Europe to the rest of the world. Chemicals know no national boundaries. These chemicals have been regulated within EU for a reason, being linked to endocrine and reproductive disturbances, cancer, neurodevelopmental diseases in humans and animals, linked to effects on biodiversity such as bee colony collapse disorder. It is respectless to not take into consideration the damage these chemicals have on the population of the importing countries, and it is also naive to disregard that the chemicals will also affect human and environmental health within the borders of EU. By banning the export of hazardous pesticides would also stimulate innovation and help Europe and the world move towards more sustainable plant protection methods. Keeping old and dangerous pesticides on the market is depriving us from a greener future and more sustainable farming practices.

We support the initiative to ban the export of hazardous pesticides produced in Europe to the rest of the world. Chemicals know no national boundaries. These chemicals have been regulated within EU for a reason, being linked to endocrine and reproductive disturbances, cancer, neurodevelopmental diseases in humans and animals, linked to effects on biodiversity such as bee colony collapse disorder. It is respectless to not take into consideration the damage these chemicals have on the population of the importing countries, and it is also naive to disregard that the chemicals will also affect human and environmental health within the borders of EU. By banning the export of hazardous pesticides would also stimulate innovation and help Europe and the world move towards more sustainable plant protection methods. Keeping old and dangerous pesticides on the market is depriving us from a greener future and more sustainable farming practices.
organization: The Swedish Society for Nature Conservation - Roslagen unit

feedback: L'agriculture existe depuis presque 10000 ans et pendant 9900 ans elle n'a utilisé aucun intrant chimique. Depuis à peine plus que 100 ans, la chimie est entrée dans l'agriculture : certes, elle a permis d'augmenter la production à l'hectare, mais le prix à payer est extrêmement lourd, pollution des sols et des nappes phréatiques, destruction de la biodiversité (insectes, insectivores...), des sols vivants et de l'environnement en général. Au niveau éthique, il est inacceptable que l'Europe permette la production et l'exportation de produits chimiques qui sont interdits en Europe en raison de leur dangerosité scientifiquement avérée, et cela au nom du libéralisme économique et de l'enrichissement de quelques entreprises sans aucun engagement sociétal. Une telle situation jette un doute évident sur les engagements politiques de l'Union européenne en matière d'environnement.
englishfeedback: Agriculture has existed for almost 10000 years and for 9900 years it has not used any chemical input. For just over 100 years, chemistry has entered agriculture: although it has helped to increase production per hectare, the price to be paid is extremely high, pollution of soil and groundwater, destruction of biodiversity (insects, insectivores, etc.), living soils and the environment in general. On an ethical level, it is unacceptable for Europe to allow the production and export of chemicals that are banned in Europe because of their scientifically proven danger, in the name of economic liberalism and the enrichment of a few companies without any societal commitment. Such a situation casts a clear doubt on the European Union’s political commitments on the environment.

feedback: The promise made in 2020 by the European Commission to end the shameful European double standard of exporting massive amounts of dangerous pesticides that are banned in Europe (after they were linked to cancer, reproductive problems and neuro-degenerative diseases as well as the dying of insects, etc) to the global South is in fact a no-brainer. Finally proposing a legislative proposal to outlaw these exports is the bare minimum the EU could do to show if it really upholds values on human rights and the UN Sustainable Development Goals. Also the export ban would be the litmus test for all the international trade agreements the EU wants to sign with non-EU countries, while always claiming that these agreements are to promote sustainability. If the EU is so concerned about sustainability in other regions, then stop exporting pesticides banned in Europe because of their links to brain damage in children and unborn babies. If these pesticides are too dangerous for Europeans, they are too dangerous for al humans. A legal opinion by the Center for International Environmental Law published in 2022 shows that EU exports of banned pesticides to Africa and Central America violate the EUs international legal obligations and human rights law. United Nations experts like Marcos Orellana, UN rapporteur on human rights and toxic substances, have considered HHPs (Highly Hazardous Pesticides) a global human rights concern for a long time: Pesticides threaten among others the right to live in dignity, the right to bodily integrity, and the right to a healthy environment. Several studies show that pesticide poisonings have been rising sharply for years today about 385 million cases of acute poisonings occur each year. The total number of fatalities around the world from unintended pesticide poisonings are estimated at some 11,000 per year. According to the Pesticide Atlas 2022 (Heinrich Boll Foundation and FOE) In 2018 and 2019, the EU and the UK approved the export of 140,908 tonnes of pesticides that are banned from being used in the EU because of unacceptable health and environmental risks. "In industrialized countries, the five largest producers sell less highly dangerous pesticides overall than in Asia, Africa and Latin America: While they account for 12 percent of total pesticide sales in Germany and 11 percent in France, they account in Brazil for 49 percent and in India for 59 percent." Indeed a handful of global agrochemical corporations (Syngenta Group, Bayer, Corteva, BASF and FMC) controlled around 70 percent of the global pesticide market in 2018. The export value of the European pesticides exports are around 15 billion euro of which 30% are HHPs. These companies basically keep selling old, non-patented molecules, in countries that have a weaker regulation. Especially in South America, Asia, and Africa, pesticide sales are on the rise. The continuous growth of the global pesticide market by an average of 4% annually is mainly due to sales in these regions. This while the EU debates the need to reduce pesticide use with 50%... Europe has a role to play in the world - its companies should not be allowed to take advantage of people in countries with weaker regulation. Farmers and farm workers often do not receive training nor protective gear to protect themselves. Personal protective equipment is often difficult to obtain, too expensive, or it is impossible to wear due to high temperatures. UN rapporteur Orellana said that the countries applying to the EU for HHP-exports "are often corrupt and burdened by weak political governance." It is traders and big agro-industrial players who invest in monocultures like soybeans (in for example Latin-America) who want these HHPs, not the people. An export ban of toxic pesticides would be a boon for innovation and help Europe move towards more sustainable plant protection methods. Keeping dangerous pesticides on the market deprives us from moving to more sustainable farming practices

Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren der Europäischen Kommission, ich wünsche mir von Ihnen in Konsequenz für die gesamte EU und weltweit, das die Ein- und Ausfuhr sowie Herstellung gesundheitlich bedenklicher und gefährlicher Chemikalien verboten ist und bleibt und dementsprechend auch weltweit durchgesetzt wird, insbesondere geltend für Pestiziete und keine Zulassung mehr für das Unkrautvernichtungsmittel Glyphosat sowie ähnliche Produkte. Die negativen Auswirkungen dieser chemischen Mittel auf die Natur und den Menschen sind umfassend untersucht und bekannt. Mit freundlichem Gruß Christof Korth
englishfeedback: Ladies and gentlemen of the European Commission, I wish you logically to ask you for the whole EU and worldwide, which is and continues to be banned from importing, exporting and producing chemicals of concern to health and hazardous chemicals, and is accordingly enforced worldwide, in particular for pesticides and no longer for herbicide glyphosate and similar products. The negative effects of these chemicals on nature and human beings are widely studied and known. Yours sincerely, Christof Korth

feedback: Ne pas faire ailleurs ce que nous ne voulons pas chez nous : les exportateurs de pesticides toxiques profite des pays où la réglementation est moins stricte. L'UE a un rôle à jouer dans le monde - ses entreprises ne devraient pas être autorisées à profiter des pays où la réglementation est plus faible. Comment pouvons-nous être pris au sérieux si nous expédions nos produits chimiques dangereux à l'étranger, empoisonnant ainsi les populations et la nature dans des pays où les règles de sécurité sont plus faibles et moins strictement appliquées ?
englishfeedback: Do not do elsewhere what we do not want at home: exporters of toxic pesticides benefit from countries with less stringent regulation. The EU has a role to play in the world – its businesses should not be allowed to benefit from countries with weaker regulation. How can we be taken seriously if we send our hazardous chemicals abroad, poisoning people and nature in countries where safety rules are weaker and less strictly enforced?

feedback: Please find COLEAD's response to this initiative in attachment.

feedback: Wir müssen endlich aufhören, die Welt weiter zu vergiften - nur aus Profit-Interesse. Sind unsere Kinder uns nichts mehr wert?
englishfeedback: We must finally stop further poisoning the world – only for profit. Are our children no longer worth us?

feedback: Kann mich dem formulierten Verbot voll und ganz anschließen. Niemand sollte mit gefährlichen, in der EU verbotenen Substanzen, Geld über Exporte verdienen.
englishfeedback: Can I fully agree with the prohibition formulated. No one should earn money through exports from dangerous substances banned in the EU.

feedback: Chemikalien, die so gefährlich sind, dass sie in der EU verboten sind, müssen letztendlich mit einem Produktionsverbot belegt werden. Ein Verbot der Ausfuhr ist das mindeste, was im Sinne der EU-Ethik gemacht werden muss.
englishfeedback: Chemicals that are so dangerous that they are banned in the EU must ultimately be banned from production. A ban on exports is at least what needs to be done in the spirit of EU ethics.

feedback: Die Produkion und Ausfuhr von in der EU verbotenen gefährlichen Chemikalien muss verboten werden, denn sie sind auch schädlich für Mensch und Natur ausserhalb der EU.
englishfeedback: The production and export of hazardous chemicals banned in the EU must be banned, as they are also harmful to humans and nature outside the EU.

feedback: The Pesticide Action Network Europe fully supports the European Commission's intention to urgently present strong legislative measures aimed at prohibiting the production and export of chemicals that have been banned in the European Union due to their hazardous properties. This aligns perfectly with the Commissions commitment under the European Green Deal and the Chemical Strategy for Sustainability, to demonstrate Europe's leadership in safeguarding our health and the environment against hazardous chemicals and promotion of sustainable practices.. It is deeply alarming that while the EU bans the use of hazardous chemicals within its own territory, it allows their export to countries with weaker safety laws. Instead of promoting alternative, safer practices, in line with the principles of agroecology, Europe is promoting the use of toxic pesticides in full knowledge about the damage that these can cause. Evidently, companies find alternative routes to profit from their toxic products by exporting them to regions with weaker health and environmental regulations and often rich in biodiversity. This practice is extremely worrying, since the use of these hazardous chemicals in these countries leads to serious health harm in adults and children, contaminates water, and causes the collapse of bee colonies and loss of biodiversity. To effectively protect human health and the environment, strict measures need to be set at the EU level to address this issue at its source. Hence in our transition towards a toxic-free environment globally, the Commission must urgently bring forward legally binding measures that prevent EU companies from producing and exporting banned hazardous chemicals. In this pursuit of higher protection, the EU should amend the PIC Regulation to prohibit the export of banned chemicals, even when there is import consent from third countries. Simply providing toxicity information is insufficient to guarantee safety, as these chemicals have been banned in the EU precisely because there is absolutely no safe use for them. The PIC Regulation already maintains a list of banned or restricted chemicals and allows for annual updates. It also includes an Annex with a list of chemicals to which an export ban applies, which could be expanded to encompass all banned hazardous pesticides and chemicals. In conclusion, it is absolutely crucial for the Commission to demonstrate leadership in promoting a higher level of protection from hazardous chemicals worldwide and the use of safer, truly sustainable alternatives. What is harmful within the EU's borders is also harmful elsewhere. Turning a blind eye to the detrimental impacts of EU-produced chemicals on other countries and allowing companies to profit from toxic practices is morally unacceptable and should be made illegal. In times of environmental crisis and human rights violations, prioritizing people's health and safeguarding natural resources is of utmost importance. The time for action is now.
Bonjour, si ces produits sont dangereux pour nous ils le sont également pour tout être humain. C'est la raison pour laquelle ils doivent être interdits aussi bien à la production qu'à l'exportation.
englishfeedback: Hello, if these products are dangerous for us as well for every human being. For this reason, they must be prohibited from both production and export.

feedback: Le règlement PIC doit interdire à la fois la production dans lUE et l'exportation , sans possibilités de déroger à l'interdiction, de tous les pesticides et autres produits chimiques dangereux qui ont été interdits dans l'UE afin de protéger les êtres vivants et la planète. L'Europe doit être exemplaire !
englishfeedback: The PIC Regulation must prohibit both the production in the EU and the export of all pesticides and other hazardous chemicals that have been banned in the EU in order to protect living beings and the planet, without any possibility to derogate from the ban. Europe must be exemplary!

feedback: Pestizide, die hier verboten wurden, richten in der Welt großen Schaden an, wenn sie exportiert werden. Es braucht ein HERSTELLUNGSVERBOT! Wir haben nur EINE Welt!!!!
englishfeedback: Pesticides that have been banned here are causing major damage in the world when exported. A ban on manufacturing is needed! We only have ONE World!

feedback: The Centre for Pesticide Suicide Prevention at the University of Edinburgh supports the Commissions proposal. People living in poor, rural communities in low and middle-income countries (LMIC) are currently at risk due to the easy availability of acutely toxic highly hazardous pesticides (HHPs), many of which are imported from the EU. We are particularly concerned about suicide deaths from intentional pesticide poisoning, which has been responsible for an estimated 14 million deaths since the Green Revolution in the 1960s, and an additional 150,000 deaths and countless injuries each year. Research shows that many of these deaths could have been prevented by restricting access to lethal means of suicide. Evidence from countries that have implemented bans on HHPs, including Sri Lanka and Bangladesh, shows that lives can be saved with no adverse impact on agriculture. This approach is promoted by the World Health Organization and the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations. Most pesticides used in LMIC are imported, including from the EU. This includes pesticides banned for use within the EU. The position whereby EU citizens are protected from harm by regulation of harmful pesticides, but citizens of other, generally poorer countries, continue to be exposed to the same harmful chemicals is unacceptable. By definition, HHPs are hazardous and therefore not safe. A risk-based approach does not work in countries where regulatory systems are under-resourced and poorly enforced. Farm workers in these countries are often uneducated and poor. They cannot afford PPE, which can also be impractical in hot climates, and may be unable to read or understand instructions on pesticide bottles. Application equipment is often basic and poorly maintained and is rarely calibrated to ensure that correct doses of pesticides are applied. It is also common practice for farmers to mix cocktails of chemicals at high doses to ensure effectiveness. This not only increases the risk of poisonings, but also increases the levels of damage to biodiversity and the environment, and raises toxic pesticide residue levels in food beings sent to market. Large-scale research trials have also shown that lockable storage is also an ineffective solution for preventing pesticide suicide and occupational harms from pesticides. Our experience shows that bans of HHPs are effective in preventing deaths as, there is often low intent to die from pesticide self-poisoning; people do not re-attempt using pesticides of other means; and when implemented correctly, with alternatives available to farmers, there is no adverse impact of crop production. Removing these harmful pesticides from the market place is therefore a positive step towards saving lives, producing safer food and protecting the agricultural environment. Unfortunately, many LMIC lack resource to effectively regulate hazardous chemicals. Regulatory teams may comprise just one or two people. They also have immature surveillance systems, lacking capacity to collect data. Prohibiting exports of banned pesticides from the EU would help restrict access to lethal means of suicide in LMIC and would contribute to a reduction in the overall global suicide rate. There is a risk that production of banned pesticides will move from the EU, with its high regulatory standards, to factories established in LMIC with less rigorous standards. As a result, harms may be transferred from rich countries to poorer countries. It is therefore imperative that these decisions result in the banned pesticides not being manufactured at all and the export of ingredients for the formulation of these pesticides elsewhere is also prohibited. We recommend that EU member states support international action to end global use of HHPs, including support for listing HHPs in Annex III of the Rotterdam Convention and for a phase-out of HHPs as proposed by the Strategic Approach to International Chemical Management (SAICM) global framework.
organization: Centre for Pesticide Suicide Prevention, The University of Edinburgh
attachementDocumentIds: [{'documentId': '090166e5ff6b2c90', 'fileName': 'Policy Brief - Impact of EU pesticide trade on global suicide.pdf'}]

feedback: I support this initiative. Exporting hazardous chemicals banned in the EU is unethical and contradicts human rights principles. Globally, chemicals have a negative impact on the environment and people's health. The United Nations recognise the unsound management of chemicals and waste as a threat to human rights, particularly affecting vulnerable populations. Many countries outside EU lack proper chemical management systems, making them less equipped banned chemicals exported from EU. Stopping these exports would protect the environment, biodiversity and at-risk-populations, while promoting safer alternatives. Replacing hazardous pesticides with cost-effective options benefits health, environment and biodiversity without affecting crop yields..

feedback: Wie kann es erlaubt sein, Chemikalien in die Welt zu verkaufen, welche in Europa verboten sind? Das ist eine Doppelmoral. Länder, in denen es kaum Vorschriften für giftige Pestizide gibt, werden als Markt benutzt. Europäische Unternehmen sollten nicht die Möglichkeit haben, diesen Umstand auszunutzen. Sie sollten vielmehr dazu angeregt werden, umweltverträgliche Produkte herzustellen. Wie kann Europa als Weltmacht ernst genommen werden, wenn wir gefährliche Chemikalien ins Ausland verschiffen und dabei Mensch und Natur in Ländern vergiften, in denen Sicherheitsvorschriften geringer sind und weniger streng durchgesetzt werden? Zumal die giftiken Chemikalien über den Markt früher oder später auch wieder zu uns zurück gelangen. Ich wünsche mir eine Welt in der ich darauf Vertrauen kann, dass die Lebensmittel, welche auf unseren Tellern landen und auf den Tellern unserer Kinder gesund sind und keine schädlichen Substanzen enthalten. Eine Welt in der man mit Freude Lebensmittel aus der Natur genießen kann in dem Bewusstsein seinem Körper etwas gutes zu tun. Europa sollte die Interessen der Europäerinnen und Europäer vertreten, deren Gesundheit schützen, die Natur und Umwelt schützen - als Lebensgrundlage aller Lebewesen, Europa in der Welt mit diesen moralischen Werten vertreten und dementsprechend handeln. Die Ausfuhr von giftigen Pestiziden ist ebenso eine Frage der Menschenrechte, denn die Pestizide schaden den Menschen. Es gibt unzählige Studien, die die schädlichen Auswirkungen der exportierten Pestizide auf den Menschen, Natur und Umwelt belegen. Die Ausfuhr giftiger Pestizide ist desaströs für Bienen, die biologische Vielfalt und den Planeten. Die Beweislage ist eindeutig: Neonics und andere giftige Pestizide töten Bienen. Deshalb sind sie in Europa verboten. Wir sollten nicht zulassen, dass diese Pestizide in Länder exportiert werden, in denen Gesundheitsvorschriften weniger streng sind und dort Bienen und die biologische Vielfalt zerstören. Ein Exportverbot für giftige Pestizide würde Europa und der Welt helfen, zu nachhaltigeren Pflanzenschutzmethoden überzugehen. Wenn gefährliche Pestizide auf dem Markt bleiben, werden wir weiter auf eine grünere Zukunft und nachhaltige Landwirtschaft warten müssen.
englishfeedback: How can it be allowed to sell chemicals banned in Europe to the world? This is a double standard. Countries with little regulation on toxic pesticides are used as a market. European companies should not be able to take advantage of this fact. Rather, they should be encouraged to produce environmentally friendly products. How can Europe be taken seriously as a global power when we ship dangerous chemicals abroad, poisoning people and nature in countries where safety rules are lower and enforcement is less stringent? This is because toxic chemicals return to us sooner or later via the market. I want a world in which I can trust that the food that ends up on our plates and which is healthy on our children’s plate and does not contain harmful substances. A world in which pleasure is to enjoy food from nature can do something well in the consciousness of their body. Europe should represent the interests of Europeans, protect their health, protect nature and the environment – as the livelihoods of all living beings, defend Europe in the world with these moral values and act accordingly. The export of toxic pesticides is also a matter of human rights, as pesticides harm people. There are countless studies demonstrating the harmful effects of exported pesticides on humans, nature and the environment. Exports of toxic pesticides are desastrous for bees, biodiversity and the planet. The evidence is clear: Neonics and other toxic pesticides kill bees. This is why they are banned in Europe. We should not allow these pesticides to be exported to countries where health rules are less stringent and where bees and biodiversity are destroyed. A ban on exports of toxic pesticides would help Europe and the world move towards more sustainable plant protection practices. If hazardous pesticides remain on the market, we will have to wait for a greener future and sustainable agriculture.

feedback: Sehr geehrte Abgeordnete, bitte sorgen Sie dafür, dass in der EU verbotene Pestizide auch für den Export verboten werden. Mit eindringlichen Grüßen im Sinne von Naturerhaltung, Gesundheit und Arbeitsschutz: Matthias Teutsch aus Mainz
englishfeedback: Dear MEPs, please ensure that pesticides banned in the EU are also banned for export. With strong greetings in terms of nature conservation, health and safety at work: Matthias Teutsch from Mainz

feedback: L'exportation de pesticides toxiques correspond à une politique de deux poids deux mesures : Les pesticides dangereux sont interdits en Europe après avoir été associés à des cancers, des problèmes de reproduction et des maladies neurodégénératives, ainsi qu'à la mort des abeilles. Certains de ces pesticides sont même interdits en Europe en raison de leur lien avec des lésions cérébrales chez les enfants et les bébés à naître. Si ces pesticides sont trop dangereux pour nous, comment pouvons-nous autoriser leur exportation ? L'exportation de pesticides toxiques bafoue le respect de la santé humaine et de la santé de lenvironnement: Chaque année, des milliers d'agriculteurs meurent des suites dune trop forte exposition à ces pesticides dangereux. Les pesticides exportés font l'objet de très nombreuses études qui confirment leurs effets néfastes sur les humains. De la même façon, de très nombreuses évidences scientifiques démontrent les effets néfastes de ces produits sur lenvironnement (par exemple Rigal et al., PNAS 2023 e2216573120 ou encore les études démontrant les effets délétères des néonicotinoïdes sur les populations dabeilles et autres insectes pollinisateurs). C'est pourquoi ils sont interdits en Europe. Pourquoi autorisons-nous encore leur exportation vers des pays où la réglementation est moins stricte et où ils produiront de manière certaine des effets néfaste sur la santé des hommes et de lenvironnement L'exportation de pesticides toxiques profite de la réglementation moins stricte de certains pays. L'UE a un rôle à jouer dans le monde - ses entreprises ne devraient pas être autorisées à profiter de réglementations plus faibles. Comment pouvons-nous être pris au sérieux si nous exportons nos produits chimiques dangereux à l'étranger, empoisonnant ainsi les populations et la nature dans des pays où les règles de sécurité sont plus faibles et moins strictement appliquées ? Un avis juridique du Center for International Environmental Law publié en 2022 montre que les exportations européennes de pesticides interdits vers l'Afrique et l'Amérique centrale violent les obligations juridiques internationales de l'UE et le droit relatif aux droits humains L'interdiction d'exporter des pesticides toxiques serait une opportunité unique pour l'innovation et aiderait l'Europe et le monde à évoluer vers des méthodes de protection des plantes plus durables. Le maintien sur le marché de pesticides anciens et dangereux nous prive d'un avenir plus vert et de pratiques agricoles plus durables.
englishfeedback: The export of toxic pesticides corresponds to a policy of double standards: Hazardous pesticides are banned in Europe after being associated with cancer, reproductive problems and neurodegenerative diseases, as well as bee death. Some of these pesticides are even banned in Europe because of their link to brain damage in children and born babies. If these pesticides are too dangerous for us, how can we authorise their export? The export of toxic pesticides violates respect for human and environmental health: Every year, thousands of farmers die as a result of excessive exposure to these hazardous pesticides. Exported pesticides are the subject of numerous studies confirming their adverse effects on humans. Similarly, very numerous scientific evidence demonstrates the adverse effects of these products on the environment (e.g. Rigal et al., PNAS 2023 e2216573120 or studies demonstrating the adverse effects of neonicotinoids on bee populations and other pollinating insects). This is why they are banned in Europe. Why do we still allow them to be exported to countries where regulation is less stringent and where they will certainly have adverse effects on human health and the environment The export of toxic pesticides benefits from the less stringent regulation of some countries. The EU has a role to play in the world – its businesses should not be allowed to benefit from weaker regulations. How can we be taken seriously if we export our hazardous chemicals abroad, poisoning people and nature in countries where safety rules are weaker and less strictly enforced? A legal opinion of the Center for International Environmental Law published in 2022 shows that European exports of banned pesticides to Africa and Central America violate the EU’s international legal obligations and human rights law. The ban on the export of toxic pesticides would be a unique opportunity for innovation and would help Europe and the world to move towards more sustainable plant protection methods. Keeping old and dangerous pesticides on the market deprives us of a greener future and more sustainable agricultural practices.

feedback: Jegliche Produktion und Handel mit diesen Giften gehört verboten. Es gefährdet in hohem Maße unsere Lebensgrundlagen! Stop sofort!
englishfeedback: All production and trade in these poisons is prohibited. It is a major threat to our livelihoods! Stop immediately!

feedback: Out of the 230 active ingredients registered in Kenya, by the Pest Control Produce Board (PCPB), only 134 are approved in Europe, 19 are not listed in the European database and 77 have been withdrawn from the European market or are heavily restricted in their use due to potential chronic health effects, negative environmental impacts, and high toxicity towards fish or bees. A study conducted in Muranga and Kirinyaga counties in 2020, confirmed that 17 active ingredients out of the 77 withdrawn in Europe were used by farmers and tests showed high concentrations of Maximum Residue Levels, beyond what is allowed in the EU, in kale and tomatoes sold on the market. The survey revealed that most agrovet dealers and farmers were not aware of the toxicity and measures that need to be followed to use these pesticides. When farmers buy these pesticides, they do not read/adhere to precautions and directions of use as indicated on the labels. During application, farmers do not use appropriate protective gear, rarely follow the right dosage, and some do not use the pesticides for their intended purpose or intended crops or adhere to post harvest intervals. The regulatory framework for monitoring usage of Highly Hazardous Pesticides (HHPs) is weak and the relevant authorities do not have the required infrastructure and manpower to adequately monitor the use of HHPs. Although there are alternatives to toxic pesticides available on the market, not many farmers, extension officers, agrovet dealers or consumers know about them. This can be attributed to ignorance, push by profit-oriented agrochemical companies, and trainings and extension systems that encourage the use of agrochemicals as the only solution for pest control. Kenya is at a point where Non-Communicable Diseases (NCDs) are on the rise placing a big economic burden on the health sector. Research has shown a correlation between NCDs and the high and unsafe use of pesticides in agriculture. In 2019, through the Parliamentary Committee on Health, Kenya Organic Agriculture Network (KOAN) with partners petitioned parliament to summon the Pesticides Control Products Board to withdraw the pesticides that have been banned in the EU from the Kenyan market. Together with partners KOAN submitted a Scientific Report on Pesticides in the Kenyan Market in September 2021 indicating reasons why these pesticides need to be banned in Kenya. KOAN supports the EU Commissions call to introduce a mechanism prohibiting production and/or export of hazardous chemicals that are banned in the EU to protect non-EU countries from their negative effects on human health and the environment. Please find below links to the publications mentioned in the feedback text provided above. 1. A study conducted in Muranga and Kirinyaga counties in 2020 Title: Pesticide use in Kirinyaga and Muranga Counties Link: https://www.koan.co.ke/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/KOAN-White-paper_opt.pdf 2. Scientific Report on Pesticides in the Kenyan Market Title: Scientific Report on Pesticides in the Kenyan Market. Link: https://routetofood.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/09/Scientific-Report-on-Pesticides-in-the-Kenyan-Market-Report_Final-1.pdf 3. Public Petition Title: Public Petition (No. 70 of 2019) Regarding Withdrawal of Harmful Chemicals from Kenyan Market. Link: http://www.parliament.go.ke/sites/default/files/2020-10/Report%20of%20Public%20Petition%20on%20Withdrawal%20of%20Harmful%20Chemical%20pesticides%20in%20the%20Kenyan%20Market.pdf Additional useful resources 1. Title: Pesticide Atlas: Facts and figures about toxic chemicals in agriculture, Kenya Edition 2022 Link: https://ke.boell.org/sites/default/files/2022-11/pesticideatlas2022_kenya.pdf 2. Title: Pesticides in Kenya: Why our health, environment and food security are at stake Link: https://routetofood.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/Pesticide-use-in-Kenya-COMP.pdf
