feedback: - mit welchem Recht muten wir unseren Schwestern und Brüdern auf anderen Kontinenten etwas zu, was wir hier für nicht akzeptabel erachten? - Die Gifte kehren über importierte Waren zu uns zurück. - Mein Erkenntnisstand, alles was ich an wissenschaftlichen Ergebnissen gelesen habe, lässt mich sehr verwundert und auch verzweifelt sein, dass es wieder und wieder in Erwägung gezogen wird, Gifte, wie z. B. Glyphosat, zu verlängern. Und bei dem Mangel an Insekten, den wir aktuell haben, ist es traurig zusehen zu müssen, dass die Anzahl der Insektenfänger (Schwalben) sich jaehrlich dezimiert. (Jungtiere werden aus dem Nest geworfen, weil es an Nahrung fehlt, "unsere" Nester sind in den letzten 10 Jahren von 8 ! Auf 2 zurückgegangen.) Ebenso bei den Störchen: von dem einen Nest, von dem ich weiß, sind zwei von drei Jungen rausgestossen worden und das dritte scheint verkrüppelt zu sein, schafft keine Flugversuche. - es ist die produzierende Industrie, die die Gifte weiter verkaufen möchte, denn aus langjährigen Erfahrungen ( ich las und sah Berichte aus Europa und Süd-Amerika), ist bekannt, dass mit klugen Pflanzungen (Mais und Kürbis) die Früchte sich gegenseitig zu schützen vermögen und gleichzeitig den Boden See. Wir mussen endlich (wieder) mit der Natur leben, von der wir Menschen ein Teil sind. S. O. P. Save Our Planet - Now!
englishfeedback: — what right do we expect our sisters and brothers on other continents to accept? — The poisons return to us via imported goods. — My knowledge of everything I have read from scientific results is very surprising and desperate that it is again and again contemplated to prolong poisons, such as glyphosate. And given the current shortage of insects, it is sad to see that the number of insect vessels (bigs) is fiercely depleted. (Young animals are thrown out of the nest because of a lack of food, ‘our’ nests are in the last 10 years of 8! Decreased to 2) Similarly in the case of disturbances: of one nest, of which I know, two out of three boys have been cut off and the third seems to be troubled, there is no flight test. — it is the manufacturing industry that wants to sell the poison further, because from many years of experience (I las and saw reports from Europe and South America), it is known that with wise plantings (maize and pumpkin), the fruit is able to protect each other while at the same time the soil of lake. We must finally (re)live with the nature of which we people are part of. S.O.P. Save Our Planet – Now!

feedback: The Australian Government Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (DAFF) welcomes the opportunity to comment on the proposed EU initiative to prohibit the production for export of hazardous chemicals banned in the EU. Please refer to attached submission for DAFF's full response. Australia, like the EU, aims for a strong regulatory system that improves outcomes for human health and the environment, ensures sound management of chemicals through international cooperation and underpins operational conditions for industry by ensuring ongoing international trade. Australia maintains that cooperation through internationally recognised and effective chemical agreements and conventions safeguards regulatory best practice for the importation and exportation of chemicals while respecting the integrity and sovereignty of other jurisdictions chemical regulators. DAFF cautions that the proposed EU initiative to prohibit the production for export of hazardous chemicals banned in the EU undermines this collaborative, international approach. Several chemistries that are not approved for use in the EU may be essential for use in international contexts for plant protection, especially under emergency responses for biosecurity concerns. The potential for disparity in risk profiles according to environmental conditions and use are internationally acknowledged which is why a one-size-fits-all approach to regulation is not appropriate for global implementation. Any prohibition on export of chemicals not approved in the EU should be limited to those chemistries agreed for prohibition of manufacture and trade under internationally agreed instruments such as the Stockholm Convention on Persistent Organic Pollutants to ensure that essential uses in other jurisdictions are not compromised by the EUs actions. Restricting export of only those chemicals that have been internationally accepted as warranting prohibition on their manufacture and global trade best adheres to these existing and internationally agreed arrangements. Where the prohibition on manufacture, trade and use of a chemical has not been internationally agreed, DAFF recommends the EU support approaches that advance global chemicals management cooperatively and collaboratively through information sharing, capacity building and support for autonomous decisions by third countries regarding import of chemicals. Australia actively engages on measures aimed at strengthening the effectiveness of internationally accepted principles such as the Rotterdam Convention on the Prior Informed Consent Procedure for Certain Hazardous Chemicals and Pesticides in International Trade (PIC), and continues to advocate for an effective prior informed consent process that meets the needs of independent nations. Australia would also support the continuation of the EU specific prior informed consent approach for the export of chemicals not approved in the EU, separate to that of the PIC. This approach has ensured foreknowledge of Australian imports and to ensure the imported materials are authorised for use within Australia. DAFF recommends the EU carefully consider the implication discontinuing production in the EU may have for international environmental and human health outcomes. Chemical production in EU is strictly regulated and held to high levels of safety and compliance. International need for accessibility of these chemistries will drive production to continue offshore in other nations where safety and regulatory frameworks may not be as stringent. Measures aimed at strengthening international collaboration and the effectiveness of internationally accepted principles will support the needs and sovereignty of independent nations by enabling autonomy when setting parameters around chemical approval and use, encouraging capacity building, safeguarding regulatory best practice and ensuring advancement of global chemical management cooperatively and collaboratively.
organization: Australian Government Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Foresty

feedback: Die EU verbietet Pestizidwirkstoffe wegen unakzeptablen Risiken für die menschliche Gesundheit und/oder die Umwet, aber produziert weiterhin diese Wirkstoffe und exportiert sie in Drittländer. Das sind unmoralische Doppelstandards. GLOBAL 2000 hat deshalb kürzlich (Feb. 2023) einen Pestizid-Test zur diesen "Doppelstandards" der EU durchgeführt: Wir haben Pestizidrückstandsuntersuchungen bei Mangos, Bohnen und Fisolen aus Nicht-EU Ländern durchgeführt und 3 in der EU verbotene Pestizidwirkstoffe gefunden, die schwerwiegende gesundheitliche und umweltschädigende Auswirkungen haben (siehe Report im Anhang). Gefunden wurde: * Carbendazim auf Mangos und Fisolen aus Peru sowie auf Zuckererbsen aus Kenia. Carbendazim ist seit 30/11/2014 nicht mehr zugelassen in der EU und folgendermaßen eingestuft gemäß CLP: Kann genetische Defekte verursachen, Kann die Fruchtbarkeit beeinträchtigen, Kann das Kind im Mutterleib schädigen, Hormonell wirksam. Sehr giftig für Wasserorganismen, Säugetiere, Regenwürmer, Fische. Persistent. * Myclobutanil auf Fisolen: Seit 31/05/2021 nicht mehr zugelassen in der EU. Einstufung: Kann vermutlich das Kind im Mutterleib schädigen, sehr persistent, giftig für Wasserorganismen. * Imidacloprid auf Mangos aus Peru: Gesundheitsschädlich bei Verschlucken. Sehr giftig für Wasserorganismen, Bienen & Wildbienen, Vögel und Säugetiere. Persistent und sehr wasserlöslich. In der EU wegen seiner hohen Bienengiftigkeit nicht mehr zugelassen seit 01/12/2020. GLOBAL 2000 führt außerdem wöchentliche Pestizidrückstands-Analysen von am Markt verfügbarem Obst und Gemüse durch (vom Supermarkt) und wir finden regelmäßig Rückstände von in der EU verbotenen/nicht zugelassenen Pestizidwirkstoffen auf Obst und Gemüse aus Nicht-EU Ländern. Siehe Dokument im Anhang ab Seite 14: Produkte aus Drittstaaten aus den Jahren 2019-2023, bei denen in der EU nicht zugelassene Pestizid-Wirkstoffe gefunden wurden. In rot sind nachgewiesene Wirkstoffe, die zur Zeit der Probenziehung in der EU nicht zugelassen waren, aber auf den Produkten aus Drittstaaten gefunden wurden. In grün Wirkstoffe, die zur Zeit der Probenziehung noch zugelassen waren, aber heute (Juli 2023) verboten sind. Es wurden bis zu 4 in der EU zum Probenziehungsdatum nicht zugelassene Pestizid-Wirkstoffe pro Produkt gefunden. Die gefundenen Wirkstoffe reichen von Carbendazim über Bifenthrin, Iprodion oder Neonikotinoide bis zu Dinotefuran etc. Auch haben wir im Jahr 2015 die Wirkstoffe angeschaut, die in Brasilien zur Orangenproduktion zugelassen sind und auch eingesetzt werden (siehe Dokument im Anhang S.22). Schon damals waren 2 der eingesetzten WIrkstoffe in der EU nicht zugelassen: Paraquat, das lebensgefährlich bei Einatmen ist und als krebserregend und fortpflanzungsschädigend eingestuft ist, sowie Flufenoxuron, das Säuglinge über die Muttermilch schädigen kann. 11 weitere der damals für die Spritzpläne empfohlenen Wirkstoffe sind heute in der EU nicht mehr zugelassen.
organization: GLOBAL 2000, Friends of the Earth Austria
englishfeedback: The EU bans pesticide active substances due to unacceptable risks to human health and/or the Umwet, but continues to produce and export these active substances to third countries. These are immoral double standards. Global 2000 has therefore recently (Feb. In 2023) a pesticide test was carried out on these EU ‘double standards’: We have carried out pesticide residue studies on mangoes, beans and fisols from non-EU countries and found 3 pesticide active substances banned in the EU that have serious adverse health and environmental effects (see report in annex). Found: * Carbendazim on mangoes and fisols from Peru and on sugar peas from Kenya. Carbendazim has not been authorised in the EU since 30/11/2014 and classified according to CLP as follows: May cause genetic defects, may affect fertility, may damage the unborn child, may cause hormonal effectiveness. Very toxic to aquatic organisms, mammals, earthworms, fish. Persistent. * Myclobutanil on fisols: No longer authorised in the EU since 31/05/2021. Classification: Is likely to cause harm to the unborn child, very persistent, toxic to aquatic organisms. * Imidacloprid on mangoes from Peru: Harmful if swallowed. Very toxic to aquatic organisms, bees and wild bees, birds and mammals. Persistent and very soluble in water. No longer authorised in the EU since 01/12/2020 because of its high bee toxicity. Global 2000 also carries out weekly pesticide residue analyses of fruit and vegetables available on the market (from the supermarket) and we regularly find residues of pesticide active substances banned/unauthorised in the EU on fruit and vegetables from non-EU countries. See document attached from page 14 onwards: Products from third countries from 2019-2023 where unauthorised pesticide active substances were found in the EU. In red are detected active substances that were not authorised in the EU at the time of sampling but were found on products from third countries. In green active substances that were still approved at the time of sampling but are banned today (July 2023). Up to 4 pesticide active ingredients not authorised per product were found in the EU at the sampling date. The active substances found range from carbendazim to bifenthrin, iprodione or neonicotinoids, to dinotefuran, etc. We also looked at the active substances authorised and used in Brazil for the production of oranges in 2015 (see document in Annex p. 22). Already at that time, 2 of the active substances used were not authorised in the EU: Paraquat, which is life-threatening by inhalation and classified as carcinogenic and toxic to reproduction, and flufenoxuron, which may cause harm to breastfed infants. 11 other active substances recommended for spraying plans at the time are no longer authorised in the EU.

feedback: Do not allow the pesticide industry to export dangerous pesticides to countries outside Europa. People in countries in Africa and South America are often poor and so are also the countries where they live. That means that these farmers and their families are unable to get help if they fall ill using these pesticides who are so dangerous that they are forbidden i EU. Of course the pesticide industry do not like to lose their profits but here your responsibility comes in. Pesticides banned in EU should be banned all over the world both for people and for the environment and if EU can manage without them also other contries can.

O Instituto Regional da Pequena Agropecuária Apropriada IRPAA, organização não governamental, de fins não econômicos, com sede e atuação há 33 anos no Semiárido brasileiro, tendo como segmento de ação apoio à agricultura familiar de base agroecológica, vem por meio deste apoiar esta iniciativa da União Europeia de criar mecanismos que proíba a produção e/ou exportação de produtos químicos perigosos proibidos na UE afim de que possa proteger os países não pertencentes à UE de seus efeitos negativos na saúde humana e no meio ambiente. Para o Brasil, isso têm grande importância, uma vez que muitos produtos proibidos na UE são largamente utilizados por aqui, causando contaminações ambientais e consequente perda de biodiversidade, bem como aumento na incidência de doenças como câncer e transtornos relacionados ao sistema nervoso central da população. A proteção de áreas ambientais, com recursos hídricos, produção orgânica e agroecológica, escolas e moradias é imprescindível para garantia da vida humana. Outros dados que se somam e agravam o cenário brasileiro é a volta do país ao Mapa da Fome, segundo relatório da Organização das Nações Unidas-ONU, 33,1 milhão de pessoas não tem garantido o que comer; também foi evidenciado que 58,7%, mais da metade da população convive com a insegurança alimentar e quase 30% das crianças brasileiras de 2 a 9 anos deixarão de fazer ao menos uma das três refeições diárias. Fortalecimento da agricultura familiar, rural e urbana, de base agroecológica é imprescindível para que as nossas crianças e adolescentes tenham uma alimentação saudável e livre de agrotóxicos. Nesse sentido, a defesa da segurança alimentar e nutricional a partir não somente de aspectos quantitativos e qualitativos, mas, também a soberania alimentar, perpassando também pelo direito à alimentação isenta de agrotóxicos. No Brasil há diversas iniciativas de combate ao uso de agrotóxicos, entretanto, com pouco êxito na contenção da referida prática dada a predominância de congressistas e governantes ligados ao agronegócio, e consequente flexibilização das leis que regulamentam o comércio e uso desses produtos. Para além disso há significativo aporte de recursos para rede de educação, mídia e serviços estatais de assessoria técnica e extensão rural ligados à métodos convencionais de produção agropecuária em vez da produção orgânica e agroecológica. Atualmente, temos como no cenário brasileiro, a continuidade da Campanha permanente contra os agrotóxicos e pela vida (https://contraosagrotoxicos.org/) que dentre as ações encontra-se aberta coleta de assinaturas, sendo necessária dois milhões assinantes, pressionado pela aprovação de um Política Nacional da Redução de Agrotóxicos (https://www.chegadeagrotoxicos.org.br/). O último governo brasileiro, por exemplo, liberou de 2019 a 2022 mais de 2.000 tipos de agrotóxicos antes proibidos, tornando o Brasil um país líder mundial no consumo de agrotóxicos. Entrelaçado as liberações houve a desarticulação de órgãos ligados ao Meio Ambiente, como o Ministério do Meio Ambiente, com intuito de limitar a fiscalização dos mesmos frente a essas ações, assim como a liberação de outros químicos já proibidos em países da União Europeia, a alteração da nomenclatura de agrotóxicos para pesticidas com intuito de facilitar a passagem desses químicos. Então, os esforços, articulação e mobilização por movimentos e organizações da sociedade civil, bem como a passagem de governos mais comprometidos com as causas socioambientais, ainda não foram suficientes para reverter tal cenários. A exportação de produtos de uso proibido na UE, além de incoerente, acaba por favorecer a propagação do seu uso nos países menos comprometidos. Desse modo, assim como há restrições quanto a tipo e níveis de resíduos nos produtos de importação pela UE, é imprescindível, a proibição da produção e exportação de produtos químicos perigosos e comprometedores da plena qualidade de vida humana e equilíbrio ambiental.
firstName: Instituto Regional da Pequena Agropecuária Apropriada
organization: Instituto Regional da Pequena Agropecuária Apropriada
englishfeedback: The Regional Institute of Small Farming Apropriada IRPAA, a non-governmental, non-economic organisation, which has been based and has been active for 33 years in the Brazilian Semiarido, with the support of agri-ecological family farming as a segment, supports this EU initiative to establish mechanisms to ban the production and/or export of hazardous chemicals banned in the EU so that it can protect non-EU countries from their negative effects on human health and the environment. For Brazil, this is of great importance, as many products banned in the EU are widely used here, causing environmental contamination and consequent loss of biodiversity, as well as an increase in the incidence of diseases such as cancer and disorders related to the central nervous system of the population. The protection of environmental areas, with water resources, organic and agro-ecological production, schools and dwellings is essential to ensure human life. Other figures that add to and worsen the Brazilian scenario are moving around the country to the Hunger Map, according to the United Nations Organisation of UN report, 33,1 million people have not guaranteed what they eat; it was also highlighted that 58.7 %, more than half of the population lives with food insecurity and almost 30 % of Brazilian children aged 2-9 will stop doing at least one of the three daily meals. Strengthening agro-ecological family, rural and urban farming is essential if our children and adolescents are to have healthy and agrotoxic food. In this sense, the defence of food and nutrition security not only from quantitative and qualitative aspects, but also from food sovereignty, is also lost through the right to food free of agrotoxic. In Brazil there are a number of initiatives to combat the use of agrotoxicants, with little success in curbing this practice, given the predominance of congressiers and governors linked to agro-business, and the resulting relaxation of laws regulating trade in and use of these products. In addition, there is a significant supply of resources to the education network, mini and state technical advisory and extension services linked to conventional farming methods rather than organic and agro-ecological production. In the Brazilian scenario, we now see the continuation of the permanent campaign against agrotoxicants and life (https://contraosagrotoxicos.org/), which among the actions is open to collection of signatures, and two million subscribers are required, under pressure from the approval of a National Policy on Reducing Agrotoxicants (https://www.chegadeagrotoxicos.org.br/). The latest Brazilian government, for example, released more than 2.000 previously banned types of agrotoxic from 2019 to 2022, making Brazil a world leader country in the consumption of agrotoxic products. In connection with releases, organs linked to the environment, such as the Ministry of the Environment, were disconnected in order to limit their monitoring of these activities, as well as the release of other chemicals already banned in EU countries, the amendment of the nomenclature of agrotoxicants for pesticides in order to facilitate the passage of these chemicals. Then, efforts, articulation and mobilisation by civil society movements and organisations, as well as the shift of governments more committed to socio-environmental causes, have not yet been sufficient to reverse such scenarios. The export of prohibited products in the EU, in addition to being inconsistent, ultimately favours the spread of their use in the least distressed countries. As well as restrictions on the type and levels of waste in EU import products, a ban on the production and export of hazardous chemicals and compromising the full quality of human life and environmental balance is essential.

feedback: Zakazujete výrobu nebezpečných chemikálií, ale dovoz kontaminovaného obilia a z neho múku plnú pesticídov a herbicídov nás nútite konzumovať! Robíte z nás druhotriednych obyvateľov a preto žiadam zákaz pre všetky produkty obsahujúce jedy a nepovolené látky, lebo je to diskriminácia na ktorej sa EU priamo podieľa!
englishfeedback: You ban the production of hazardous chemicals, but you force us to eat contaminated grain and its flour with full pesticides and herbicides! Making us a second class population, I am calling for a ban on all products containing poisons and unauthorised substances because it is the discrimination in which the EU is directly involved!

feedback: Žiadam komisiu, aby zohľadnila prijatie zákazu dovozu a konzumácie potravín, ktoré boli ošetrované nedovolenými látkami alebo dovolenými látkami, ale v prekročenom množstve. Ako občan EÚ sa cítim diskriminovaná, keď nám EÚ prikazuje konzumovať múku z kontaminovaného obilia dovezeného z Ukrajiny!!! Takýmto príkazom sa EÚ dopúšťa diskriminácie, ale aj genocídy obyvateľov východného bloku!!!!
englishfeedback: I ask the Commission to take account of the adoption of a prohibition on the import and consumption of foodstuffs which have been treated with illicit substances or authorised substances but in excess quantities. As an EU citizen, I feel discriminated against when the EU obliges us to consume flour from contaminated grain imported from Ukraine! With such an order, the EU commits discrimination, but also genocide, of the people of the Eastern bloc!

feedback: Ich war mehr als überrascht, als ich erfahren habe, dass es erlaubt ist, in der EU verbotene Pestizide aus der EU auszuführen. Das macht überhaupt keinen Sinn und muss aus meiner Sicht dringend korrigiert werden. Pestizide, die in der EU wegen Risiken für Umwelt und Gesundheit aus gutem Grund verboten sind, dürfen auch nicht exportiert werden, bzw. sollten erst gar nicht produziert werden dürfen.
englishfeedback: I was more than surprised when I learned that it is allowed to export banned pesticides in the EU. This makes no sense at all and, in my view, urgently needs to be corrected. Pesticides that are banned for good reason in the EU because of risks to the environment and health must not be exported or should not be allowed to be produced at all.

feedback: Chemikalien, die wegen ihrer Gefährlichkeit innerhalb der EU nicht eingesetzt werden dürfen, sollten entsprechend auch nicht erst hergestellt werden. Eine Ausfuhr in andere Länder verbietet sich damit von selbst.
englishfeedback: Similarly, chemicals that cannot be used within the EU due to their hazardous nature should not be manufactured in the first place. Exports to other countries are therefore prohibited by themselves.

feedback: JE REMERCIE LA COMMISSION DE NOUS PERMETTRE DE DONNER NOTRE AVIS ! En tant qu'européen, nous ne pouvons produire et envoyer dans le monde, des produits que nous estimons dangereux pour notre santé de français et d'européens. Persister c'est : - une catastrophe environnementale (atteinte à la biodiversité, pollution des sols et des eaux, émissions de GES pour leur fabrication) (tout cela coûte très cher au climat de la terre ) - un danger pour les êtres humains (cancers et autres maladies touchant les agriculteurs, les agricultrices et les personnes consommatrices) (tout cela coûte très cher aux familles de la terre ) - un fardeau économique, lié aux coûts cachés quils représentent : subventions, coûts administratifs dapprobation et de mise sur le marché, de réévaluation, coûts sanitaires et de dépollution (tout cela coûte très cher aussi aux sociétés et états de la terre ) - un modèle à rebours du modèle agroécologique que je défends - sans compter que quand nous consommons des produits importés, cela se retrouve dans notre assiette... Jusqu'à aujourdhui, lUE adopte une position très critiquable : elle reconnaît comme dangereux toute une liste de pesticides dont elle interdit la vente dans ses pays membres MAIS autorise la production et lexportation vers dautres pays ne bénéficiant pas de réglementation suffisante pour protéger leurs paysannes et leurs citoyennes. Serions-nous aussi perfides ! continuer dans cette voie est une hypocrisie. On vous dira : qu'elle aille habiter en Chine ! Que notre économie en pâtira ! etc... Mais Alors, quel monde laissons-nous à nos enfants ? OUI, nous devons : - donner l'exemple, - chercher à augmenter le niveau de protection en dehors de l'UE même si les pays se procurent ces chimies nocives, par ailleurs, - encourager les opérateurs commerciaux en dehors de l'UE à reconsidérer l'utilisation future de ces produits chimiques.
englishfeedback: I THANK THE COMMISSION FOR ALLOWING US TO GIVE OUR OPINION! As a European, we cannot produce and send to the world products that we consider dangerous for our health of French and Europeans. Persisting is: — an environmental disaster (damage to biodiversity, pollution of soil and water, GHG emissions for their production) (all of which is very expensive for the earth’s climate) – a danger to humans (cancers and other diseases affecting farmers, women farmers and consumers) (all this is very expensive for the land’s families) – an economic burden linked to the hidden costs they represent: subsidies, administrative costs of approval and placing on the market, reassessment, health and clean-up costs (all of which is very expensive also for companies and states of the land) – a reverse model of the agro-ecological model that I am advocating – not to mention that when we consume imported products, this can be found in our base... Until today, the EU has taken a very critical stance: it recognises as dangerous a list of pesticides, the sale of which it prohibits in its member countries MAIS, authorises production and export to other countries which do not have sufficient rules to protect their farmers and citizens. Let us also be perfide! continue in this direction is hypocrisy. You will be told: she is living in China! That our economy will suffer! etc. But what world do we leave to our children? Yes, we need to: — lead by example, – seek to increase the level of protection outside the EU even if countries obtain these harmful chemies, on the other hand, encourage traders outside the EU to reconsider the future use of these chemicals.

feedback: Diese Pestizide sind zu Recht in Europa verboten, dann kann nicht der Export erlaubt werden! Danke !!!
englishfeedback: These pesticides are rightly banned in Europe, then export cannot be allowed! Thank you!

feedback: Länder, in denen es kaum Vorschriften für giftige Pestizide gibt, werden als Markt benutzt. Europäische Unternehmen sollten nicht die Möglichkeit haben, diesen Umstand auszunutzen. Wie kann Europa als Weltmacht ernst genommen werden, wenn wir gefährliche Chemikalien ins Ausland verschiffen und dabei Mensch und Natur in Ländern vergiften, in denen Sicherheitsvorschriften geringer sind und weniger streng durchgesetzt werden? Ein Exportverbot für giftige Pestizide würde Europa und der Welt helfen, zu nachhaltigeren Pflanzenschutzmethoden überzugehen. Wenn gefährliche Pestizide auf dem Markt bleiben, werden wir weiter auf eine grünere Zukunft und nachhaltige Landwirtschaft warten müssen. Ein Rechtsgutachten des Center for International Environmental Law, das 2022 veröffentlicht wurde, zeigt, dass die EU mit dem Export verbotener Pestizide nach Afrika und Mittelamerika gegen internationale rechtliche Verpflichtungen und die Menschenrechte verstößt. Diese Pestizide sind in Europa verboten, aber der Export ist erlaubt: Das ist eine Doppelmoral. Die gefährlichen Pestizide wurden in Europa verboten, nachdem sie mit Krebs, Beeinträchtigung der Fruchtbarkeit und neurodegenerativen Krankheiten in Verbindung gebracht wurden - zum Bienensterben tragen sie außerdem bei. Einige dieser Pestizide sind in Europa verboten, weil sie mit Hirnschäden bei Kindern und ungeborenen Babys in Verbindung gebracht werden. Wenn diese Pestizide für uns zu gefährlich sind: Wie können wir dann zulassen, dass sie exportiert werden?
englishfeedback: Countries with little regulation on toxic pesticides are used as a market. European companies should not be able to take advantage of this fact. How can Europe be taken seriously as a global power when we ship dangerous chemicals abroad, poisoning people and nature in countries where safety rules are lower and enforcement is less stringent? A ban on exports of toxic pesticides would help Europe and the world move towards more sustainable plant protection practices. If hazardous pesticides remain on the market, we will have to wait for a greener future and sustainable agriculture. A legal opinion from the Center for International Environmental Law, published in 2022, shows that the EU is in breach of international legal obligations and human rights by exporting banned pesticides to Africa and Central America. These pesticides are banned in Europe, but exports are allowed: This is a double standard. Hazardous pesticides have been banned in Europe after being associated with cancer, fertility impairment and neurodegenerative diseases and contribute to bee mortality. Some of these pesticides are banned in Europe because they are associated with brain damage in children and unborn babies. If these pesticides are too dangerous for us: How can we then allow them to be exported?

feedback: Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, von einer Bürgerrechtsorganisation habe ich erfahren, dass in der EU demnächst über ein Exportverbot für giftige Pestizide nach Afrika und Südamerika abgestimmt werden soll. Ich finde es ethisch nicht vertretbar, Pestizide, die in Europa mit gutem Grund verboten sind in ärmere Länder mit niedrigeren Schutzbestimmungen auszuführen. Der Arbeitsschutz der Arbeiter in der Landwirtschaft in Afrika und Südamerika ist wesentlich geringer als bei uns und die Arbeit mit den giftigen Pestiziden führt bereits nach kurzer Zeit zu Vergiftungen und schwerwiegenden Erkrankungen. Zudem ist nicht auszuschließen, dass landwirtschaftliche Produkte aus den beiden Ländern, die mit diesen giftigen Pestiziden bearbeitet wurden, z.T. wieder in Europa im Supermarkt landen, was dann auch noch für die hier lebenden Menschen gefährlich werden könnte. Die Auswirkungen auf die dort vorhandenen Ökossysteme sind verheerend, was wiederum eine Katastrophe angesichts der sich aktuell zuspitzenden Klimakrise und des grassierenden Artensterbens darstellt. Bitte setzen Sie sich für ein Exportverbot ein. Mit freundlichen Grüßen Julie Gretenkord
englishfeedback: Ladies and Gentlemen, from a civil rights organisation, I have learned that a ban on exports of toxic pesticides to Africa and South America is about to be voted in the EU. I do not find it ethically acceptable to export pesticides that are for good reason banned in Europe to poorer countries with lower protective provisions. The health and safety of agricultural workers in Africa and South America is much lower than for us, and work on toxic pesticides is already leading to poisoning and serious illnesses after a short period of time. Moreover, it cannot be ruled out that agricultural products from the two countries that have been processed with these toxic pesticides will in some cases end up in Europe again in the supermarket, which could then also become dangerous for the people living there. The impact on the existing eco-systems is devastating, which in turn is a catastrophe given the current worsening climate crisis and the widespread extinction of species. Please advocate an export ban. Yours sincerely, Julie Gretenkord

feedback: Wir brauchen ein Exportverbot von in der EU verbotenen Pestizide. Diese Pestizide sind aufgrund ihrer Gefährlichkeit für Natur, Umwelt und den Menschen in der EU verboten. Sie sind jedoch in anderen Ländern ebenso schädlich und sollten daher auch dort nicht ausgebracht werden. Natur- und Artenschutz hören nicht an den EU Grenzen auf, sondern sollten dringend auch global betrachtet werden. Themen wie Klimawandel, Arten- und Naturschutz sind global genauso wichtig, wie lokal. Auch stehen Menschen, die in Ländern des globalen Südens in der Landwirtschaft arbeiten, oftmals nicht ausreichend Schutzausrütung zur Verfügung, um sich vor gesundheitlichen Schäden durch das Ausbringen der Pestizide zu schützen. Daher sollten wir unserer globalen Verantwortung nachkommen und den Export dieser Substanzen beenden! Vielen Dank!
englishfeedback: We need a ban on exports of pesticides banned in the EU. These pesticides are banned in the EU because of their hazardous nature, the environment and people. However, they are equally harmful in other countries and should therefore not be applied there. Nature and species protection do not stop at the EU’s borders, but should also urgently be looked at globally. Issues such as climate change, species and nature protection are as important globally as local. In addition, people working in agriculture in countries of the global south are often not sufficiently protected to protect themselves from damage to health caused by pesticide application. We should therefore assume our global responsibility and stop exporting these substances! Thank you!

feedback: Le règlement devrait interdire la vente de tous les pesticides et autres produits considérés comme dangereux pour la santé humaine et pour l'environnement y compris à l'exportation vers des pays tiers.
englishfeedback: The Regulation should prohibit the sale of all pesticides and other products considered dangerous for human health and the environment, including for export to third countries.

feedback: The Division of Environmental Health in the School of Public Health at the University of Cape Town in South Africa has been conducting health, environmental and policy research linked to chemicals for over 40 years. This research has focused on national, regional and global chemical issues and risk management/prevention. Our work focuses on protecting the health of populations (particularly vulnerable populations in Africa and other low- and middle-income countries LMICs), as well as the environment they live in. Currently, South Africa and other African countries receive many pesticides and chemicals that are banned for use in the EU. It is important to reflect on why a country would decide to ban the use of a chemical nationally yet support the continued production of said chemical to be used in other countries. How is it that a country can support a not in my backyard (NIMBY) principle that allows for people and the environment in other countries to be exposed to chemicals legislated to be too toxic, hazardous, carcinogenic, mutagenic, toxic to reproduction, toxic to aquatic environments, etc.? There are two key factors which do not warrant the unethical export of banned chemicals from the EU to LMICs. Firstly, are the extensive profits earned by EU-based companies by continuing to sell harmful chemicals which are often old molecules and therefore cheap to produce while earning the company substantial income. In turn, EU country governments presumably benefit from the taxes paid by these companies on profits linked to selling EU-banned chemicals. There may be an assumption in the EU that LMICs do not have to import these banned chemicals and do so freely. However, the complexity behind weak, fragmented and unspecific chemical legislation, which is an issue in South Africa and other LMICs, is that without legislation like REACH (CLP, etc.) these countries cannot legally deny the importation of these chemicals. National industries and companies wanting to receive these chemicals can legally prevent the non-importation of these chemicals due to weak legislation. Thus it is critical that the EU supports legislation prohibiting the production and export of EU-banned chemicals. The second factor which does not justify the exportation of EU-banned chemicals often expressed is the need for these chemicals (pesticides) for food security or because they are cheap and support the economies and production in resource-poor countries. Firstly, there is no research which directly links the need to use banned pesticides to promote food security in a country. The lack of food security is often more of an access issue than a production issue. Furthermore, there are less toxic alternatives available for agricultural production, particularly in light of increased pest resistance to many of the EU-banned pesticides, for example. The loophole of weak legislation and the unfounded argument for the need for cheap chemicals does not consider the hidden externalities and costs for LMICs, like South Africa, when their populations and environment are exposed to these hazardous chemicals. These come in the form of increased health costs for the public health sector, with often failing and poor infrastructure, to manage the increase in cancers, developmental and neurobehavioral linked diseases, the increase in asthma cases and allergies, acute poisonings, self-harm and deaths currently being experienced. Lastly, stopping the production and export of EU-banned pesticides and chemicals should be implemented immediately with all export permits not honored. There should be no phase-out periods granted for companies to dump their remaining stocks of these EU-banned chemicals on any LMIC or other non-EU country. It is unethical and a human rights violation to allow for a period of time to continue exporting so that the exporting companies and the EU countries where these companies are based do not have to deal with the stockpiles (e.g., the granting of a
organization: Division of Environmental Health, University of Cape Town

feedback: Il est inadmissible que l'Europe fabrique des produits dont elle connaît les dangers pour les vendre à des pays tiers
englishfeedback: It is unacceptable for Europe to produce products whose dangers it knows to sell them to third countries

feedback: Verbot der Herstellung und Ausfuhr von Chemikalien, die in der Europäischen Union verboten sind
englishfeedback: Ban on the production and export of chemicals banned in the European Union

feedback: Je soutiens l'option qui consiste à introduire une interdiction de produire des produits chimiques dangereux qui ne sont pas approuvés ou sont interdits de mise sur le marché et/ou dutilisation dans lUnion. Voici les raisons pour lesquelles je soutiens cette option : En tant qu'infirmière : il vaut mieux prévenir que guérir. Nous produisons déjà pas mal d'armes qui tuent ... Pourquoi continuer à produire en Europe des produits, des intrants qui ne sont pas sans impact sur la Santé mondiale. Nous produisons en plus ce que nous ne voulons pas utiliser chez nous ... La Terre ne devrait appartenir à personne et devrait être respectée comme l'Homme l'a toujours fait. Maintenant, l'homme veut tout contrôler, il dit connaître (il dit qu'il gère !) et veut nourrir la planète et donner à manger au monde entier ... N'avions-nous pas déjà promis cela il y a plus de 40 ans ? En ce temps là, le bol de riz était de la même qualité pour tous et nous voulions aussi permettre à tous d'avoir accès à l'eau. Qu'en est-il advenu ? Il y a le riz non traité qui a du goût, qui est aussi plus cher (pas un grain de riz n'est jeté ...) et l'autre que je ne veux pas manger ... ! Nous avons une qualité de l'eau qui se détériore et nous devons la traiter régulièrement pour qu'elle continue à être potable pour tous. Mais si vous l'analysez de plus près ... elles contient des substances chimiques, des pesticides et que sais-je encore mais dans des normes acceptables pour certains. Et nous, nous avons la "chance" d'avoir des restrictions : je n'ose donc pas imaginer ce qu'il en est dans ces pays où nous continuons à exporter nos produits de synthèse. Cela n'est pas rassurant !!! Qu'allons-nous laisser aux enfants et aux générations futures ? J'ai toujours vu et admiré les paysans travaillant aux champs en plein jour et aux regards de tous. Aujourd'hui, j'aimerais pouvoir voir les exploitants de nos Terres sur le terrain quand ils se mettent à engager une main d'oeuvre pour faire leur (sale) boulot ... Pourquoi ne se trouvent-ils pas sur le terrain au moment où ils pulvérisent et "nourrissent" la Terre de leurs intrants tolérés chez nous. Il parait que même sur nos vitres, il se trouve avoir des résidus de ces substances ... Qu'en est-il des poumons et de la peau de nos tous jeunes enfants ? Je sors sans doute du contexte mais en plus, cette année, ils ont géré, pulvérisé avec ces produits tolérés par certains pour "nourrir" la planète mais pas de chance ... il pleut et des hectares de blé sont en train de moisir sur pied !!! J'en pleure quand je traverse nos campagnes : les champs virent du jaune au gris, au noir (voir photo prise en Hesbaye). Quel argent va encore indemniser ces pauvres agriculteurs qui ont perdu confiance en leur savoir faire et qui se sont tournés vers ces entreprises sans scrupule qui les forment gratuitement !!! ...? Pour toute cette main d'oeuvre qui perdrait leur emploi ... Il y a de nombreuses réorientations professionnelles possible et dans des métiers bien plus valorisants. Quelques exemples de métiers en pénurie : électricien ; aide-soignant ; main d'oeuvre pour un travail agricole respectueux de l'environnement. Il nous faut des courageux qui voient le travail à fournir et qui n'attendent pas d'obéir à des puissances qui ne recherchent que le profit. A quand d'ailleurs de nouvelles usines non pas made in "RPC" mais des usines qui n'exploiteraient pas la main d'oeuvre et paieraient leurs employés à un juste prix. Où est cette main-d'oeuvre qualifiée capable de produire des vêtements qui seraient en fibres naturelles ou qui fabriquerait des produits qui se répareraient plutôt que d'être à "usage unique" ? Du travail, il y en aura toujours !!! Le tout est qu'il soit valorisant, non abrutissant et plus respectueux de la Nature et de l'Homme !!!
englishfeedback: I support the option of introducing a ban on the production of hazardous chemicals that are not approved or banned from being placed on the market and/or dutilised in the EU. Here are the reasons why I support this option: As a nurse: prevention of disease is better than cure. We are already producing weapons that kill... Why continue to produce products in Europe, inputs that have an impact on global health. We also produce what we do not want to use at home... The Earth should not belong to anyone and should be respected as man has always done. Now, man wants to control everything, he says he knows (he says he manages!) and wants to feed the planet and give food to the whole world... Have we not promised this already more than 40 years ago? At that time, rice bol was of the same quality for everyone and we also wanted to give everyone access to water. What done? There is untreated rice that has a taste, which is also more expensive (no rice grain is discarded...) and the other that I do not want to eat...  We have a deteriorating quality of water and we need to treat it regularly so that it continues to be drinking for all. But if you analyse it more closely... they contain chemicals, pesticides and which I still grasp but to acceptable standards for some. And we have the ‘chance’ to have restrictions: so I do not want to imagine what is happening in these countries where we continue to export our synthetic products. This is not reassuring! What will we leave to children and future generations? I have always seen and admired the peasants working in the fields on the day and in the eyes of everyone. Today, I would like to see the operators of our Land on the ground when they start to hire a labour force to make their (dirty) jobs... Why are they not on the ground when they spray and “feed” the Earth on their tolerated inputs at home. It seems that even on our windows, there are residues of these substances... What about the lungs and skin of our young children? I probably know the context, but in addition this year they managed, sprayed with these products that were tolerated by some to ‘feed’ the planet, but no chance... he pledges and hectares of wheat are mould on the ground! I am alive when I go through our countryside: the fields move from yellow to grey and black (see photo taken in Hesbaye). What money will still compensate these poor farmers who have lost confidence in their know-how and have turned to these unscrupulous businesses that train them free of charge? ...? For all this labour force who loses their jobs... There are many career shifts possible and in much more valuable occupations. Some examples of shortage occupations: electrician; caregivers; labour force for environmentally-friendly agricultural work. We need courageous people who see the work to be done and do not expect to obey powers that are only seeking profit. This is when new plants not made in the PRC but plants which do not exploit the labour force and pay their employees a fair price. Where is this skilled workforce capable of producing clothes that would be made of natural fibres or which would produce products that would react rather than being “single-use”? From work, there will always be one! It is all that it is valued, non-abrutionary and more respectful of nature and man!

feedback: EU Commission is currently conducting an impact assessment simultaneously with the public consultation, although no concrete legislative proposal has been submitted yet. However, the actual impact can only be determined when it is clearly defined which substances exactly are to be banned and under which conditions. If it proves to be true that there are serious plans to ban all substances on the EU PIC list, the impact assessment carried out until then will be far from sufficient and the Commission runs the risk of violating the inter-institutional principle of best legislation, as the Council and Parliament would not be sufficiently involved. Substances are now to be identified and banned on basis of the PIC regulation. At this point in time, only the Commission knows how extensive the planned ban might be. It is made clear whether it should be a ban on PIC substances, or even on all substances listed in Annex I of the PIC Regulation. There is already a functioning and established law that regulates how chemical substances can be banned, namely the REACH Regulation. Based on scientific data, including thousands of studies (mostly on vertebrates), safe uses for humans and the environment have already been identified. We do not need a new law that now annuls these and undermines the REACH Regulation because the Commission is running out of time with its political agenda. Under the guise of sustainability, relatively unproblematic industrial chemicals are being equated with super-poisons, namely those PIC substances for which international agreements actually exist. Under the slogan: "Lead by example" and within the framework of sustainability, the EU Commission is presenting a legislative initiative aimed at banning the production and export of PIC substances altogether. This may not only concern the substances listed in Annex 3 of the Rotterdam Convention, but all 289 EU PIC entries added unilaterally by the Commission, which are not subject to international agreements (it is important to distinguish between entries and substances, because behind the 289 entries there are in fact hundreds of substances or even more; an example: the entry: all dioctyltin compounds stands for 48 substances). The impending ban, which would affect the production and export of hundreds of substances in the EU, represents a massive disadvantage for the European chemical industry on the global market. The European production of the less hazardous industrial chemicals, which are also on the list, is probably responsible for thousands of jobs, which would be lost due to a production ban. This would not be in line with the UN sustainability goals. Non-EU countries would continue to produce these substances and even expand production, as the substances are used in numerous everyday products and are indispensable in them. Both in articles and as substances themselves, they would be legally allowed to be imported into the EU despite the production ban. Weakening Europe as an industrial location or even dismantling it in parts cannot have a positive signal effect on the non-EU world. It would be desirable for the Commission's draft to start by banning substances for which international agreements actually exist.

Diese Pestizide sind in Europa verboten, aber der Export ist erlaubt: Das ist eine Doppelmoral. Die gefährlichen Pestizide wurden in Europa verboten, nachdem sie mit Krebs, Beeinträchtigung der Fruchtbarkeit und neurodegenerativen Krankheiten in Verbindung gebracht wurden - zum Bienensterben tragen sie außerdem bei. Einige dieser Pestizide sind in Europa verboten, weil sie mit Hirnschäden bei Kindern und ungeborenen Babys in Verbindung gebracht werden. Wenn diese Pestizide für uns zu gefährlich sind: Wie können wir dann zulassen, dass sie exportiert werden? Die Ausfuhr von giftigen Pestiziden ist eine Frage der Menschenrechte, denn die Pestizide schaden den Menschen: Jedes Jahr sterben Tausende von Landwirt*innen durch den Kontakt mit gefährlichen Pestiziden. Es gibt unzählige Studien, die die schädlichen Auswirkungen der exportierten Pestizide auf den Menschen belegen.
englishfeedback: These pesticides are banned in Europe, but exports are allowed: This is a double standard. Hazardous pesticides have been banned in Europe after being associated with cancer, fertility impairment and neurodegenerative diseases and contribute to bee mortality. Some of these pesticides are banned in Europe because they are associated with brain damage in children and unborn babies. If these pesticides are too dangerous for us: How can we then allow them to be exported? The export of toxic pesticides is a human rights issue, as pesticides harm people: Every year thousands of farmers die from exposure to hazardous pesticides. There are countless studies demonstrating the harmful effects of exported pesticides on humans.

feedback: Ich unterstütze die Initiative. Wir können nicht Chemikalien ausführen, die wir selbst als giftig für Mensch und Natur befinden. Es sollte eine Ausfuhr unterbunden / verboten werden. Ein gerechter Akt, nicht nur für uns Europäer.
englishfeedback: I support the initiative. We cannot export chemicals that we find themselves toxic to humans and nature. Export should be prevented/prohibited. A fair act, not only for us Europeans.

feedback: Können Sie es verantworten, dass weiterhin Exporte giftiger Pestizide nach Afrika und Südamerika erlaubt sind. NEIN Können Sie es verantworten, dass durch diese giftigen Pestizide Menschen zu schaden kommen und die Böden vergiftet werden. NEIN Die Pestizidindustrie wird ein Exportverbot verkraften, die Produktion umstellen, wie bei jeder technologischen Neuerung. Die Arbeitsplätze werden erhalten bleiben.
englishfeedback: Can you be responsible for continuing to allow exports of toxic pesticides to Africa and South America. No can you be responsible for the harm caused by these toxic pesticides and the poisoning of soils. No, the pesticide industry will face an export ban that switches production, as with any technological innovation. Jobs will be preserved.

feedback: I have observed and commented on the introduction of mass monocultures of genetically modified crops in Argentina from 1997 onwards (see: Argentina: A Case Study on the Impact of Genetically Engineered Soya: https://www.econexus.info/publication/argentina-case-study-impact-genetically-engineered-soya ) and noted the cumulative negative impact of herbicides and other agrotoxics sprayed from the air on biodiversity and human health. Furthermore, thousands of small farmers were forcibly expelled from their farms, sometimes with considerable violence, to make way for this development. It is important to remember that agricultural monocultures are extremely vulnerable to disease and invasive pests. Thus herbicide tolerance expanded rapidly in targeted weeds, necessitating the development of crops tolerant of these herbicides as well as, or instead of, glyphosate, whose use is still permitted in the EU. These include glufosinate ammonium, which is now banned in the EU and which the EU is still exporting. https://apps.fas.usda.gov/newgainapi/api/Report/DownloadReportByFileName?fileName=Agricultural%20Biotechnology%20Annual_Buenos%20Aires_Argentina_10-20-2020 This has led to toxic treadmills the development of crops with resistance to more than one herbicide to address these diseases and pests, leading to increased pest and weed resistance and increasingly heavy application of multiple herbicides and pesticides in response across Argentina and also in Brazil and Paraguay. In turn, this response has continued to promote resistance to multiple herbicides amongst persistent weeds and pests. Other substances applied in these massive monocultures include chlorpyrifos, cypermethrin and endosulfan, banned in the EU, but which the EU is still exporting. https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/B9780444593894000021 https://ri.conicet.gov.ar/bitstream/handle/11336/24885/CONICET_Digital_Nro.db45f812-2be9-4960-b24f-f194a2faaf39_A.pdf?sequence=2&isAllowed=y In Argentina, the application of multiple chemicals from the air to crops engineered to be tolerant of these chemicals has had - and continues to have - profound impacts on the health of communities ranging from villages to small towns. Impacts range from miscarriages and birth defects to serious skin problems. https://www.econexus.info/files/corruption-of-agricultural-science-orfc.pdf Another major problem the EU must consider is the fact that in many countries, pesticides are applied without the precautions prescribed, for example, proper protective equipment for workers, often women, to protect them from the agrotoxics they are forced to apply. Other issues include: people having no access to health checks or treatment and no choice about their working conditions. This is a vital point: the EU may have regulations for the use of agrotoxics, but the countries to which they export them often do not, or else these are not enforced. This means that it is simply not morally acceptable to export agrotoxics to such countries, even if their use is allowed in the EU. Where it is no longer allowed, but the EU continues to export, this is even worse. The expansion of agricultural monocultures of GM crops across South America has led to the destruction of forests, with serious negative impacts on soil quality and water supplies. Such forest clearance also leads to accelerated climate change. It has also had serious negative impacts on Indigenous Peoples, whose lands have been appropriated by producers of these crops, for example in Paraguay: https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/11/30/how-paraguay-indigenous-communities-are-fighting-big-soy Much of the GM soya and corn exported from Argentina, Paraguay, Brazil etc is used as feed, for example pigs in intensive production in Germany. This demonstrates the serious impacts of the consumption of meat produced in such feedlots in the global north on biodiversity, climate and people in the global south.

As a Dutch and EU citizen, father and academic, I would like to wholeheartedly endorse this initiative by the European Commission. Plenty of scientific evidence has shown that the pesticides under discussion are harmful to health and the environment and may cause long-term and long-lasting damages - to the EU and its citizens as well: pollution knows no boundaries, as the 'globalization' of DDT has shown us. There is no moral reason to continue the export of pesticides forbidden in the EU. We would be much better off to instead collaborate on (not export) knowledge-building of agro-ecological climate-smart systems; developing governance arrangements so that farmers are rewarded for implementing such systems over extractive, chemical-dependent systems; and promoting plant-based diets to relieve overall pressures on our food systems. (As a family of vegetarians, we are already doing our part in this!) While the fear of production moving out of the EU might not be unfounded, this should by no means encourage a 'race to the bottom'. Rather, it should encourage the EU to strengthen existing international regulations such as the UN Rotterdam treaty and develop alternatives that are not only more sustainable, but also more productive and resilient. Finally, the loss of jobs and growth I find, to be fair, a non-issue. What is important is that EU citizens can participate meaningfully in our society and are guaranteed a basic standard of living. Neither is tied to a specific sector, on the contrary, no EU citizen should have to choose between not having a job and producing products that harm our soils, animal and human life. Like all transitions, the move away from chemical pesticides will disrupt existing structures, and thus require measures to ensure human wellbeing throughout, such as professional re-education and financial support for humans (rather than companies) whose livelihood depends on production of now-banned pesticides. In this way, the human capital now invested in creating harmful products can be made available for and invited to develop truly sustainable food systems. I look forward to see this initiative 'in action' in full force and appreciate its development by the European Commission. Sincerely, Auke Pols The Netherlands

L'interdiction des pesticides dangereux s'impose pour les raisons suivantes: L'exportation de pesticides toxiques révèle une politique de deux poids deux mesures : les pesticides dangereux sont interdits en Europe après avoir été associés à des cancers, des problèmes de reproduction et des maladies neurodégénératives, ainsi qu'à la mort des abeilles. Certains de ces pesticides sont même interdits en Europe en raison de leur lien avec des lésions cérébrales chez les enfants et les bébés. Si ces pesticides sont trop dangereux pour nous, comment pouvons-nous autoriser leur exportation ? L'exportation de pesticides toxiques est une question de droits humains, car ces pesticides sont nocifs pour notre santé. Chaque année, des milliers d'agriculteurs meurent des suites dune trop forte exposition à ces pesticides dangereux. Les pesticides exportés font l'objet d'innombrables études qui confirment leurs effets délétères sur les humains. L'exportation de pesticides toxiques est néfaste pour les abeilles, la biodiversité et la planète en général. Les preuves sont claires : les néonics et autres pesticides dangereux tuent les abeilles. C'est pourquoi ils sont interdits en Europe. Pourquoi autorisons-nous encore leur exportation vers des pays où la réglementation est moins stricte, alors quils continueront de tuer les abeilles et décimer la biodiversité ? L'exportation de pesticides toxiques profite des pays où la réglementation est moins stricte. L'UE a un rôle à jouer dans le monde - ses entreprises ne devraient pas être autorisées à profiter des pays où la réglementation est plus faible. Comment pouvons-nous être pris au sérieux si nous expédions nos produits chimiques dangereux à l'étranger, empoisonnant ainsi les populations et la nature dans des pays où les règles de sécurité sont plus faibles et moins strictement appliquées ! L'interdiction d'exporter des pesticides toxiques serait une opportunité unique pour l'innovation et aiderait l'Europe et le monde à évoluer vers des méthodes de protection des plantes plus durables. Le maintien sur le marché de pesticides anciens et dangereux nous prive d'un avenir plus vert et de pratiques agricoles plus durables. Un avis juridique du Center for International Environmental Law publié en 2022 montre que les exportations européennes de pesticides interdits vers l'Afrique et l'Amérique centrale violent les obligations juridiques internationales de l'UE et le droit relatif aux droits humains.
englishfeedback: The ban on hazardous pesticides is necessary for the following reasons: The export of toxic pesticides reveals a double standard policy: hazardous pesticides are banned in Europe after being associated with cancer, reproductive problems and neurodegenerative diseases, as well as bee death. Some of these pesticides are even banned in Europe due to their link to brain damage in children and babies. If these pesticides are too dangerous for us, how can we authorise their export? The export of toxic pesticides is a human rights issue, as these pesticides are harmful to our health. Every year, thousands of farmers die as a result of excessive exposure to these hazardous pesticides. Exported pesticides are the subject of countless studies confirming their harmful effects on humans. The export of toxic pesticides is harmful to bees, biodiversity and the planet in general. The evidence is clear: neonics and other hazardous pesticides kill bees. This is why they are banned in Europe. Why do we still allow their export to countries with less stringent regulation, while they will continue to kill bees and decay biodiversity? The export of toxic pesticides benefits countries with less stringent regulation. The EU has a role to play in the world – its businesses should not be allowed to benefit from countries with weaker regulation. How can we be taken seriously if we send our dangerous chemicals abroad, poisoning people and nature in countries where safety rules are weaker and less strictly enforced! Banning the export of toxic pesticides would be a unique opportunity for innovation and would help Europe and the world to move towards more sustainable plant protection methods. Keeping old and dangerous pesticides on the market deprives us of a greener future and more sustainable agricultural practices. A legal opinion of the Center for International Environmental Law published in 2022 shows that European exports of banned pesticides to Africa and Central America violate the EU’s international legal obligations and human rights law.

Certains de ces pesticides sont même interdits en Europe en raison de leur lien avec des lésions cérébrales chez les enfants et les bébés à naître. englishfeedback: The export of toxic pesticides reveals a double standard policy: Hazardous pesticides are banned in Europe after being associated with cancers, reproductive problems and neurodegenerative diseases, as well as with the death of bees and other pollinators. Some of these pesticides are even banned in Europe because of their link to brain damage in children and born babies. If these pesticides are too dangerous for us, how can we authorise their export? The export of toxic pesticides is a human rights issue, as these pesticides are harmful to our health: Every year, thousands of farmers die as a result of excessive exposure to these hazardous pesticides. Exported pesticides are subject to countless studies confirming their adverse effects on humans. The export of toxic pesticides is harmful to bees, biodiversity and the planet in general. The evidence is clear: neonics and other hazardous pesticides kill bees. This is why they are banned in Europe. Why do we still allow their export to countries with less stringent regulation, while they will continue to kill bees and decay biodiversity? The export of toxic pesticides benefits countries with less stringent regulation. The EU has a role to play in the world – its businesses should not be allowed to benefit from countries with weaker regulation. How can we be taken seriously if we send our hazardous chemicals abroad, poisoning people and nature in countries where safety rules are weaker and less strictly enforced? Banning the export of toxic pesticides would be a unique opportunity for innovation and would help Europe and the world to move towards more sustainable plant protection methods. Keeping old and dangerous pesticides on the market deprives us of a greener future and more sustainable agricultural practices. A legal opinion of the Center for International Environmental Law published in 2022 shows that European exports of banned pesticides to Africa and Central America violate the EU’s international legal obligations and human rights law.
