L'exportation de pesticides toxiques est une question de droits humains , car ces pesticides sont nocifs pour notre santé : Chaque année, des milliers d'agriculteurs meurent des suites dune trop forte exposition à ces pesticides dangereux. Les pesticides exportés font l'objet d'innombrables études qui confirment leurs effets néfastes sur les humains. L'exportation de pesticides toxiques est néfaste pour les abeilles, la biodiversité et la planète en général. Les preuves sont claires : les néonics et autres pesticides dangereux tuent les abeilles. C'est pourquoi ils sont interdits en Europe. Pourquoi autorisons-nous encore leur exportation vers des pays où la réglementation est moins stricte, alors quils continueront de tuer les abeilles et décimer la biodiversité ? L'exportation de pesticides toxiques profite des pays où la réglementation est moins stricte. L'UE a un rôle à jouer dans le monde - ses entreprises ne devraient pas être autorisées à profiter des pays où la réglementation est plus faible. Comment pouvons-nous être pris au sérieux si nous expédions nos produits chimiques dangereux à l'étranger, empoisonnant ainsi les populations et la nature dans des pays où les règles de sécurité sont plus faibles et moins strictement appliquées ? L'interdiction d'exporter des pesticides toxiques serait une opportunité unique pour l'innovation et aiderait l'Europe et le monde à évoluer vers des méthodes de protection des plantes plus durables. Le maintien sur le marché de pesticides anciens et dangereux nous prive d'un avenir plus vert et de pratiques agricoles plus durables. Un avis juridique du Center for International Environmental Law publié en 2022 montre que les exportations européennes de pesticides interdits vers l'Afrique et l'Amérique centrale violent les obligations juridiques internationales de l'UE et le droit relatif aux droits humains.
englishfeedback: Thank you for your interest in this consultation on the European Commission’s export ban on hazardous pesticides. Here is the link to the Commission’s website – click ICI. And by clicking on this link you can watch a short explanatory video. Here are some reasons why we need to ban hazardous pesticides: The export of toxic pesticides reveals a double standard policy: Hazardous pesticides are banned in Europe after being associated with cancer, reproductive problems and neurodegenerative diseases, as well as bee death. Some of these pesticides are even banned in Europe because of their link to brain damage in children and born babies. If these pesticides are too dangerous for us, how can we authorise their export? The export of toxic pesticides is a human rights issue, as these pesticides are harmful to our health: Every year, thousands of farmers die as a result of excessive exposure to these hazardous pesticides. Exported pesticides are subject to countless studies confirming their adverse effects on humans. The export of toxic pesticides is harmful to bees, biodiversity and the planet in general. The evidence is clear: neonics and other hazardous pesticides kill bees. This is why they are banned in Europe. Why do we still allow their export to countries with less stringent regulation, while they will continue to kill bees and decay biodiversity? The export of toxic pesticides benefits countries with less stringent regulation. The EU has a role to play in the world – its businesses should not be allowed to benefit from countries with weaker regulation. How can we be taken seriously if we send our hazardous chemicals abroad, poisoning people and nature in countries where safety rules are weaker and less strictly enforced? Banning the export of toxic pesticides would be a unique opportunity for innovation and would help Europe and the world to move towards more sustainable plant protection methods. Keeping old and dangerous pesticides on the market deprives us of a greener future and more sustainable agricultural practices. A legal opinion of the Center for International Environmental Law published in 2022 shows that European exports of banned pesticides to Africa and Central America violate the EU’s international legal obligations and human rights law.

feedback: Sindical de Trabajadores Agrícolas, Bananeros y Campesinos (ASTAC) ha presentado un importante informe que apoya la prohibición de plaguicidas altamente peligrosos (HHP), que aún están siendo ampliamente utilizado en la industria agroalimentaria de Ecuador, a pesar de estar prohibido en la Unión Europea. El objetivo principal del informe es sacar a la luz los peligros del modelo de captura corporativa de los agronegocios. en Ecuador, tomando como ejemplo la cadena de suministro del banano y el doble rasero en el contexto de la gente del Sur Global. El informe destaca el hecho de que los pesticidas y sus metabolitos utilizados en el cultivo de banano en Ecuador puede persistir en el medio ambiente y en las cadenas de valor de los alimentos a través de la biomagnificación, lo que lleva a riesgos a largo plazo para la salud de los seres humanos y el ecosistema. El informe ha encontrado que 31 activos ingredientes clasificados como HHP se están utilizando en el cultivo de banano, con el 50% de ellos siendo fungicidas Diez de los fungicidas utilizados se aplican mediante fumigación aérea, entre ellos Mancozeb, que está clasificado como altamente tóxico para los humanos. A pesar de estar prohibido en la Unión Europea en 2020 debido a su toxicidad, su uso continúa en Ecuador, particularmente para el control de la Sigatoka Negra en plantaciones de banano A pesar de estar clasificados como HHP, ha habido un crecimiento sostenido en las importaciones y nacionales. producción de Mancozeb en Ecuador. Esto se debe a la comercialización y al aumento de la resistencia de los hongos para responder a la aplicación. Ha llevado a un aumento en la frecuencia de las fumigaciones aéreas, lo que expone a las comunidades y cuerpos de agua a la deriva primaria y secundaria causada por el rociado. El informe de la ASTAC también destaca el incumplimiento y la no implementación de los protocolos de fumigación debido a la falta de gobernanza e infraestructura. El informe ofrece un análisis crítico del modelo agroindustrial bananero en Ecuador, documentando la situación de los trabajadores, hombres y mujeres, así como de las comunidades afectadas por las fumigaciones aéreas. El informe pide la prohibición de los HHP en la industria agroindustrial de Ecuador mencionada en el informe, de granja para formar, con el fin de proteger la salud humana y el medio ambiente. El informe sugiere la importancia de implementar una gobernanza e infraestructura efectivas para garantizar el cumplimiento de protocolos establecidos, eliminando los dobles raseros. La salud y seguridad de las comunidades. afectados por la fumigación aérea debe ser una prioridad máxima, y la prohibición de los PAP debe considerarse como una paso crucial para lograrlo.
organization: Asociación Sindical de Trabajadores Agrícolas y Campesinos ASTAC
englishfeedback: A trade union of agricultural workers, banana workers and peasants (ASTAC) has submitted an important report supporting the ban on highly hazardous pesticides (HHP), which are still widely used in Ecuador’s agri-food industry, despite being banned in the European Union. The main objective of the report is to bring to light the dangers of the agricultural sector’s corporate capture model in Ecuador, taking as an example the banana supply chain and double standards in the context of the people of the Global South. The report highlights the fact that pesticides and their metabolites used in banana cultivation in Ecuador can persist in the environment and in food value chains through biomagnification, leading to long-term risks to human health and the ecosystem. The report found that 31 active ingredients classified as HHP are being used in banana cultivation, 50 % of which are fungicides Ten of the fungicides used are applied by aerial fumigation, including Mancozeb, which is classified as highly toxic to humans. Despite being banned in the European Union in 2020 due to its toxicity, its continued use in Ecuador, particularly for the control of Negra Sigatoka in banana plantations. Although it is classified as HHP, there has been sustained growth in imports and nationals.Mancozeb production in Ecuador has grown steadily. This is due to the commercialisation and increased resistance of fungi to respond to implementation. It has led to an increase in the frequency of aerial fumigations, exposing water communities and bodies to primary and secondary drift caused by spraying. The ASTAC report also highlights non-compliance and non-implementation of fumigation protocols due to a lack of governance and infrastructure. The report provides a critical analysis of the banana agro-industrial model in Ecuador, documenting the situation of workers, men and women, as well as the communities affected by aerial fumigations. The report calls for a ban on HHP in Ecuador’s agro-industrial industry mentioned in the report, farm to train, in order to protect human health and the environment. The report suggests the importance of implementing effective governance and infrastructure to ensure compliance with established protocols, eliminating double standards. Health and safety of communities affected by aerial fumigation should be a top priority, and the ban on PAPs should be seen as a crucial step towards achieving this.

feedback: Informe de análisis toxicológico de abejas muertas en Suc Tuc y Oxa, Hopelchén, Campeche Eric Vides Borrell1,2, Jaime González Tolentino1, Octavio Gaspar Ramírez3 y Rémy Vandame1 1 El Colegio de la Frontera Sur (ECOSUR), San Cristóbal de Las Casas, Chiapas 2 Consejo Nacional de Humanidades Ciencia y Tecnología (CONAHCYT) 3 Centro de Investigación y Asistencia en Tecnología y Diseño del Estado de Jalisco (CIATEJ), subsede Noreste 20 de mayo de 2023 Resumen Se presenta un análisis toxicológico realizado en el caso de la mortandad de abejas ocurrida en las comunidades de Suc Tuc y Oxa, Hopelchén, Campeche, a partir del 22 de marzo de 2023. Muestras de abejas, miel, polen y cera fueron recolectadas de 18 apiarios afectados en estas comunidades, las cuales fueron analizadas para residuos de fipronil y sus metabolitos. Los resultados arrojan que el 100 % de las muestras de abejas presentan residuos de fipronil a concentraciones que superan la dosis letal media (DL50), además de presentar residuos de sus metabolitos. Las otras muestras no presentan residuos de este compuesto. Los resultados indican la responsabilidad que el fipronil juega en la reciente intoxicación de abejas en Hopelchén y la posibilidad de una vía de intoxicación por contacto tras recientes fumigaciones.
organization: El Colegio de la Frontera Sur, Conahcyt
englishfeedback: Toxicological analysis report on dead bees in Suc Tuc and Oxa, Hopelchén, Campeche Eric Vides Borrell1,2, Jaime González Tolentino1, Octavio Gaspar Ramírez3 and Rémy Vandame1 1 The College of Southern Border (ECOSUR), San Cristóbal de Las Casas, Chiapas 2 National Council for Humanities Science and Technology (CONAHCYT) 3 Centre for Research and Assistance in Technology and Design of the State of Jalisco (CIATEJ), sub-site Noreste 20 May 2023 Summary presents a toxicological analysis for bee mortality in the communities Suc Tuc and Oxa, Hopelchén, Campeche, as of 22 March 2023. Samples of bees, honey, pollen and wax were collected from 18 affected apiaries in these communities, which were analysed for residues of fipronil and its metabolites. The results show that 100 % of bee samples present fipronil residues at concentrations exceeding the average lethal dose (LD50), as well as residues of their metabolites. The other samples do not show residues of this compound. The results indicate the responsibility of fipronil for the recent bee poisoning in Hopelchén and the possibility of a contact poisoning route following recent fumigations.

feedback: Giftige Pestizide sind ein Desaster für Bienen und andere Insekten, überhaupt für die biologische Vielfalt und unseren Planeten. Die Studienlage ist eindeutig: Neonics und andere giftige Pestizide vernichten Bienen als wichtige Bestäuber, und deshalb sind sie ja auch in Europa verboten. Warum sollten diese Gifte in andere Länder exportiert werden, in denen Gesundheitsvorschriften weniger streng sind und dann dort die Insekten und die biologische Vielfalt zerstören? Ja, das ist von hoher Doppelmoral: europäische Unternehmen suchen nun den Markt außerhalb Europas, um dort ihren Profit zu generieren. Kann denn Europa als integer und fortschrittlich wahrgenommen werden, wenn wir gefährliche Chemikalien ins Ausland verfrachten und dabei Mensch und Natur in Ländern vergiften, in denen Sicherheitsvorschriften geringer sind und weniger streng durchgesetzt werden? Kein Export gefährlicher Pestizide! Für eine nachhaltige, gesunde Landwirtschaft!
englishfeedback: Toxic pesticides are a disaster for bees and other insects, even for biodiversity and our planet. The study situation is clear: Neonics and other toxic pesticides destroy bees as important pollinators and are therefore also banned in Europe. Why should these poisons be exported to other countries where health rules are less stringent and then destroy insects and biodiversity there? Yes, this is high double: European companies are now looking for the market outside Europe to generate their profits there. Can Europe be perceived as an integer and progressive if we ship dangerous chemicals abroad, poisoning people and nature in countries where safety rules are lower and enforcement is less stringent? No export of hazardous pesticides! Towards sustainable, healthy agriculture!

feedback: Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, es ist unmoralisch in der EU gefährliche Chemikalien zu verbieten, sie aber Menschen in anderen Teilen der Welt zuzumuten. Letztendlich gelangen sie auch wieder in die EU. Damit macht sich die EU doppelt unglaubwürdig und schadet nicht nur ihrem Ansehen, sondern auch Mensch, Tier und Umwelt. Diese Chemikalien sind Gift für alle! Sie sollten nirgendwo hingelangen.
englishfeedback: Ladies and Gentlemen, it is immoral to ban dangerous chemicals in the EU, but to expect them to people in other parts of the world. Ultimately, they also return to the EU. This makes the EU twice unreliable and harms not only its reputation, but also human beings, animals and the environment. These chemicals are toxic for all! They should not travel anywhere.

feedback: Scientifique ( biologiste ), je suis fermement opposée à l'exportation de produits chimiques maintenant interdits dans l'UE en raison de leur toxicité avérée
englishfeedback: Scientific (biologist), I strongly oppose the export of chemicals now banned in the EU because of their proven toxicity

feedback: Ich fordere ein absolutes Exportverbot für giftige Pestizide.
englishfeedback: I call for an absolute ban on exports of toxic pesticides.

feedback: Ich fordere ein absolutes Exportverbot für giftige Pestizide
englishfeedback: I call for an absolute ban on exports of toxic pesticides

feedback: Diese Pestizide sind in Europa verboten, aber der Export ist erlaubt: Das ist eine Doppelmoral. Die gefährlichen Pestizide wurden in Europa verboten, nachdem sie mit Krebs, Beeinträchtigung der Fruchtbarkeit und neurodegenerativen Krankheiten in Verbindung gebracht wurden - zum Bienensterben tragen sie außerdem bei. Einige dieser Pestizide sind in Europa verboten, weil sie mit Hirnschäden bei Kindern und ungeborenen Babys in Verbindung gebracht werden. Wenn diese Pestizide für uns zu gefährlich sind: Wie können wir dann zulassen, dass sie exportiert werden? Die Ausfuhr von giftigen Pestiziden ist eine Frage der Menschenrechte, denn die Pestizide schaden den Menschen: Jedes Jahr sterben Tausende von Landwirt*innen durch den Kontakt mit gefährlichen Pestiziden. Es gibt unzählige Studien, die die schädlichen Auswirkungen der exportierten Pestizide auf den Menschen belegen. Die Ausfuhr giftiger Pestizide ist desaströs für Bienen, die biologische Vielfalt und den Planeten. Die Beweislage ist eindeutig: Neonics und andere giftige Pestizide töten Bienen. Deshalb sind sie in Europa verboten. Wir sollten nicht zulassen, dass diese Pestizide in Länder exportiert werden, in denen Gesundheitsvorschriften weniger streng sind und dort Bienen und die biologische Vielfalt zerstören. Länder, in denen es kaum Vorschriften für giftige Pestizide gibt, werden als Markt benutzt. Europäische Unternehmen sollten nicht die Möglichkeit haben, diesen Umstand auszunutzen. Wie kann Europa als Weltmacht ernst genommen werden, wenn wir gefährliche Chemikalien ins Ausland verschiffen und dabei Mensch und Natur in Ländern vergiften, in denen Sicherheitsvorschriften geringer sind und weniger streng durchgesetzt werden? Ein Exportverbot für giftige Pestizide würde Europa und der Welt helfen, zu nachhaltigeren Pflanzenschutzmethoden überzugehen. Wenn gefährliche Pestizide auf dem Markt bleiben, werden wir weiter auf eine grünere Zukunft und nachhaltige Landwirtschaft warten müssen. Ein Rechtsgutachten des Center for International Environmental Law, das 2022 veröffentlicht wurde, zeigt, dass die EU mit dem Export verbotener Pestizide nach Afrika und Mittelamerika gegen internationale rechtliche Verpflichtungen und die Menschenrechte verstößt.
englishfeedback: These pesticides are banned in Europe, but exports are allowed: This is a double standard. Hazardous pesticides have been banned in Europe after being associated with cancer, fertility impairment and neurodegenerative diseases and contribute to bee mortality. Some of these pesticides are banned in Europe because they are associated with brain damage in children and unborn babies. If these pesticides are too dangerous for us: How can we then allow them to be exported? The export of toxic pesticides is a human rights issue, as pesticides harm people: Every year thousands of farmers die from exposure to hazardous pesticides. There are countless studies demonstrating the harmful effects of exported pesticides on humans. Exports of toxic pesticides are desastrous for bees, biodiversity and the planet. The evidence is clear: Neonics and other toxic pesticides kill bees. This is why they are banned in Europe. We should not allow these pesticides to be exported to countries where health rules are less stringent and where bees and biodiversity are destroyed. Countries with little regulation on toxic pesticides are used as a market. European companies should not be able to take advantage of this fact. How can Europe be taken seriously as a global power when we ship dangerous chemicals abroad, poisoning people and nature in countries where safety rules are lower and enforcement is less stringent? A ban on exports of toxic pesticides would help Europe and the world move towards more sustainable plant protection practices. If hazardous pesticides remain on the market, we will have to wait for a greener future and sustainable agriculture. A legal opinion from the Center for International Environmental Law, published in 2022, shows that the EU is in breach of international legal obligations and human rights by exporting banned pesticides to Africa and Central America.

feedback: Ich fordere die EU-Kommission auf, ihre 2020 eingegangene Verpflichtung einzuhalten, "mit gutem Beispiel voranzugehen und sicherzustellen, dass in der EU verbotene gefährliche Chemikalien nicht für den Export hergestellt werden". Gesundheitsgefahren, welche die EU ihren Bürgern nicht zumuten will, sollte sie auch weltweit vermeiden - sonst macht sie sich unglaubwürdig.
englishfeedback: I call on the European Commission to honour its 2020 commitment to ‘lead by example and ensure that hazardous chemicals banned in the EU are not produced for export’. Health threats that the EU does not want to share with its citizens should also be avoided worldwide – otherwise it will make itself uncredible.

feedback: Sehr geehrte Verantwortungsträger in der EU-Kommision: es ist unerhört wichtig, dass giftige Chemikalien nicht in die Umwelt geraten. Sie hält nicht noch mehr davon aus! Darum sollte es selbstverständlich sein dass die Chemikalien die hier verboten sind nicht in andere Länder exportiert werden dürfen. Die Natur kennt keine Ländergrenzen. Es ist EINE ERDE auf def wir alle leben. EINE MENSCHHEIT, EINE TIERWELT, EINE PFLANZENWELT. Verbieten Sie deshalb den Export von giftigen Pestiziden! Mit freundlichen Grüssen Sabine Krüger
englishfeedback: Dear responsibilities in the EU Commission: it is undeniable that toxic chemicals do not enter the environment. It doesn’t stop it! It should therefore be self-evident that the chemicals which are prohibited here should not be exported to other countries. Nature does not know any borders. It is ONE ERDE on which we all live. HUMANITY, ANIMAL LIFE, PLANT LIFE. Therefore, ban the export of toxic pesticides! Yours sincerely, Sabine Krüger

feedback: Diese Pestizide sind in Europa verboten, aber der Export ist erlaubt. Das ist eine Doppelmoral. Länder, in denen es kaum Vorschriften gegen giftige Peatizide gibt, werden als Markt benutzt. Europäische Unternehmen und Konzerne sollten nicht die Möglichkeit haben, diesen Umstand auszunutzen. Wie kann Europa Vorreiter sein, wenn gefährliche Chemikalien ins außereuropäöische Ausland bzw. in Drittstaaten exportiert werden und dort Mensch und Natur schädigen. Ist die Umwelt in Afrika und Südamerika weniger schützenswert? Doch wohl kaum. Der Export von in der EU verbotenen Pestizuiden muss dringend unterbunden werden.
englishfeedback: These pesticides are banned in Europe, but exports are allowed. This is a double standard. Countries with little regulation against toxic pesticides are used as a market. European companies and groups should not be able to take advantage of this fact. How can Europe be a pioneer when hazardous chemicals are exported abroad and/or to third countries and harm people and nature there. Is the environment in Africa and South America less worthy of protection? But it is unlikely to be a good thing. There is an urgent need to stop exporting pestizuids banned in the EU.

feedback: BE would like to thank the Commission for the consultation on this initiative. Please find in the document attached to this feedback the BE position on each of the options evaluated in order to adopt a legislative measure prohibiting the export of chemicals banned in the European Union.
organization: Federal Public Service Health, Food Chain Safety and Environment
attachementDocumentIds: [{'documentId': '090166e5ff58de31', 'fileName': 'Prohibiting production for export chemicals banned - BE position.docx'}]

feedback: Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, es ist verantwortungs- und rücksichtslos, Chemikalien, die in der EU aus guten Gründen verboten sind, weiter herzustellen und in andere Länder auszuführen. Mensch und Natur außerhalb der EU damit zu schädigen empfinde ich als zutiefst unmoralisch. Außerdem kommen diese Stoffe mit Importen auch wieder in die zu uns zurück. Ich fordere Sie deshalb auf, diese Praxis unverzüglich zu beenden! Hochachtungsvoll, Dr. Andreas Lang
englishfeedback: Ladies and Gentlemen, it is irresponsible and irresponsible to further manufacture and export chemicals that are banned for good reasons in the EU. I consider it deeply immoral to harm human beings and nature outside the EU. In addition, these substances are also returned to us with imports. I therefore call on you to put an end to this practice without delay. Highly respected, Dr Andreas Lang

feedback: Es ist verantwortungs- und rücksichtslos Chemikalien, die in der EU aus guten Gründen verboten sind, weiter herzustellen und in andere Länder auszuführen. Mensch und Natur außerhalb damit zu schädigenden empfinde ich als zutiefst unmoralisch. Außerdem kommen diese Stoffe mit Importen auch wieder in die EU zurück. Ich fordere Sie auf, diese Praxis unverzüglich zu beenden!
englishfeedback: It is a responsible and reckless chemical that is banned in the EU for good reasons and continues to be manufactured and exported to other countries. I feel deeply immoral to harm human beings and nature outside. In addition, these substances are also returned to the EU with imports. I call on you to put an end to this practice without delay.

feedback: Federchimica supports the goals of the Chemical Strategy for Sustainability and the European Commissions underlying policy objective to improve human and environmental safety around the world. However, Federchimica believes that the Commissions document mainly refers to the export of those substances that do not comply with the regulatory requirements on human health, animal health or environmental protection. But there are also other reasons that can lead a substance to be banned at European level, such as economic reasons. Therefore, Federchimica believes it would be useful to carry out a socio-economic impact assessment to understand the implications that this ban could have on the European industries. Moreover, specific products are exported to fulfil specific needs in non-EU countries: banning their production and export would only result in a loss of turnover and jobs for European companies since such a ban would not be applicable to non-EU countries which would have a competitive advantage. Also, Federchimica assumes that this initiative is described in a way too general (e.g., prohibited substances) and is concerned that the public consultation mixes two very different scenarios, when proposing export bans of substances due to their hazardous properties and/or unacceptable risks to human health or the environment. Federchimica does not agree with an export ban for substances solely based on a hazard classification. Whether or not a hazardous substance poses an unacceptable risk depends on its use and can only be assessed by a risk assessment. It is also necessary to take into consideration the fact that chemical substances have hazardous characteristics due to their structure, but for this reason they are used to obtain materials that can have important uses for people's life quality. In conclusion, Federchimica encourages Europe, as a global leader in chemical policy, to export its well-established best practices in safety, risk assessment of chemical products, transparency and traceability by reviewing and improving the provisions of the PIC regulation. Finally, Federchimica suggests that the new restrictive measures, if introduced, should at least be accompanied by economic measures to support EU companies. More detailed considerations are available in the attached document.

Chemikalien, verboten in der EU, sollten keinesfalls exportiert werden. Unsere Verantwortung gilt hierbei nach innen und nach außen. Dies sollte auch für Chemikalien gelten, deren schädliche Wirkung sowohl medizinisch als auch für die Umwelt in der Diskussion und ungeklärt ist. Jegliche gegenteilige Auffassung halte ich für strikt unmoralisch.
englishfeedback: Chemicals banned in the EU should never be exported. Our responsibility lies both internally and externally. This should also apply to chemicals whose harmful effects are both medically and environmentally under discussion and unclear. Any contrary view seems to me to be strictly immoral.

feedback: Ein Verbot des Exports von in der EU nicht zugelassenen chemischen Erzeugnissenen (Pestizide und Herbizide) ist nicht nur in sich logisch und konsequent, sondern zwingend im Sinne des Geltungsanspruchs Europäischer Regeln und Bestimmungen über die EU-Außengrenzen hinaus geboten. Darüberhinaus bestünde durchaus die Gefahr, dass mithilfe dieser Chemikalien produzierte landwirtschaftliche Erzeugnisse (undeklariert) wieder in die EU eingeführt würden.
englishfeedback: A ban on the export of chemical products not authorised in the EU (pesticides and herbicides) is not only logical and consistent in itself, but is mandatory in line with the right to apply European rules and provisions beyond the EU’s external borders. There would also be a risk that agricultural products produced using these chemicals would be re-imported (declared) into the EU.

feedback: Die fraglichen Pestizide wurden in Europa verboten, nachdem sie mit Krebs, Beeinträchtigung der Fruchtbarkeit und neurodegenerativen Krankheiten, Hirnschäden bei Kindern und ungeborenen Babys in Verbindung gebracht wurden. Es ist inzwischen wissenschaftlich umfangreich nachgewiesen, dass Neonics und andere giftige Pestizide Bienen töten und zum Insektensterben erheblich beitragen. Insekten, vor allem Bienen, sind für die Landwirtschaft zwingend erforderlich und daher zu schützen. Die Ausfuhr giftiger Pestizide nimmt die Zerstörung der biologischen Vielfalt und damit folglich die Zerstörung von Flora und Fauna wissentlich in Kauf. Das ist verwerflich. Es darf nicht sein, dass krankmachende und zerstörerische Pestizide in Nicht EU-Länder exportiert werden dürfen, in denen Gesundheitsvorschriften weniger streng sind und dort die biologische Vielfalt zerstören. Die Ausfuhr von giftigen Pestiziden ist eine Frage der Menschenrechte, denn die Pestizide schaden den Menschen: Jedes Jahr sterben Tausende von Landwirt*innen durch den Kontakt mit gefährlichen Pestiziden. Es gibt unzählige Studien, die die schädlichen Auswirkungen der exportierten Pestizide auf den Menschen belegen. Ein Rechtsgutachten des Center for International Environmental Law, das 2022 veröffentlicht wurde, zeigt, dass die EU mit dem Export verbotener Pestizide nach Afrika und Mittelamerika gegen internationale rechtliche Verpflichtungen und die Menschenrechte verstößt. Über den Import von Lebensmitteln und Pflanzen kommen diese Pestizide wieder zu uns nach Europa zurück und setzen ihre zerstörerische Arbeit fort (zB nachgewiesene Pestizidbelastung bei Blumen). Der wirtschaftliche Schaden, der durch den wissentlich zerstörerischen Einsatz von Pestiziden hervorgerufen wird, wird von der Weltgemeinschaft nicht mehr aufgefangen werden können, wenn nicht ein klares Verbot ausgesprochen wird. Der vermeindliche Vorteil des Pestizideinsatzes ist lokal und von kurzer Dauer - der globale wirtschaftliche Schaden steht jedoch in keinem Verhältnis zum kurzzeitigen Vorteil des Einsatzes von Pestiziden. Durch wirtschaftliche Beziehungen werden in Folge des Pesizideinsatzes außerhalb der EU (zB Reimport von belasteten Produkten, Resistenzen gg. Pestizide, Vernichtung von Insekten, Verwehung von Pestiziden) auch die Bürger*innen der EU mittelbar geschädigt. Daher ist ein Verbot des Exportes aus Gründen der Menschenrechte, des Naturschutzes und des Schutzes der Bürger*innen der EU zwingend erforderlich. Ich gehe sogar so weit zu fordern, dass Produkte, auf denen nicht erlaubte Pestizide nachgewiesen werden, in der EU nicht verkauft werden dürfen.
englishfeedback: The pesticides in question were banned in Europe after being associated with cancer, fertility impairment and neurodegenerative diseases, brain damage in children and unborn babies. There is now extensive scientific evidence that Neonics and other toxic pesticides kill bees and contribute significantly to insect mortality. Insects, especially bees, are essential for agriculture and are therefore to be protected. The export of toxic pesticides knowingly accepts the destruction of biodiversity and consequently the destruction of flora and fauna. This is reprehensible. It must not be possible for sick and destructive pesticides to be exported to non-EU countries where health rules are less stringent and where biodiversity is destroyed. The export of toxic pesticides is a human rights issue, as pesticides harm people: Every year thousands of farmers die from exposure to hazardous pesticides. There are countless studies demonstrating the harmful effects of exported pesticides on humans. A legal opinion from the Center for International Environmental Law, published in 2022, shows that the EU is in breach of international legal obligations and human rights by exporting banned pesticides to Africa and Central America. Through the import of food and plants, these pesticides return to Europe and continue their destructive work (e.g. evidence of pesticide contamination in flowers). The economic damage caused by the knowingly destructive use of pesticides will no longer be compensated by the global community unless a clear ban is imposed. The expected advantage of pesticide use is local and short-term, but the global economic damage is disproportionate to the short-term benefit of pesticide use. As a result of the use of pesicide outside the EU, economic relationships (e.g. reimportation of contaminated products, resistance, etc.) Pesticides, destruction of insects, disposal of pesticides), including indirect damage to EU citizens. A ban on exports on grounds of human rights, nature protection and the protection of EU citizens is therefore imperative. I even go so far as to insist that products on which unauthorised pesticides are detected cannot be sold in the EU.

feedback: BAYER = capitalist smelling nasty money!

It´s non-ethical to export hazardous chemicals banned in the EU because these chemicals harm people, biodiversity and environmental media! Low income countries are especially at risk due to limited resources for a safe management of those chemicals, which are prohibited for good reasons. I strongly support the initiative to stop these exports which will help to protect the environment and populations at risk. We must strive for safer alternatives and develop further methods to still have good agricultural yields. Prof. Dr. Andreas Schaeffer

Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, bitte setzten Sie sich für ein Verbot der Herstellung und/oder Ausfuhr bestimmter, in der EU verbotener gefährlicher Chemikalien ein. Mit dem Ziel auch Drittländer vor den abträglichen Auswirkungen dieser Chemikalien auf die menschliche Gesundheit und die Umwelt zu schützen Vielen Dank vorab.
englishfeedback: Ladies and Gentlemen, please call for a ban on the production and/or export of certain hazardous chemicals banned in the EU. With the aim of protecting third countries from the adverse effects of these chemicals on human health and the environment, thank you very much in advance.

feedback: Ein Rechtsgutachten des Center for International Environmental Law, das 2022 veröffentlicht wurde, zeigt, dass die EU mit dem Export verbotener Pestizide nach Afrika und Mittelamerika gegen internationale rechtliche Verpflichtungen und die Menschenrechte verstößt. Ich bitte Sie daher dringend sich für ein schon längstens fälliges Exportverbot ein zu setzten. Merci vielmals!
englishfeedback: A legal opinion from the Center for International Environmental Law, published in 2022, shows that the EU is in breach of international legal obligations and human rights by exporting banned pesticides to Africa and Central America. I would therefore ask you urgently to advocate a ban on exports which is already due at the earliest. Merci’s many times!

feedback: Es wäre eine gefährliche Doppelmoral, wenn die EU erlaubt, dass hier verbotene Giftstoffe ins Ausland verkauft werden und dort Schaden anrichten dürfen, der schlussendlich uns alle wieder trifft. Es gibt jetzt schon viel zu wenige Insekten und ganz besonders die wichtigen Honigbienen. Es ist jetzt an der Zeit, dass wir Rückgrat beweisen und zu unseren Werten stehen. Alles Andere ist bullshit und Heuchelei. Alles Liebe
englishfeedback: It would be dangerous double morality if the EU allowed banned toxic substances to be sold abroad and to cause damage there, which ultimately hits all of us again. There are already far too few insects and especially important honeybees. It is now time to show our backbone and stand by our values. Everything else is bullshit and hay. All love

feedback: Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, ein Exportverbot von hier verbotenen Pestiziden und Chemikalien ist überfällig, und ich wünsche mir sehr, dass dieses Gesetz durchkommt. Alles andere wären peinliche Doppelstandards, die die EU auf internationaler Ebene diskreditieren. Pestizide töten Lebewesen, das ist ihr Zweck. Seit mehr als 10.000 Jahren gibt es menschliche Landwirtschaft, die ohne Gifte auskommt. Und wenn wir als Menschheit weitere 10.000 Jahre leben wollen, müssen wir diese gefährlichen Stoffe aus der Welt schaffen. Sie schaden allen Beteiligten: Menschen, Tieren, Pflanzen, Klima, Artenvielfalt. Die Chemieindustrie behauptet gern, die Ernährungssicherheit wäre nur mit ihren Produkten gewährleistet. Das Gegenteil stimmt. Pestizide machen Bauern und Landwirtinnen abhängig, schaden ihnen gesundheitlich und finanziell. Biointensivkulturen zeigen: Auf kleinstem Raum sind hohe Erträge möglich. Auf ganz natürlich Weise. Freundlichst: Dr. Ute Scheub
englishfeedback: Ladies and Gentlemen, a ban on exports of pesticides and chemicals banned here is overdue and I very much wish this law to be enforced. Anything else would be bogus double standards that the EU discredits at international level. Pesticides kill living organisms, which is their purpose. Human farming has been in place for more than 10.000 years without poisoning. And if we want to live as humanity for another 10.000 years, we need to remove these dangerous substances from the world. They harm all parties involved: Humans, animals, plants, climate, biodiversity. The chemical industry would like to claim that only its products would ensure food security. The opposite is true. Pesticides make farmers dependent, harm their health and finances. Biointensive crops show: High yields are possible in the smallest space. In a very natural way. Kindly: Dr Ute Scheub

feedback: Der Planet brennt und gleichzeitig ertinkt er! Um sicherzugehen, dass er endgültig verwüstet, hören wir nicht auf ihn zu vergiften (wenn nicht bei uns, dann anderswo), und das mit dem perfiden Argument, die Menschheit nicht anders ernähren zu können. Wann ist endlich Schluss mit unserer kranken Ökonomie, die den Ast absägt auf dem wir sitzen? Ich fordere Sie auf, alles zu tun, diesen Trend zu stoppen, und immer das Paradigma 'mit der Natur statt gegen sie' bei all Ihren Überlegungen und Entscheidungen zugrunde zu legen. Das sind wir unseren Nachkommen und der gesamten Mitwelt schuldig. Vielen Dank in voraus.
englishfeedback: The planet burns while inking! In order to make sure that he is finally devastated, we do not listen to him (if not with us, then elsewhere) with the perfidence argument that humanity cannot be fed otherwise. When can we finally conclude with our sick economy, which is sawing the thing on which we are sitting? I call on you to do everything possible to stop this trend and always use the paradigm ‘with nature rather than against them’ in all your thoughts and decisions. We owe this to our descendants and to the wider world. Thank you in advance.

feedback: We all have for a long time heard about the crises of art extinction especially concerning the bees. Bees are central also for our own survival. So please make a responsible and wise decision for the globe and mankind: Prohibit production for export of chemicals banned in the European union and continue banning new hazardous chemicals. Yours Elisabet Näsman, professor emerita and grandmother of Max, Linus, Kai and Tor

Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, die Umweltzerstörung hat ein Ausmaß angenommen, welches für die Pflanzen- und Tierwelt aber auch für den Menschen bedrohlich ist. Die Artenvielfalt in allen Bereichen ist extrem zurück gegangen und vielen Tierarten fehlt die Nahrung, weil es immer weniger Insekten gibt. Das die Chemie ein wesentlicher Verursacher für diese Problematik ist, wurde nun mehrfach durch viele Studien belegt und auch deshalb sind bei uns in Europa viele Chemikalien in der Landwirtschaft verboten. Es kann und darf nicht sein, dass dann diese Chemikalien weiterhin ungehindert ins Ausland verkauft werden dürfen. Diese Praxis muss unbedingt gestoppt werden, denn die Erhaltung einer lebenswerten Natur ist eine internationale Aufgabe die nicht an den Grenzen Europas aufhört. Ich fordere Sie auf diese doppelmoralige Praxis umgehend zu beenden und sich für ein Exportverbot und internationales Herstellungsverbot dieser Chemikalien einzusetzen!! Mit freundlichem Gruß
englishfeedback: Ladies and gentlemen, environmental degradation has reached an extent that is threatening both for plant and animal life and for humans. Biodiversity has been extremely declining in all areas and many animal species lack food as insects are decreasing. The fact that chemistry is a major source of this problem has now been confirmed on several occasions by many studies and that is why many agricultural chemicals are banned in Europe. It cannot and must not be allowed to continue to sell these chemicals abroad without hindrance. It is essential to stop this practice, as preserving a life-worthy nature is an international task that does not stop at Europe’s borders. I call on you to put an end to this dual practice as soon as possible and to advocate a ban on exports and international production of these chemicals. Best regards

feedback: THE PIC REGULATION SHOULD BE RETAINED UNCHANGED 1) The EU pesticide system is unusually severe. Most pesticides that are banned in the EU are pesticides that have previously been approved. Those that are banned may have failed EU risk assessments or been found to have data gaps during the review. The EU system is very strict as it is not allowed to provide additional studies to fill data gaps that may have been raised during the review. This difference explains why many pesticides banned in the EU continue to be approved in comparable countries. eg Diquat banned in the EU, approved in Australia and the USA (27 PIC export notifications in 2021) Thiram banned in the EU, approved in Australia, Canada and the USA (532 PIC notifications in 2021) Permethrin not approved in the EU, approved in Australia, Canada (621 PIC notifications in 2021). Permethrin was not banned in the EU it simply wasnt registered; the manufacturer had more profitable options. The EU review involves the evaluation of a small number (typically 2 or 3) representative uses. These uses may not represent the full spectrum of possible uses and application rates that could be available for that substance in the EU. Due to the inflexibility of the EU system, if the representative uses do not pass the risk assessment or have data gaps, ALL the uses are withdrawn. There is no possibility to save uses that might pass risk assessment, not have data gaps, or could have a label change that would allow them to pass. The EU system also includes rigid (and arbitrary) limits on the amount of pesticide that can be allowed in groundwater. The EU groundwater limit is not risk based and is not shared outside the EU, but is one of the main reasons pesticides are banned in the EU. It is wrong for the EU to impose its system on non EU countries by the application of EU rules to them, as a secondary consequence of the withdrawal of PIC. By withdrawing PIC the EU would be effectively applying its system to third countries that could be more flexible in their approach.The EU does not necessarily know best and it is over-reach to apply its system to others without them being able to mitigate the effects by taking their own decisions. It is also wrong of the EU to think that it can decide for other non-EU countries what pesticides they can and cannot have, on the assumption that they are unable to decide for themselves. Its condescending and high handed of the EU to impose its system on third countries by withdrawing PIC. 2) The EU system includes safeguards for EU agriculture which ending PIC takes away from outside countries. The EU system (Regulation 1107/2009) includes concepts such as EMERGENCY USE (art 53) and ESSENTIAL USE (art 4.5) as safety nets in case there is an over-riding need for a pesticide that has been banned. Cancelling the availability of pesticides to third countries by ending PIC means that these countries may have no safety net. Pesticides will suddenly become non-available, and while EU farmers are protected from changes in the availability of pesticides by the two concepts above, farmers in third countries will have no such protection. Its wrong of the EU, by ending PIC to effectively ban pesticides needed by third countries, denying their farmers the safeguards that are provided for EU farmers. 3) Risk Assessment Considerations are Different between EU and non-EU States.The EU system considers the Risk of a pesticide in the setting of EU Agricultural conditions. Conditions in other countries are often quite different (for example in tropical versus temperate crops). Crops and pest pressure are different.4) In many cases the effect achieved will not be as expected. Third country farmers faced unable to obtain pesticides from EU producers are likely to turn to the same pesticides produced to lower standards outside the EU. EU jobs will be lost but the intended effect will not be achieved.

ECA appreciates the Commissions efforts to reduce the use and risk of pesticides containing hazardous active substances, even beyond its borders, as outlined in the European Green Deal, the Farm to Fork strategy and the Chemicals Strategy for Sustainability. Even if they are prohibited in the EU, the production and export of these hazardous substances may lead to raw materials produced in non-EU countries and commercialised in the EU ultimately containing residues of toxic substances. Even if these residues are low and still permitted in the EU through the different official Maximum Residue Limits (MRLs), they increase consumers exposure to hazardous chemicals. As such, we strongly support this initiative. To ensure high food quality and consumer safety, while minimising potential temporary market disruptions that might emerge as a consequence of such an important legal instrument, ECA would like to underline the following points: - We welcome the initiative to prohibit the production of hazardous substances that are currently forbidden in the EU but exported to non-EU countries. The use of these plant protection products in non-EU countries results in products that are imported to the EU for consumption potentially being contaminated with toxic substances. Thus, banning the export of these products would be highly beneficial for EU consumers from a food safety point of view. - Yet, it is important to incentivise the use of sustainable, affordable, and safe alternatives to the hazardous chemicals to be banned for export. Therefore, we call on the Commission to pursue its dialogue with non-EU countries to define accompanying measures and adequate solutions to ensure a smooth transition and minimise possible market disruptions during the phase-out of these hazardous chemicals. - We consider that producers in non-EU countries need an appropriate transition period and support to phase-out these hazardous chemicals. The International Cocoa Organization (ICCO) estimates that between 30% and 40% of cocoa production losses in major cocoa growing nations are caused by pest and disease infestation , which illustrates the essential role that pesticides play. - Furthermore, it is important to keep in mind that, even if this initiative creates a precedent at a global level and reinforces the reliability and credibility of EU products, other non-EU countries will still produce hazardous chemicals and export them to other third countries. For this reason, we strongly urge the European Commission to consider complementary actions to discourage the production of hazardous chemicals at a global level.
attachementDocumentIds: [{'documentId': '090166e5ff55ef6f', 'fileName': '20230727 - ECA reply to consultation - Ban on pesticides produced in EU for export -final.pdf'}]

feedback: As an ecotoxicologist and environmental chemist I can't believe that we have to discuss about this question. I support this initiative very much. Exporting hazardous chemicals banned in the EU is unethical and contradicts human rights principles as well as the Sustainable Development Goals. Millions of acute poisonings (for example due to pesticides) occur annually in low- and middle-income countries due to inadequate management. The United Nations recognizes the unsound management of chemicals and waste as a threat to human rights, particularly affecting vulnerable populations. Many countries outside the EU lack proper chemical management systems, making them less equipped to handle banned chemicals exported from the EU. Stopping these exports would protect the environment, biodiversity, and at-risk populations, while promoting safer alternatives and in addition give us as the European Union more credibility. Replacing hazardous pesticides with cost-effective options benefits health, environment, and biodiversity without harming crop yields.
Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, Stoffe, die wegen ihrer tödlichen Folgen in der EU verboten sind, sollten auch nicht in andere Länder exportiert werden. Mit freundlichen Grüßen Ursula Wingert
englishfeedback: Ladies and Gentlemen, substances banned in the EU because of their lethal effects should not be exported to other countries either. Yours sincerely, Ursula Wingert

feedback: As K+S, we provide the agriculture market with highly efficient fertilizing products contributing to crop health and food security. At the same time, we set high standards for all our products and their environmental impacts in line with the high regulatory standards established in the EU. While in general we deem a sound information basis necessary for everyone to make reasonable decisions on which products to use, we have some concerns with the policy options proposed by the EU Commission for the revision of the PIC Regulation. First of all, as the EUs implementation of the UN convention, the PIC Regulation should always be based on the principles of the UN convention. More than 160 contracting parties agreed on these fundamental principles and rules. Single-handed, one-sided deviations by the EU may significantly harm the well-established and efficient information system and global trading cooperations. Additionally, it would patronize many countries and disrupt the level playing field. Therefore, we highly encourage to strive for a global solution. However, instead of promoting amendments on the Rotterdam Convention contributing to higher safety levels worldwide, the EU Commission proposes several one-sided policy options. With the limited information available yet, it is challenging to assess the impact each option would have. Further clarification and definitions are highly necessary. For example, it is not clear what the policy option to introduce production prohibitions for chemical not approved or prohibited for placing on the market and/or use in the EU shall cover. Production bans should generally only be considered as a measure of last resort. There are several reasons possible why a substance or mixture may not be placed on EU market, not all of them basing of insufficient ways to handle them safely. Additionally, the revision of the REACH Regulation, EUs main regulation dealing with chemicals restrictions and prohibitions, is still on-going. The proposed extension of the generic approach to risk management (GRA) would lead to much higher numbers of restricted chemicals. If all these chemicals would become subject to the PIC Regulation, the bureaucratic burden for exporting companies would increase tremendously bringing EUs industry in disadvantage. At the same time, a benefit for human health or the environment may be doubted as the GRA restrictions shall be solely based on the hazard profile and shall not consider even simplest means to handle these hazards safely which may also be applied in third countries. Especially when dealing in the agricultural sector, prohibitions of specific products may directly reflect on crop yields and/or food prizing. On one hand, there may be no suitable alternative leading to lower crop yields and in consequence to shortages and/or increasing prizes for agricultural products. On the other hand, professional users might be forced to switch to alternative products coming from countries with lower standards regarding product safety, occupational health, and productions impact on the environment than the EU. This may lead in the end to higher risks for users and bigger adverse effects on the environment. This would be directly contradicting to the PIC Regulations and Rotterdam Conventions general goal! The PIC Regulation is a suitable and powerful tool to implement worldwide standards. Instead of one-sided hampering with the established system and potentially causing severe trade disruptions and regrettable product substitutions, the EU should promote further improvements at the UN level. For these reasons, we strongly urge to refrain from any generic prohibitions but consider other, less limiting, and more inclusive policy options.

Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, diese Pestizide sind in Europa verboten, aber der Export ist erlaubt? Das ist eine Doppelmoral die es gewaltig in sich hat. Die Ausfuhr giftiger Pestizide ist desaströs für Bienen, die biologische Vielfalt und den Planeten, egal in welchem Land, deshalb muss der Export verboten werden, eigentlich müsste ein Herstellungsverbot eingeführt werden. Ein minimal Ziel sollte das Verbot sein. Ein Exportverbot für giftige Pestizide würde Europa und der Welt helfen, zu nachhaltigeren Pflanzenschutzmethoden überzugehen, deshalb Schluss damit ohne Hintertür für die Lobbyisten der Chemiebrache. Mit freundlichen Grüßen
englishfeedback: Ladies and Gentlemen, these pesticides are banned in Europe but export is allowed? This is a double morale that it has tremendously in itself. Exports of toxic pesticides are disastrous for bees, biodiversity and the planet, irrespective of the country in which they are exported, so exports must be banned and a production ban should be introduced. The ban should be a minimal objective. A ban on exports of toxic pesticides would help Europe and the world to move towards more sustainable plant protection practices, thus ending without a back door for the lobbyists of the chemical fallow. [Complimentary close]

feedback: Sehr geehrte Menschen in der Europäischen Kommission, Ich stimme für ein Verbot von Herstellung und Ausfuhr von Chemikalien ( wie Pestiziden u. a. ), die in Europa verboten sind. Was uns schadet, soll auch anderen nicht schaden. Vielen Dank, Dagmar Jessen
englishfeedback: Dear people in the European Commission, I am in favour of banning the production and export of chemicals (such as pesticides, etc.) that are banned in Europe. What harms us is not to the detriment of others. Thank you, Dagmar Jessen

feedback: Voici quelques raisons pour lesquelles nous avons besoin dinterdire les pesticides dangereux : L'exportation de pesticides toxiques révèle une politique de deux poids deux mesures : Les pesticides dangereux sont interdits en Europe après avoir été associés à des cancers, des problèmes de reproduction et des maladies neurodégénératives, ainsi qu'à la mort des abeilles. Certains de ces pesticides sont même interdits en Europe en raison de leur lien avec des lésions cérébrales chez les enfants et les bébés à naître. Si ces pesticides sont trop dangereux pour nous, comment pouvons-nous autoriser leur exportation ? L'exportation de pesticides toxiques est une question de droits humains , car ces pesticides sont nocifs pour notre santé : Chaque année, des milliers d'agriculteurs meurent des suites dune trop forte exposition à ces pesticides dangereux. Les pesticides exportés font l'objet d'innombrables études qui confirment leurs effets néfastes sur les humains. L'exportation de pesticides toxiques est néfaste pour les abeilles, la biodiversité et la planète en général. Les preuves sont claires : les néonics et autres pesticides dangereux tuent les abeilles. C'est pourquoi ils sont interdits en Europe. Pourquoi autorisons-nous encore leur exportation vers des pays où la réglementation est moins stricte, alors quils continueront de tuer les abeilles et décimer la biodiversité ? L'exportation de pesticides toxiques profite des pays où la réglementation est moins stricte. L'UE a un rôle à jouer dans le monde - ses entreprises ne devraient pas être autorisées à profiter des pays où la réglementation est plus faible. Comment pouvons-nous être pris au sérieux si nous expédions nos produits chimiques dangereux à l'étranger, empoisonnant ainsi les populations et la nature dans des pays où les règles de sécurité sont plus faibles et moins strictement appliquées ? L'interdiction d'exporter des pesticides toxiques serait une opportunité unique pour l'innovation et aiderait l'Europe et le monde à évoluer vers des méthodes de protection des plantes plus durables. Le maintien sur le marché de pesticides anciens et dangereux nous prive d'un avenir plus vert et de pratiques agricoles plus durables. Un avis juridique du Center for International Environmental Law publié en 2022 montre que les exportations européennes de pesticides interdits vers l'Afrique et l'Amérique centrale violent les obligations juridiques internationales de l'UE et le droit relatif aux droits humains.
englishfeedback: Here are some reasons why we need to ban hazardous pesticides: The export of toxic pesticides reveals a double standard policy: Hazardous pesticides are banned in Europe after being associated with cancer, reproductive problems and neurodegenerative diseases, as well as bee death. Some of these pesticides are even banned in Europe because of their link to brain damage in children and born babies. If these pesticides are too dangerous for us, how can we authorise their export? The export of toxic pesticides is a human rights issue, as these pesticides are harmful to our health: Every year, thousands of farmers die as a result of excessive exposure to these hazardous pesticides. Exported pesticides are subject to countless studies confirming their adverse effects on humans. The export of toxic pesticides is harmful to bees, biodiversity and the planet in general. The evidence is clear: neonics and other hazardous pesticides kill bees. This is why they are banned in Europe. Why do we still allow their export to countries with less stringent regulation, while they will continue to kill bees and decay biodiversity? The export of toxic pesticides benefits countries with less stringent regulation. The EU has a role to play in the world – its businesses should not be allowed to benefit from countries with weaker regulation. How can we be taken seriously if we send our hazardous chemicals abroad, poisoning people and nature in countries where safety rules are weaker and less strictly enforced? Banning the export of toxic pesticides would be a unique opportunity for innovation and would help Europe and the world to move towards more sustainable plant protection methods. Keeping old and dangerous pesticides on the market deprives us of a greener future and more sustainable agricultural practices. A legal opinion of the Center for International Environmental Law published in 2022 shows that European exports of banned pesticides to Africa and Central America violate the EU’s international legal obligations and human rights law.

feedback: AEPLA, Asociación Empresarial para la Protección de las Plantas, representa a empresas que fabrican productos fitosanitarios químicos en España, algunos de los cuales se exportan a terceros países, y son susceptibles de verse afectados por una potencial prohibición. Previo a la elaboración de una propuesta legislativa por parte de la Comisión Europea, solicitamos una reflexión profunda sobre si una prohibición sería la mejor manera de lograr los objetivos planteados, en concreto: proteger a los países no pertenecientes a la UE de sus efectos negativos en la salud humana y el medio ambiente y, por otro lado, armonizar la política interior y la exterior, reforzando la posición internacional de la UE. Respecto a la protección de terceros países evitando la exportación de químicos prohibidos en Europa, esta propuesta no tiene en cuenta las necesidades específicas en materia de sanidad vegetal que pueden existir fuera de Europa. Debido a que las circunstancias climáticas y agronómicas son diferentes, también lo son las enfermedades y plagas a las que deben enfrentarse y por este motivo, terceros países deberían disponer de soluciones fitosanitarias que se producen en Europa, aunque aquí no sean necesarias. El ámbito y alcance de la potencial prohibición también debería ser definido teniendo en cuenta el impacto en los productos fitosanitarios. La prohibición de exportación a terceros países de los químicos no autorizados en Europa podría incluir sustancias activas fitosanitarias cuyo uso se encuentra permitido para la salud humana o animal a nivel global. Además, no solo existen en el caso de los fitosanitarios sustancias prohibidas expresamente, también aquellas que no se han registrado o presentado a renovación en Europa por diferentes motivos y que desde nuestro punto de vista no deberían ser objeto de esta prohibición. En cualquier caso, consideramos que la prohibición no es la manera de hacer frente a estos objetivos. Tampoco contribuiría a la armonización a nivel global en el uso de químicos, ya que en la UE, algunas sustancias se prohíben por criterios de peligro cuando en otros países están autorizadas porque la autorización se basa en evaluación de riesgos. Además, una prohibición así también podría llegar a impedir o convertirse en barrera para que la innovación y las mejoras tecnológicas que existen fuera de Europa no lleguen aquí. Nuestra propuesta es la mejora y el fortalecimiento del marco legislativo existente. En la actualidad disponemos de un sistema implementado, el Reglamento 649/2012 EU PIC (Prior Informed Consent) con potenciales áreas de mejora que deberían explorarse en primer lugar. Consideramos que la mejora normativa permite una mejor adaptación a circunstancias cambiantes y en este caso, la prohibición no tendría una base o sustento científico. Para concluir, una prohibición general podría tener un impacto en la competitividad a nivel europeo y también directo en nuestro sector puesto que en la UE producimos muchas de las soluciones que se exportan y cuya vocación es ofrecer innovación y tecnología al mundo entero. La decisión de fabricación de un producto fitosanitario se basa en criterios económicos y estrictamente empresariales y su localización produce sin duda, una importante contribución a la economía del país. Una prohibición de exportación de productos químicos como la que se está planteando podría tener consecuencias en relación con la deslocalización de nuestras fábricas y el empleo, por ejemplo, en nuestro país empresas que forman parte de AEPLA, producen fitosanitarios químicos y también semilla tratada cuyo destino son terceros países y se verían seriamente afectadas por esta prohibición.
englishfeedback: AEPLA, Asociación Empresarial para la Protección de las Plantas, represents companies manufacturing chemical plant protection products in Spain, some of which are exported to third countries and may be affected by a potential ban. Prior to the drafting of a legislative proposal by the European Commission, we call for an in-depth reflection on whether a ban would be the best way to achieve the objectives set out, namely: protect non-EU countries from their negative effects on human health and the environment and, on the other hand, harmonise internal and external policies, strengthening the EU’s international position. With regard to the protection of third countries by preventing the export of banned chemicals in Europe, this proposal does not take into account the specific plant health needs that may exist outside Europe. Because the climatic and agronomic circumstances are different, the diseases and pests they face are also different and for this reason, third countries should have plant health solutions that occur in Europe, even if they are not needed here. The scope and scope of the potential ban should also be defined taking into account the impact on plant protection products. The export ban to third countries of chemicals not authorised in Europe could include plant protection active substances the use of which is permitted for human or animal health globally. Furthermore, there are not only plant protection substances that are expressly prohibited, including those that have not been registered or submitted for renewal in Europe for different reasons and which, in our view, should not be subject to this prohibition. In any case, we consider that the prohibition is not the way to address these objectives. It would also not contribute to global harmonisation in the use of chemicals, as in the EU, some substances are banned on the basis of hazard criteria when in other countries they are authorised because authorisation is based on risk assessment. Moreover, such a ban could also prevent or become a barrier for innovation and technological improvements outside Europe not to come here. Our proposal is to improve and strengthen the existing legislative framework. We now have an implemented system, Regulation (EU) No 649/2012 (Prior Informed Consent), with potential areas for improvement that should be explored first. We consider that better regulation allows for a better adaptation to changing circumstances and, in this case, the ban would not have a scientific basis or support. To conclude, a general ban could have an impact on competitiveness at European level and also directly in our sector, since in the EU we produce many of the solutions that are exported and which aim to provide innovation and technology to the world. The decision to manufacture a plant protection product is based on economic and strictly business criteria and its location undoubtedly makes an important contribution to the economy of the country. An export ban on chemicals such as the one under consideration could have consequences in relation to the relocation of our factories and employment, for example in our country, which are part of AEPLA, produce chemical plant protection products and also treated seeds destined for third countries and will be seriously affected by this ban.
attachementDocumentIds: [{'documentId': '090166e5ff548b65', 'fileName': 'Contribución AEPLA Consulta Pública CE - Export Ban.pdf'}]

feedback: Diese Pestizide sind in Europa verboten, aber der Export ist erlaubt: Das ist eine Doppelmoral. Die Ausfuhr giftiger Pestizide ist desaströs für Bienen, die biologische Vielfalt und den Planeten. Ein Exportverbot für giftige Pestizide würde Europa und der Welt helfen, zu nachhaltigeren Pflanzenschutzmethoden überzugehen.
englishfeedback: These pesticides are banned in Europe, but exports are allowed: This is a double standard. Exports of toxic pesticides are desastrous for bees, biodiversity and the planet. A ban on exports of toxic pesticides would help Europe and the world move towards more sustainable plant protection practices.

feedback: Es ist höchste Zeit, dass die Zerstörung der Bodenfruchtbarkeit durch gefährliche Chemikalien gestoppt wird. Unzählige wissenschaftliche Studien liefern unüberhörbare Warnungen.
englishfeedback: It is high time that the destruction of soil fertility is stopped by hazardous chemicals. Countless scientific studies provide insurmountable warnings.

feedback: I support this initiative. Exporting hazardous chemicals banned in the EU is unethical and contradicts human rights principles. Globally, chemicals have a negative impact on the environment and people's health. Millions of acute pesticide poisonings occur annually in low- and middle-income countries due to inadequate management. The United Nations recognizes the unsound management of chemicals and waste as a threat to human rights, particularly affecting vulnerable populations. Many countries outside of EU lack proper chemical management systems, making them less equipped to handle banned chemicals exported from the EU. Stopping these exports would protect the environment, biodiversity, and at-risk populations, while promoting safer alternatives. Replacing hazardous pesticides with cost-effective options benefits health, environment, and biodiversity without harming crop yields.
Wenn festgestellt wird, daß eine Chemikalie gesundheitsschädlich ist, sollte nicht nur ein weltweites Handelsverbot wirksam, sondern auch eine weitere Produktion verboten werden. Keine Kompromisse.
englishfeedback: If a chemical is found to be harmful to health, not only a global trade ban should be effective but also further production should be banned. No compromises.

feedback: L'exportation de pesticides toxiques révèle une politique de deux poids deux mesures : Les pesticides dangereux sont interdits en Europe après avoir été associés à des cancers, des problèmes de reproduction et des maladies neurodégénératives, ainsi qu'à la mort des abeilles. Certains de ces pesticides sont même interdits en Europe en raison de leur lien avec des lésions cérébrales chez les enfants et les bébés à naître. Si ces pesticides sont trop dangereux pour nous, comment pouvons-nous autoriser leur exportation ? L'exportation de pesticides toxiques est une question de droits humains , car ces pesticides sont nocifs pour notre santé : Chaque année, des milliers d'agriculteurs meurent des suites dune trop forte exposition à ces pesticides dangereux. Les pesticides exportés font l'objet d'innombrables études qui confirment leurs effets néfastes sur les humains. L'exportation de pesticides toxiques est néfaste pour les abeilles, la biodiversité et la planète en général. Les preuves sont claires : les néonics et autres pesticides dangereux tuent les abeilles. C'est pourquoi ils sont interdits en Europe. Pourquoi autorisons-nous encore leur exportation vers des pays où la réglementation est moins stricte, alors quils continueront de tuer les abeilles et décimer la biodiversité ? L'exportation de pesticides toxiques profite des pays où la réglementation est moins stricte. L'UE a un rôle à jouer dans le monde - ses entreprises ne devraient pas être autorisées à profiter des pays où la réglementation est plus faible. Comment pouvons-nous être pris au sérieux si nous expédions nos produits chimiques dangereux à l'étranger, empoisonnant ainsi les populations et la nature dans des pays où les règles de sécurité sont plus faibles et moins strictement appliquées ? L'interdiction d'exporter des pesticides toxiques serait une opportunité unique pour l'innovation et aiderait l'Europe et le monde à évoluer vers des méthodes de protection des plantes plus durables. Le maintien sur le marché de pesticides anciens et dangereux nous prive d'un avenir plus vert et de pratiques agricoles plus durables. Un avis juridique du Center for International Environmental Law publié en 2022 montre que les exportations européennes de pesticides interdits vers l'Afrique et l'Amérique centrale violent les obligations juridiques internationales de l'UE et le droit relatif aux droits humains. Documentation: https://reporterre.net/On-empoisonne-le-monde-a-Lyon-BASF-produit-un-pesticide-banni-en-France https://www.editionsladecouverte.fr/les_moissons_du_futur-9782707171542 https://reporterre.net/Les-Moissons-du-futur https://reporterre.net/Reorienter-d-urgence-l-agriculture Jean-Luc DEBARD
englishfeedback: The export of toxic pesticides reveals a double standard policy: Hazardous pesticides are banned in Europe after being associated with cancer, reproductive problems and neurodegenerative diseases, as well as bee death. Some of these pesticides are even banned in Europe because of their link to brain damage in children and born babies. If these pesticides are too dangerous for us, how can we authorise their export? The export of toxic pesticides is a human rights issue, as these pesticides are harmful to our health: Every year, thousands of farmers die as a result of excessive exposure to these hazardous pesticides. Exported pesticides are subject to countless studies confirming their adverse effects on humans. The export of toxic pesticides is harmful to bees, biodiversity and the planet in general. The evidence is clear: neonics and other hazardous pesticides kill bees. This is why they are banned in Europe. Why do we still allow their export to countries with less stringent regulation, while they will continue to kill bees and decay biodiversity? The export of toxic pesticides benefits countries with less stringent regulation. The EU has a role to play in the world – its businesses should not be allowed to benefit from countries with weaker regulation. How can we be taken seriously if we send our hazardous chemicals abroad, poisoning people and nature in countries where safety rules are weaker and less strictly enforced? Banning the export of toxic pesticides would be a unique opportunity for innovation and would help Europe and the world to move towards more sustainable plant protection methods. Keeping old and dangerous pesticides on the market deprives us of a greener future and more sustainable agricultural practices. A legal opinion of the Center for International Environmental Law published in 2022 shows that European exports of banned pesticides to Africa and Central America violate the EU’s international legal obligations and human rights law. Documentation: https://reporterre.net/On-empoisonne-le-monde-a-Lyon-BASF-produit-un-pesticide-banni-en-France https://www.editionsladecouverte.fr/les_moissons_du_futur-9782707171542 https://reporterre.net/Les-Moissons-du-futur https://reporterre.net/Reorienter-d-urgence-l-agriculture

feedback: Based on the required extensive risk assessments, plant protection products and their active ingredients are one of the best-studied and safest products worldwide. Their role in modern agriculture is significant. Yield losses can be due to weeds, pathogens, viruses and animal pests. The potential and actual losses differ between regions: potential losses are 71% in N-W Europe, 63% in S-W Europe, 52% in both N-E and S-E Europe, while actual losses are 18%, 25%, 30% and 32% respectively (Oerke, 2006). It should be noted that some substances are registered and used in third countries for other reasons than crop protection (such as vector control). In addition, the products being considered are exported to fulfill specific needs and of farmers outside of the EU. Different regions have different needs - the agronomic and climatic conditions vary from one region to another. For example, tropical and sub-tropical climates tend to have high pest and disease pressure due to the combination of heat and moisture. Therefore, we would like to express our concern regarding this proposal of banning production for export such active ingredients which could be essential for food production and food safety in non-European countries. Also, what could be expected is the increase of use untested pesticides - illegal and counterfeit products.

EU SHOULD STOP EXPORTING TOXIC CHEMICALS AND PESTICIDES TO DEVELOPING COUNTRIES & SHOULD TAKE THE LEAD TO STOP SUCH PRACTICES WORLDWIDE Despite being an agriculture-based country, Nepal is not self-sufficient in many agricultural products required to feed its citizens, thus heavily dependent on importation. The consumption of imported foods especially vegetables and fruits has resulted in an increase in Non-Communicable Diseases among the general people. And the country still does not have enough regulatory provisions as well as testing infrastructures throughout the county. The use of pesticides is increasing over the years at the rate of 10-20% per year in Nepal with average use of 396 g/ha but in the case of vegetables, it is much higher, 1600g/ha in areas with commercial vegetable production. There is a 20-fold increase in pesticide import from 56172 tons in 1997/98 to 623217 tons in 2016/17 to 1135504 tons a.i.in 2021/22. There are 4762 trade names and 163 pesticides registered in Nepal. Pieces of evidence have shown that the pesticides and chemicals that have been banned as well as severely restricted in EU regions are being recklessly produced and exported to many developing countries including Nepal. Chemicals like Dibutyltin dilaurate and others, severely restricted chemicals in the EU have been found to be exported to Nepal from Germany in the year 2022. In 2019, the EU as a single market accounted for 2.7 % of Nepals imports originated from the EU (EUR 305M1). The EU exports mainly machinery and transport equipment, chemicals, agricultural products, and other manufactures to Nepal (The European Union and Nepal | EEAS (europa.eu). These chemicals might be banned and/or restricted in the EU but are being exported to Nepal. Pieces of evidence of the impact of the pesticides have been found in Nepal from the use of such toxic pesticides and chemicals, viz: The adverse effect of pesticides has been found more in pregnant women, with a 5-9% increase in adverse birth outcomes, 13 grams decrease in birth weight of a child with gestational length, preterm birth, and birth abnormalities (Sagar GC and Jyoti Neupane. (2019). Multiple residues were observed in 56% of the eggplant samples, 96% of the chili samples, and all of the tomato samples. The most frequently detected pesticides in these vegetables were carbendazim and chlorpyrifos. Pesticide residues in 4% of the eggplant, 44% of the tomato, and 19% of the chili samples exceeded the EU maximum residue limits (MRLs). The residues of triazophos, omethoate, chlorpyrifos, and carbendazim exceeded the EU MRLs (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.envres.2019.03.002). According to a study related to chlorpyrifos health effects, out of 628 farmer participants, 317 participants (50.5%) complained about discomfort immediately after spraying pesticides. About 43.7% of the participants complained of headache, followed by blurred vision 25.4%, back pain 24.3%, and dizziness and nausea 19.7%. More than one-tenth of the participants complained of dry mouth, skin irritation, and muscular illness and less than one-tenth of participants suffered from extreme tiredness, loss of appetite, respiratory difficulties, and speech difficulty (Aryal, K.K., Aug 2016). Therefore, I urge the EU and its member countries: 1. to stop exporting Highly Hazardous Pesticides, banned chemicals, and mixtures for your own consumption but exporting to developing countries e.g., Spain, Germany, Netherlands, and Belgium have been found to be exporting banned or severely restricted chemicals (e.g. Dibutyltin dilaurate) and mixture to Nepal in 2022 and 2023. 2. EU should also take the lead and develop mechanisms to end exploring contaminated vegetables, fruits, and other agricultural products from one country to another. Please see my Video Message: https://youtu.be/1fP3ixR4vi8 Ram Charitra Sah Executive Director and Environment Scientist CEPHED, Mahalaxmi Municipality-2, Lalitpur Kathmandu, Nepal
organization: Center for Public Health and Environmental Development (CEPHED)

feedback: Il est impératif de modifier le règlement PIC afin d'interdire à la fois la production dans lUE et l'exportation - sans aucune dérogation - de tous les pesticides et autres produits chimiques dangereux interdits dans l'UE afin que soient protégés l'environnement et la santé humaine.
englishfeedback: It is imperative to amend the PIC Regulation to ban both the production in the EU and the export – without any derogation – of all pesticides and other hazardous chemicals banned in the EU in order to protect the environment and human health.
