A regulamentação de agrotóxicos no Brasil define que esses produtos devem ser registrados antes de ingressar no mercado, a Lei 7.802 de 1989 e o seu decreto regulamentador, o 4074 de 2002 definem os critérios de avaliação dos agrotóxicos, seus componentes e afins e a competência dos órgãos federais de saúde, meio ambiente e agricultura, compartilhada com os órgãos estaduais e municipais. Para as exportações as medidas sanitárias e fitossanitárias possuem relevância significativa e para tanto, os produtos exportados pelo Brasil para a União Europeia devem atender aos requisitos fitossanitários estabelecidos pelo Bloco. Dois aspectos importantes da regulação brasileira estão relacionados aos critérios de proibição de registro e a validade do mesmo. De acordo com o § 6º do artigo 3º da Lei 7.802/89 os critérios de proibição são ausência de método de desativação de modo a impedir que os seus resíduos remanescentes provoquem riscos ao meio ambiente e à saúde pública; para os quais não haja antídoto ou tratamento eficaz no Brasil; que revelem características teratogênicas, carcinogênicas ou mutagênicas, de acordo com os resultados atualizados de experiências da comunidade científica; que provoquem distúrbios hormonais, danos ao aparelho reprodutor, de acordo com procedimentos e experiências atualizadas na comunidade científica; que se revelem mais perigosos para o homem do que os testes de laboratório, com animais, tenham podido demonstrar, segundo critérios técnicos e científicos atualizados; e cujas características causem danos ao meio ambiente.
englishfeedback: The regulation of agrotoxicants in Brazil stipulates that such products must be registered before entering the market, Law 7.802 of 1989 and its implementing decree, No 4074 of 2002, define the criteria for assessing agrotoxicants, their components and the like and the competence of the federal bodies for health, the environment and agriculture, shared with state and municipal bodies. For exports sanitary and phytosanitary measures are of significant relevance and to that end, the products exported by Brazil to the European Union must comply with the phytosanitary requirements laid down by the Block. Two important aspects of Brazilian regulation relate to the criteria for prohibition of registration and its validity. According to Article 3 (6) of Law 7.802/89, the prohibition criteria are the absence of a method of deactivation in order to prevent the remaining waste from causing a risk to the environment and public health; for which there is no antidote or effective treatment in Brazil; which show teratogenic, carcinogenic or mutagenic characteristics according to the up-to-date results of experiments in the scientific community; causing hormonal disorders, damage to the reproductive system according to up-to-date procedures and experiments in the scientific community; which are more dangerous for man than laboratory tests on animals have been able to demonstrate, in accordance with up-to-date technical and scientific criteria; and whose characteristics cause damage to the environment.

feedback: Ik vind dit voorstel voornamelijk negatief voor de Europese chemische sector. Reeds maakt het huidige Europese klimaat het de chemische sector niet gemakkelijk, hoewel ik de strenge normen niet slecht vind. Maar veel van de Europese bedrijven actief in de chemische sector doen momenteel aan export naar derde landen waar chemicaliën naartoe gaan die inderdaad misschien niet legaal zijn in het exporterende land maar wel in het binnenkomende land. Een verbod op een product kan dan ook komen om wille van het lokale klimaat of de bestudeerde impact op de lokale fauna en flora. Deze regeling zou voor bedrijven in Europa enkel een financiële hinder kunnen vormen. Als er geen export meer mag gebeuren vanuit EU naar derde landen, zullen de Europese bedrijven die groot en kapitaalkrachtig genoeg zijn investeren in magazijnen/ import lijnen vanuit productie land naar het derde land zelf. Dit betekent dat niet enkel de Europese chemische bedrijven geraakt zullen worden, maar tevens de werknemers van deze bedrijven, de Europese laboratoriums die testen uitvoeren voor deze bedrijven en iedereen gelieerd, rechtstreeks of in onderaanneming voor een van deze actoren. Doordat op dit moment nog de grondstoffen/afgewerkte producten een passage maken in Europa en hier de controle normen/eisen hoger liggen dan in het merendeel van de wereld, resulteert dit rechtstreeks in een strengere tussen controle. Er kan gegarandeerd worden dat kwalitatieve normen voor contaminatie worden gerespecteerd. Qua milieu impact betekent deze regeling weinig voor de rest van de wereld, per slot van rekening zijn de grondstoffen nog steeds legaal in de landen en zal er een omweg gevonden worden, dit ten nadele van de Europese unie. Het zou jammer zijn om de Europese kwalitatief sterke markt van chemicaliën te verzwakken, zo niet te doen verdwijnen omwille van een maatregel die weinig tot geen verandering zal brengen. Ik hoop dat er met alle consequenties rekening gehouden zal worden en vertrouw op mijn Europese unie tot een verstandige beslissing in deze materie.
englishfeedback: I think this proposal is mainly negative for the European chemical sector. Already, the current European climate does not make the chemical sector easy, although I do not find the high standards to be bad. However, many of the European companies active in the chemical sector are currently exporting to third countries where chemicals are going, which may not be legal in the exporting country but in the incoming country. A product ban may therefore be due to the local climate or the impact studied on local fauna and flora. This scheme could only create a financial nuisance for businesses in Europe. If exports from the EU to third countries are no longer allowed, European companies that are large and capital-intensive will invest in warehouses/import lines from production to the third country itself. This means that not only the European chemical companies will be affected, but also the employees of these companies, the European laboratories carrying out tests for these companies and all associated, directly or by subcontracting to one of these actors. The fact that at present the raw materials/finished products are still passing through in Europe, and where the control standards/requirements are higher than in most of the world, directly results in a tighter control between controls. It can be ensured that qualitative standards for contamination are respected. In terms of environmental impact, this arrangement has little impact on the rest of the world, after all, raw materials are still legal in the countries and will be reversed, to the detriment of the European Union. It would be regrettable to weaken, if not eliminate, the European high quality chemicals market because of a measure that will bring little or no change. I hope that all the consequences will be taken into account and rely on my European Union for a sensible decision on this matter.

feedback: We source hydrogen cyanamide from a trusted and reputable manufacturer in the EU. Hydrogen cyanamide is an important Plant Growth Regulator (PGR) necessary to achieve profitable yields of kiwifruit in growing regions which do not receive adequate winter chilling. This substance is an important tool to improve and increase uniform budbreak and flowering. Viable alternatives are not available and the use is of vital importance to affected horticultural sectors. An export ban does not change the existing demand for this important substance in New Zealand. In the event of a European export ban, this demand will be met by manufacturers from other countries - especially China - who are already supplying this active ingredient in this market. It is foreseeable that the situation of users with regard to product labeling, quality assurance, user training, safety instruction and equipment with personal protective equipment would worsen in the event of a compulsory withdrawal of the only European manufacturer. A European export ban would neither reduce the use of this substance nor reduce the risks for users and the environment. The use of hydrogen cyanamide is currently permitted in this region and necessary risk reduction measures have been specified accordingly.
Il est grand temps de mettre fin à ces exportations et à respecter les règles européennes comme le bien-être de ces populations
englishfeedback: It is high time to stop these exports and to respect European rules such as the welfare of these people.

feedback: Tout à fait d'accord avec la proposition d'une législation interdisant aux sociétés ou particuliers de l'UE d'exporter ou faire exporter des produits interdits en UE ...... quand bien même ils le feraient par le biais d'une société ou personne extérieure à l'UE Cela tombe sous le sens que si un produit est interdit d'usage en UE il doit également être interdit de "commerce" en dehors par une personne juridique (une société) ou non établie en UE Il faut également s'assurer qu'une personne juridique ou privée de nationalité de l'UE n'exerce de tels commerces en s'établissant en dehors de l'UE Il me paraît suffisant d'interdire la commercialisation car sans commercialisation toute production serait vaine
englishfeedback: I strongly agree with the proposal for legislation prohibiting EU companies or individuals from exporting or having exported products prohibited in the EU...... even if they do so through a company or person outside the EU. This means that if a product is prohibited for use in the EU, it must also be prohibited from “trade” outside the EU by a legal person (a company) or not established in the EU. It is also necessary to ensure that a legal or private person of EU nationality does not engage in such trade outside the EU. I think it is sufficient to prohibit marketing as without marketing any production would be pointless.

feedback: La santé humaine ,la biodiversite et l'environnement sont impactées par ces pesticides, fongicides, herbicides etc... Interdit en Europe, la CE autorise leurs exportations. Mais des résidus de pesticides finissent malgré tout dans nos assiettes. A méditer car il y a un grand danger pour nous . Bien à vous
englishfeedback: Human health, biodiversity and the environment are affected by these pesticides, fungicides, herbicides, etc. Banned in Europe, the EC authorises their exports. But pesticide residues still end up in our plates. To be meditated because there is a great danger to us. Respectfully,

feedback: What about the hazardous chemicals (under the PIC legislation) which are imported in the EU to produce the goods which will sell/use either in UE or in a non-UE country! Is this scenario also foreseen in this initiative?

Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, es sollten keine gefährliche Chemikalien mehr aus der EU geliefert werden, die in der EU bereits verboten sind. Das ist fahrlässig, da dort Natur und Menschen genauso geschädigt werden wie hier. Es gibt außerdem keine Grenzen für Vergiftung. Bitte verbieten Sie diese Praxis. Mit freundlichen Grüßen, Sybille Dömel.
englishfeedback: Ladies and Gentlemen, no dangerous chemicals should be shipped from the EU that are already banned in the EU. This is negligent, as nature and people are harmed in the same way as here. There are also no limits on poisoning. Please prohibit this practice. Yours sincerely, Sybille Dömel.

feedback: Non pas de pesticides dangereux nulle part.
englishfeedback: Nowhere is hazardous pesticides.

feedback: Il me paraît absolument indéfendable, voire malveillant, de permettre l'exportation de produits chimiques dont on a interdit l'usage sur le sol européen, pour des raisons sanitaires et/ou environnementales. L'exposition des personnes, des animaux et des végétaux à ce type de produit a les mêmes effets néfastes, quelle que soit la région du monde considérée. En conséquence de quoi, je suis en faveur d'une interdiction totale de l'exportation de ces produits dangereux, et, partant, en faveur de l'interdiction de leur production. Je vous remercie de m'avoir donné l'occasion de m'exprimer.
englishfeedback: It seems to me absolutely untenable, if not malicious, to allow the export of chemicals whose use on European soil has been prohibited, for health and/or environmental reasons. Exposure of humans, animals and plants to this type of product has the same adverse effects, regardless of the region of the world in question. Consequently, I am in favour of a total ban on the export of those dangerous products, and therefore in favour of prohibiting their production. Thank you for giving me the opportunity to speak.

feedback: The treatment of seeds constitutes a use of plant protection products under Article 2(1)(a) of Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009, as the purpose of the application is to protect plants and the seeds are considered as plants under Article 3(5) of the same Regulation. The treatment of seeds with plant protection products assures both seed and plant health by restricting pests and pathogens. This helps to secure crop quality, safety and yield, while applying only very small quantities of plant protection products directly to the seed itself, prior to the sowing, seed treatments protect the seed during germination and protect the plant itself during growth. The seed treatment process takes place in the countries where the seeds are produced, or in the headquarters of the company (e.g. for vegetable seeds). Seed companies supply high quality seeds of innovative varieties all over the world. 2,8 billion worth of seeds are exports outside EU to Ukraine, USA, Mexico, Egypt, Morocco, or India. Some countries have specific legal requirements and ask to specific treatment on seeds to enter their market because of phytosanitary reason. The highly industrialized treatment process in the EU is conducted by specialist professionals, with safety and environmental issues carefully managed throughout. Facilities are designed to ensure safe operating conditions and special equipment protects workers from any accidental exposure to the chemicals. By using treated seed, farmers in third countries no longer have to handle or mix the actual chemical substances themselves this practically eliminates any risks of unwanted exposure. As demonstrated in the videos treatment outside the EU is not always conducted to the standard we as European seed industry with our ESTA scheme advocate. https://youtube.com/watch?v=FUYXaVZimZE&feature=share https://youtube.com/shorts/J3y8-QvI_m0?feature=share https://www.youtube.com/shorts/FxGy8vEt5LI

Alle gefährlichen Chemikalien sollten in Europa verboten werden (auch die Produktion). Pestizide in der Landwirtschaft sind zu verbieten. Das Agrarsystem sollte auf pflanzliche Nahrung mit ökologischen Methoden umgestellt werden (100% BIO-Landwirtschaft - so schnell wie möglich). Siehe u.a. die Ausstellung "Irrweg Pestizide" (www.irrweg-pestizide.de). Freundliche Grüße Birgitt Kruse und Jürgen Kruse, Steinstr. 12, 48301 Nottuln, Tel.: 02502-4129881 Siehe auch: Bundesbürgerinitiative Waldschutz ( https://www.bundesbuergerinitiative-waldschutz.de/ ), https://www.bundesbuergerinitiative-waldschutz.de/2022/08/03/gewachsen-um-zu-bleiben-endlich-schutz-f%C3%BCr-alte-b%C3%A4ume/ https://www.facebook.com/groups/1077418446980066 Arbeitskreis Heckenschutz www.heckenschutz.de www.hecke.wg.vu info@heckenschutz.de Steinstr. 12 48301 Nottuln T: 02502 - 4129881 5.7.2023
englishfeedback: All hazardous chemicals should be banned in Europe (including production). Pesticides in agriculture should be banned. The agricultural system should be converted to plant-based food using organic methods (100 % BIO farming – as soon as possible). See, inter alia, the exhibition ‘Irrweg Pesticides’ (www.irrweg-pestizide.de). Best regards, Birgitt Kruse and Jürgen Kruse, Steinstr. 12, 48301 Notuln, tel: 02502-4129881 See also: Federal Citizens’ Initiative Waldschutz ( https://www.bundesbuergerinitiative-waldschutz.de/ ), https://www.bundesbuergerinitiative-waldschutz.de/2022/08/03/gewachsen-um-zu-bleiben-endlich-schutz-f%C3%BCr-alte-b%C3%A4ume/ die Arbeitkreis Heckenschutz (Hecken Protection Working Group) 12 48301 Notuln T: 02502 – 4129881 5.7.2023

feedback: Forbrugerrådet Tænk bakker op om at forbyde eksport af kemikalier, der er forbudt i EU. En beslutning, der skulle være blevet gennemført i det øjeblik de enkelte kemikalier blev forbudt i EU. Initiativet fremhæver, at der i 2020 blev eksporteret 667.000 ton forbudte eller 'restricted' kemikalier til lande udenfor EU. Forestil jer, hvis det var omvendt. At EU importerede kemikalier, som andre lande havde forbudt på grund af deres negative egenskaber (kræft, hormonforstyrrelser mm). At vi udsatte vores borgere og miljø for kemikalier andre lande vurderede var skadelige. EU Kommissionen har gennemført forbuddene og restriktionerne i EU for at beskytte mennesker og miljø, og selvfølgelig bør dette også gælde andre lande, hvor mennesker og miljø risikerer at lide under de skadelige egenskaber ved kemikalierne, som vi har besluttet at borgere i EU ikke skal udsættes for. Og med eksporten risikerer vi faktisk på nuværende tidspunkt, at borgere i EU bliver udsat for de forbudte kemikalier. Det viser de årlige pesticidprøver fra fødevarestyrelsen tydeligt, idet forbudte pesticider ender op på de frugter og grøntsager, som vi importerer til Danmark. Initiativet vil fjerne EUs dobbeltmoral på området, og styrke EUs troværdighed, når intentionen er en kemikaliestrategi med bæredygtighed for øje - det bør gælde mennesker og miljø i hele verden.
englishfeedback: The Danish Consumer Council Think supports banning the export of chemicals banned in the EU. A decision that should have been implemented as soon as individual chemicals were banned in the EU. The initiative highlights that in 2020, 667.000 tonnes of banned or ‘restricted’ chemicals were exported outside the EU. Imagine you if it was the other way round. The EU imported chemicals that other countries had banned because of their negative properties (cancer, endocrine disruption, etc.). We exposed our citizens and the environment to chemicals from other countries assessed as harmful. The European Commission has implemented the prohibitions and restrictions in the EU to protect people and the environment, and of course this should also apply to other countries where people and the environment are at risk of suffering from the harmful properties of chemicals to which we have decided that EU citizens should not be exposed. Indeed, with exports, we currently risk exposing EU citizens to banned chemicals. This shows clearly the annual pesticide samples from the Danish Veterinary and Food Administration, as banned pesticides end up on the fruit and vegetables we import into Denmark. The initiative will eliminate the double standards of the EU in this area and strengthen the credibility of the EU when it intends to be a chemicals strategy for sustainability – it should apply to people and the environment around the world.

feedback: Madame, Monsieur, Je suis d'accord avec l'interdiction de la production à des fins d'exportation de produits chimiques dans l'UE. Merci de tenir compte de mon avis. Bien cordialement, Une citoyenne de l'UE.
englishfeedback: Dear Sir/Madam, I agree with the ban on the production of chemicals for export to the EU. Thank you for taking my opinion into account. Well warmly, an EU citizen.

feedback: World is getting smaller and smaller, and more and more interconnected. Everyone (not just us, Europeans) have therefore the duty to spread across the entire world the best practises. In terms of heath & safety, indeed Europe is clearly quite in an advanced stage versus many other Countries, so it's correct to try to make that the best of our legislation could be adopted elsewhere. Hence, in line of principle, I do agree about the prohibition to export outside EU, what in the EU it's forbidden to be used. However, especially over the last couple of years, after the adoption of the "Chemical Strategy for Sustainability", I have several critics against the logic of Commission and ECHA, starting from the mantra "toxic-free environment". This is totally against (1) science ("zero" or "free" doesn't exist in nature); (2) a Risk-based approach, instead of an Hazard-based one; (3) the Circular Economy. (1): we can we drink a coffee, but we couldn't use it into a plastic, and then recycle it... (2): Risk (Hazard x Exposure) must always be the polar star: we must MANAGE risks, not blindly try to avoid them, which would be impossible and counterproductive. (3): Managing risk (which means, for instance, mechanically recycling plastics, even if containing hazardous molecules, as long as not posing exposure) would allow a much wider circularity of the entire economy, with huge advantages for raw materials and energy savings. Therefore, unless EU shall not switch before towards a real Risk-based approach, I would NOT induce other Countries to follow us. And of course, those Countries would keep safely using such molecules acquired from third parties, with an obvious economic damage for the EU industry, without any real advantages in terms of health and safety (or often, exactly the opposite).

Fecc acknowledges the consultation on Hazardous chemicals prohibiting production for export of chemicals banned in the European Union (link) and welcomes the opportunity to provide input. In this consultation we would like to raise the following points: 1. Fecc supports the legislative initiative that aims to introduce a mechanism prohibiting production and/or export of certain hazardous chemicals that are banned in the EU to protect non-EU countries from their negative effects on human health and the environment. The consistency between internal and external policies should be achieved in order to improve the international standing of the EU, strengthening the credibility of our values and actions and most importantly improving protection of human health and the environment globally. 2. Each legislative action should focus on risk assessment on health and environment. The hazard classification of a chemical substance is intrinsically driven by its structure, and some of them do play an essential use in the functioning of society, health, etc. 3. The holistic approach to the subject with harmonization and internationalization of the action should be foreseen to raise awareness. In developing countries often the use of hazardous chemicals is not properly regulated, and they can be misused. It poses a severe risk to health, safety, and the environment. Fecc is the association that represents chemical, food and active pharmaceutical ingredients distributors, most of which are SMEs. We believe that sustainability and an integral regulatory framework go hand-in-hand. We would be happy to engage further with the Commission to pursue sustainable, environment friendly and safe solutions in this area.

La Commission de l'UE a interdit l'utilisation des produits chimique dangereux dans les pays de l'UE pour la protection de la santé humaine et de l'environnement. Ces produits chimiques interdits dans la région de l'UE sont souvent exportés vers les pays en développement et à économie de transition, en l'occurrence des pesticides extrêmement dangereux, comme Atrazine ; Chlorpyrifos et autres ; qui ont souvent de graves impacts négatifs sur la santé humaine (leucémies, troubles respiratoires, la maladie de Parkinson) et sur la biodiversité. Nous savons que la stratégie sur les produits chimiques pour la durabilité adoptée le 14 octobre 2020 est une action clé du pacte vert européen et de la transition vers un environnement sans produits toxiques. La stratégie vise à protéger les personnes et l'environnement contre les produits chimiques dangereux et à encourager l'innovation pour développer des alternatives sûres et durables, au sein de l'UE et dans le monde. Conformément à la stratégie sur les produits chimiques1, cette initiative vise à assurer une plus grande cohérence entre les politiques internes et externes et à améliorer ainsi la position internationale de l'UE, à renforcer la crédibilité de nos valeurs et de nos actions et, surtout, à améliorer la protection de la santé humaine et de l'environnement à l'échelle mondiale. L'initiative est liée à plusieurs règlements de l'UE qui contribuent à décider si les produits chimiques sont considérés comme interdits ou strictement réglementés, en particulier dans le contexte du règlement PIC. Ceux-ci incluent : Règlement REACH (Règlement 1907/2006 sur l'enregistrement, l'évaluation, l'autorisation et la restriction des produits chimiques) Règlement PIC (Règlement 649/2012 sur l'exportation et l'importation de produits chimiques dangereux) Règlement sur les produits phytopharmaceutiques (Règlement 1107/2009 concernant la mise sur le marché des produits phytopharmaceutiques) Règlement sur les biocides Le commerce international des produits chimiques dangereux est réglementé par la Convention de Rotterdam des Nations Unies sur la procédure de consentement préalable en connaissance de cause (PIC) pour certains produits chimiques et pesticides dangereux dans le commerce international. L'UE et tous ses États membres sont parties à la convention, qui compte actuellement 165 parties. Le règlement PIC de l'UE met en œuvre la convention de Rotterdam et est conforme aux éléments essentiels de la convention. lexigence de notification d'exportation Les mesures qui seront examinées dans le cadre doptions pourraient inclure, par exemple: Augmenter la quantité dinformations mises à la disposition des pays tiers au titre du règlement PIC, afin de leur permettre de mieux agir sur les risques recensés en vertu de la législation de lUnion en restreignant ou en interdisant la production et lutilisation des produits chimiques concernés de la même manière que dans lUnion. Réviser les exigences actuelles en matière dexportation au titre du règlement PIC, afin doffrir un niveau plus élevé de protection contre les importations non désirées de produits chimiques dangereux interdits dans lUnion. Introduire une interdiction de produire des produits chimiques dangereux qui ne sont pas approuvés ou sont interdits de mise sur le marché et/ou dutilisation dans lUnion Européenne. Eu égard à tout ce qui précède, nous demandons à la Commission de l'UE dutiliser sa position et son influence pour interdire la production et l'exportation des produits chimiques dangereux notamment des pesticides extrêmement dangereux vers les pays en développement et ceux à économie de transition afin de protéger la santé des populations de ces pays et notre planète. (This submission is being made on behalf of Mr. Joseph DENOUGBETO.)
englishfeedback: The EU Commission has banned the use of hazardous chemicals in EU countries to protect human health and the environment. These chemicals banned in the EU region are often exported to developing and transition economies, in this case highly hazardous pesticides, such as Atrazine; Chlorpyrifos and others; they often have serious negative impacts on human health (leukaemia, respiratory disorders, Parkinson’s disease) and biodiversity. We know that the Chemicals for Sustainability Strategy adopted on 14 October 2020 is a key action of the European Green Deal and the transition to a toxic-free environment. The strategy aims to protect people and the environment from hazardous chemicals and to encourage innovation to develop safe and sustainable alternatives, within the EU and globally. In line with the Chemicals Strategy 1, this initiative aims to ensure greater coherence between internal and external policies and thereby improve the EU’s international position, strengthen the credibility of our values and actions and, above all, improve the protection of human health and the environment globally. The initiative is linked to several EU regulations that help decide whether chemicals are considered to be banned or severely restricted, in particular in the context of the PIC Regulation. These include: Reach Regulation (Regulation 1907/2006 on the Registration, Evaluation, Authorisation and Restriction of Chemicals) PIC Regulation (Regulation 649/2012 on the export and import of dangerous chemicals) Regulation on plant protection products (Regulation 1107/2009 concerning the placing of plant protection products on the market) Regulation on biocides International trade in hazardous chemicals is regulated by the United Nations Rotterdam Convention on the Advanced Informed Consent (PIC) procedure for certain hazardous chemicals and pesticides in international trade. The EU and all its Member States are parties to the Convention, which currently has 165 Parties. The EU PIC Regulation implements the Rotterdam Convention and is in line with the essential elements of the Convention. Increase the amount of information made available to third countries under the PIC Regulation, to enable them to better address the risks identified under Union legislation by restricting or prohibiting the production and use of the chemicals concerned in the same way as in the Union. Revise the current export requirements under the PIC Regulation to provide a higher level of protection against unwanted imports of dangerous chemicals banned in the EU. Introduce a ban on the production of hazardous chemicals which are not approved or are prohibited from being placed on the market and/or used in the European Union. In light of all the above, we call on the EU Commission to use its position and influence to ban the production and export of hazardous chemicals, in particular highly hazardous pesticides to developing countries and those with transition economies in order to protect the health of the people of these countries and our planet. (This submission is made on half of Mr. Joseph DENOUGBETO)

feedback: The earth is an ecosystem in which all geographical regions and populations share its elements. When a negative impact occurs in one part of this ecosystem or when the activities of specific populations cause a harm to the ecosystem, then the whole ecosystem is threatened. Climate change is a good example of this. Chemicals, especially pesticides can be very damaging to the ecosystem (e.g., ground water contamination, affecting non-target species and biodiversity, etc.) Those chemicals do not know boundaries or limits since they persist in the environment, move through and within local ecosystems, and cause significant consequences wherever they exist. Thus, when plant protection products that applied in large quantities in several parts of the world, are proved to be very toxic to human and to cause a high impact to nature, they should be banned not only in EU but in all parts of the world. In countries of the global south (e.g. third world countries), there are no tools or resources to assess, evaluate or control the damage caused by plant protection products. Furthermore, plant protection products are used in several ways that are different than what they are meant for. Therefore, it is of high importance for the EU to take the lead in controlling the direct and indirect damage caused by the plant protection products in those countries. Most hazardous plant protection products are invented, manufactured and distributed by EU related business. Thus, EU should take responsibility and play an active role in preventing damage caused in those countries.

Ecologistas en Acción apoya decididamente la propuesta de prohibir la exportación de sustancias prohibidas en la Unión Europea. La fabricación y exportación de sustancias prohibidas en la UE a países terceros tiene consecuencias nefastas para los países importadores , en especial para los trabajadores y trabajadoras que se ven obligados a utilizar sustancias prohibidas en la UE por sus consecuencias inaceptables para la salud humana y el medio ambiente y poblaciones locales expuestas a estos tóxicos. Además, la consecuencias adversas, si bien probablemente menores no se circunscriben a los países importadores sí no que se extienden a la ciudadanía de la UE, tanto en lo relativo a los riesgos laborales derivados de la fabricación y manipulación de estas sustancias, como aquéllos otros que potencialmente sufre la población UE al importar bienes, incluidos alimentos que pueden contener residuos o cantidades de sustancias prohibidas en la UE. Un ejemplo de lo anterior, es el siguiente: En el programa oficial de control de residuos de plaguicidas de alimentos, realizado por las autoridades españolas en 2020, se detectaron residuos del plaguicida tiametoxam de baya de goji,producida en China. El objeto de este programa de control es la seguridad alimentaria y generar la confianza al consumidor sobre que los alimentos que se adquieren no tienen residuos de plaguicidas en cantidades superiores a los límites máximos que la legislación de la Unión Europea (Reglamento CE 396/2005) establece como instrumento de protección a los más vulnerables. El plaguicida detectado en la muestra de baya de goji cultivada en China contenía cantidades del insecticida neonicotinoide tiametoxam por debajo del límite máximo de residuos de plaguicidas (LMR). Por tanto, este dato considerado de manera aislada no debería generar preocupación. No obstante, se trata un plaguicida no autorizado en la Unión Europea. Esto es debido a que su no autorización (Reglamento CE 1107/2009, relativo a la comercialización de plaguicidas) afecta a su uso en la Unión Europea. Sin embargo, no tiene ningún efecto en lo relativo a su producción, por lo que pueden seguir fabricándose en cualquiera de los Estados miembros y venderse a países no pertenecientes a la Unión Europea. De esta forma, los plaguicidas no autorizados en la Unión Europea pueden retornar en forma de residuos de plaguicidas a las estanterías de nuestras tiendas de barrio y supermercados sin generar la alarma de las autoridades. Gracias a la información proporcionada por la Subdirección General de Aire Limpio y Sostenibilidad Industrial (Ministerio de Medio Ambiente), conocemos que en 2020 España exportó a China 1.260 kilos del insecticida neonicotinoide tiametoxam, lo que hace posible la hipótesis de que el plaguicida usado en China en el cultivo de bayas de goji hubiese sido fabricado en España. El caso de la detección del tiametoxam en un alimento importado por España no es sino uno de los muchos que pueden ser señalados y es un claro ejemplo de la hipocresía regulatoria de la Unión Europea. Al mismo tiempo que se prohíbe el uso de un determinado plaguicida en la Unión Europea, se permite su fabricación y exportación a países terceros y su retorno en forma de residuos de plaguicidas. Urge que la Unión Europea tome medidas que prohíban la fabricación y exportación de plaguicidas no autorizados e impida la comercialización de alimentos, sea cual sea su procedencia, que contengan estos plaguicidas. La exportación de plaguicidas prohibidos traslada a otros países el modelo de producción agraria que Europa descarta. No solo existe un comercio de plaguicidas no autorizados sino también una externalización de las consecuencias adversas para la salud humana y el medio ambiente, que afecta directamente a los agricultores y agricultoras de los países importadores, pero también de manera indirecta a las consumidoras y consumidores europeos a través de la alimentación.
englishfeedback: Environmentalists in Action strongly support the proposal to ban the export of substances banned in the European Union. The manufacture and export of substances banned in the EU to third countries has harmful consequences for importing countries, in particular for workers who are forced to use substances banned in the EU because of their unacceptable consequences for human health and the environment and local populations exposed to these toxic substances. In addition, the adverse consequences, although they are probably not limited to importing countries, do not extend to EU citizens, both in terms of occupational risks arising from the manufacture and handling of these substances, as well as those potentially suffered by the EU population when importing goods, including food that may contain residues or quantities of substances banned in the EU. An example of the above is the following: Residues of the pesticide thiamethoxam of goji, produced in China, were detected in the official control programme for pesticide residues of food by the Spanish authorities in 2020. The objective of this control programme is food safety and to create consumer confidence that the food purchased does not contain pesticide residues in excess of the maximum limits established by European Union legislation (Regulation (EC) No 396/2005) as a means of protecting the most vulnerable. The pesticide detected in goji’s berry sample grown in China contained amounts of the insecticide neonicotinoid thiamethoxam below the maximum pesticide residue level (MRL). Therefore, this data taken in isolation should not give rise to concern. However, it is an unauthorised pesticide in the European Union. This is because their non-authorisation (Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009 on the placing of pesticides on the market) affects their use in the European Union. However, it has no effect on their production and can therefore continue to be produced in any of the Member States and sold to countries outside the European Union. In this way, pesticides not authorised in the European Union can return in the form of pesticide residues to the shelves of our local shops and supermarkets without raising the authorities’ alarm. From the information provided by the Subdirectorate-General for Clean Air and Industrial Sustainability (Ministry of the Environment), we know that in 2020 Spain exported 1.260 kg of the neonicotinoide thiamethoxam insecticide to China, which makes it possible to assume that the pesticide used in China in the cultivation of goji berries was manufactured in Spain. The case of the detection of thiamethoxam in a food imported by Spain is only one of many that can be reported and is a clear example of the European Union’s regulatory hypocresy. While prohibiting the use of a particular pesticide in the European Union, its manufacture and export to third countries and its return in the form of pesticide residues are allowed. There is an urgent need for the European Union to take action to ban the manufacture and export of unauthorised pesticides and to prevent the placing on the market of foods, whatever their origin, containing these pesticides. The export of banned pesticides shifts the agricultural production model that Europe rejects to other countries. There is not only trade in unauthorised pesticides but also outsourcing of adverse consequences for human health and the environment, which directly affects farmers in importing countries, but also indirectly affects European consumers and consumers through food.

feedback: The Commission's proposal to ban the production of pesticides and fertilizers whose use is prohibited in the EU is supported by our organization. We believe it is important to extend the ban to all those substances in the food chain that are banned in Europe, such as growth hormones, food additives, or molecules such as Bisphenol that dissolve in the environment and by contaminating soil and water enter the food chain. The exemes given are not exhaustive, but the concept is.
I think we need to stop exporting banned pesticides to countries with weaker regulation. Its bad for people and planet!
Im Zuge der bevorstehenden CSRD Gesetzverabschiedung muss dieses Thema berücksichtigt werden !
englishfeedback: This issue must be taken into account in the upcoming CSRD adoption!

feedback: INDECOSA-CGT ne peut que se réjouir de cette initiative de la Commission Européenne. Nous avons été profondément déçus par labandon de la révision du Règlement REACh suite aux pressions des lobbies industriels, alors même que notre étude de 2020 sur la gestion des phtalates et leur utilisation dans les produits dintérieur démontrait clairement les failles et absurdités (pour ne pas dire complaisances) de cette gestion par le Règlement et son agence, lECHA. Il est insupportable de penser que des produits jugés trop dangereux / nocifs pour les populations européennes puissent être autorisés à la fabrication en Europe pour exportation dans le monde. Il est dune hypocrisie consommée destimer que les protections fournies obligatoirement aux salariés des pays disposant dun droit social de haute qualité puissent être accordées à ceux des pays récepteurs, parfois fortement déficients en matière de santé publique et dinformation sanitaire. Ce monde ne peut disposer de valeurs humaines pour les européens, aussitôt oubliées pour les autres pays, lorsquils nont pas la chance doffrir les mêmes droits à leurs citoyens. Et ce dautant plus que le commerce mondial a fait et fait toujours une démonstration constante de son absence déquité et de morale dès lors que le droit le lui autorise. En France, nous faisons dores et déjà le constat que lorsque une interdiction existe de façon ferme sur un territoire, celle-ci ne permet pas le résultat attendu. C'est le cas avec des traces dans l'eau de chlorothalonil alors que celui-ci est interdit depuis 2020 en France. En permettant l'export de produit interdit sur un territoire ou un espace, nous ne garantissons pas la sécurité de tous, notamment à l'heure de la mondialisation. L'interdiction des néonicotinoïdes est aujourd'hui un réel enjeu, avec un risque durable sur la santé et sur l'environnement. L'autorisation à l'export de ce produit, ne fait que déplacer le problème. Nous redisons notre opposition formelle à fermer les yeux sur l'exportation de la pollution hors zone UE. Nous, INDECOSA-CGT, appuyons donc cette initiative et exigeons quelle ne puisse être contournée par le système dérogatoire autorisé dans le cadre de REACh.
englishfeedback: INDECOSA-CGT can only welcome this initiative of the European Commission. We were deeply disappointed by the labandon of the revision of the REACh Regulation following pressure from industrial lobbies, even though our 2020 study on the management of phthalates and their use in indoor products clearly demonstrated the flaws and absurdities (not to say complacency) of this management by the Regulation and its agency, Lecha. It is unbearable to think that products considered too dangerous/harmful to European populations can be authorised for manufacturing in Europe for export to the world. It is a hypocrisy consumed that the mandatory protection provided to employees in countries with high quality social rights can be granted to those of the receiving countries, which are sometimes severely deficient in terms of public health and health information. This world cannot have human values for Europeans, immediately forgotten for other countries, when they do not have the chance to equip their citizens with the same rights. This is all the more so given that world trade has consistently demonstrated its lack of decency and morality when permitted by law. In France, we already note that when a ban exists firmly in a territory, it does not achieve the desired result. This is the case with traces in chlorothalonil water, which has been banned in France since 2020. By allowing the export of products banned in a territory or space, we do not guarantee the safety of all, especially in a globalised world. Banning neonicotinoids is now a real challenge, with a lasting risk to health and the environment. The export authorisation of this product merely alters the problem. We reiterate our formal opposition to turning a blind eye to exporting pollution outside the EU. We, INDECOSA-CGT, therefore support this initiative and demand that the derogation system authorised under REACh cannot be circumvented.

feedback: Il est absolument nécessaire d'interdire la production de tels produits. C'est tant une question de respect de la dignité humaine qu'environnementale.
englishfeedback: It is absolutely necessary to prohibit the production of such products. It is both a matter of respect for human dignity and of the environment.

feedback: This initiative primarily aims at strengthening the credibility of the EU at international level. It aims at banning the production and export of chemicals that are banned in the EU under either REACH, PPP or BPR, or banned under the UN Rotterdam Convention (PIC). The EU bans can be done either based on unacceptable risk or unacceptable hazard. These chemicals can potentially also cause harm outside the EU. It is acknowledged that the economic consequence for EU manufacturer would be a loss of business in favour of non-EU countries. It is then stated that However, in the long term, this change is expected to reinforce the reliability of EU products as regards safety and quality and thus their image on the global market. I understand that the rest of the world is observing with interest the EU Regulatory activities on hazardous chemicals, but it is not always in agreement with them. The intention to ban the manufacture in the EU and export from the EU for certain chemicals would be seen as the EU putting its facts together but at the same time affecting its own economy, and depending on the audience could be both seen as increasing its credibility or decreasing it. I believe that the EU can share directions it is taking with the international community but cannot force it on the detriment of EU economy. It is important to keep in mind that this foreseen ban would be for chemicals that have shown under EU criteria an unacceptable risk scenario but this may not be relevant for scenarios relevant for other parts of the world where risk characterisation could be done differently and socio-economic impact would be weighted differently. This ban would also be for chemicals that are simply classified as hazardous without any demonstration of unacceptable risk, which is even worse, especially considering the new hazard classes under the EU CLP when these have not even yet been discussed at the UN GHS level. The impact on the EU economy is acknowledged but with the statement that in the long run EU products would be regarded as safer and of better quality. I would like to point out that the quality of products is not only linked to safety aspects but much more. If the EU products are unable to fulfil other requirements and/or are not economically competitive due to the impossibility to use key substances then the EU economy will again suffer. Hence, I believe that this statement on possible long-term benefits should be substantiated as, for the moment, it looks way too theoretical. The EU CSS has not yet been transposed into revised EU legislation and its impact is largely unknown because the future classification of chemicals and the effective implementation of the envisaged changes are uncertain. This intention to ban the manufacture and export of these chemicals is therefore too premature and should in any case be discussed at international level. I understand the wish for EU to lead the global safety agenda for chemicals but the EU can only make recommendations and not force its agenda to others, and should keep in mind the protection of EU economy and the global competitiveness in which the EU is engaged for decades (rightly or not). The current need to inform the importing countries under PIC is sufficient for those chemicals that the UN consider as posing unacceptable effects. The information provided could be improved by identifying the reasons for the EU ban (unacceptable risk under specific conditions or hazard), which could help the importing country in determining whether these apply to them.

Szeretném, ha megfontolnák bizonyos mesterségesen előállított édesítőszerek, tehát vegyi anyagok előállításának és felhasználásának tilalmát. Az utóbbi időben tudományosnak tűnő vizsgálatokról lehet olvasni, melyek kimutatták, hogy bizonyos ilyen édesítőszerek DNS károsító hatásúak, rákkeltőek, mégis szinte minden cukormentes élelmiszerben megtalálhatók, legalábbis Magyarországon. Ilyen például a szukralóz.
englishfeedback: I would like to consider a ban on the production and use of certain artificially manufactured sweeteners, i.e. chemicals. Recent studies that have appeared to be scientific, have shown that some of these sweeteners are DNA harmful, carcinogenic but still found in almost all sugar-free foods, at least in Hungary. This is the case, for example, of sucralose.

feedback: EU's PIC Regulation should stay as close as possible to the UNs Rotterdam Convention on the Prior Informed Consent (PIC) and should be used consequently. Substances not approved according Plant Protection Products Regulation (Regulation 1107/2009) or Biocides Regulation (Regulation 528/2012) and exported for these uses or substances restricted or authorized according REACH Regulation (Regulation 1907/2006) but manufactured in the EU should consequently be handled under PIC. Recipient countries need to give there approval prior to an export from the EU. However, it is not acceptable to refuse the sending of substances as mentioned before to any non-EU countries only based on EU's PPP or Biocides or REACH Regulation, without involvement of the recipient countries. This looks like colonialism and is denying non-EU countries their right to decide what substances they want to have in their country and is denying their ability to safe the health of their citizens or their environment on their own. Furthermore I would see this as a breach against the world trade regime that most of the EU countries (or all?) have signed.

Les mêmes causes produisant les mêmes effets dans les mêmes conditions, cette règlementation serait la bienvenue. En effet, ayant étudié la question dans le cadre d'un mémoire de recherche à l'université de Strasbourg, il ressort que l'interdiction est une nécessité pour plusieurs raisons. Premièrement, l'UE réclame une position de leader en matière environnementale et cela ne saurait être complète si l'UE exporte les conséquences néfastes des pesticides en dehors de ces territoires. Deuxièmement, ces pesticides ont des conséquences dommageables sur la santé humaine et l'environnement. La destruction de la biodiversité et l'assujettissement des agriculteurs africains par le biais de ces pesticides devraient bien s'arrêter. Ces pesticides portent atteinte au droit de l'environnement "per se" mais aussi à des multiples droits humains indirectement. Aussi, il faut rappeler que le rapporteur du CDH soulignait en 2018 qu'il est faux que ces pesticides contribuent à la sécurité alimentaire. Troisièmement, il faut noter que l'UE importe de nombreux produits venant des pays importateurs des produits chimiques. Ces produits interdits en Europe à l'état brut reviennent donc d'une manière ou d'une autre sur les territoires européens sous forme de "fruits et légumes" en majorité. Cela contribue à une atteinte à la santé des citoyens européens de manière indirecte. Même si des mesures sont prises pour limiter les traces d'insecticides dans les produits importés, il faut noter que les citoyens européens ne sont pas exemptés d'atteinte. L'UE devrait arrêter se départir du lobbying des industries productrices de pesticides et adopter une règlementation très fortes pour protéger l'environnement et la population mondiale.
englishfeedback: As the same causes produce the same effects under the same conditions, these rules would be welcome. Having studied the issue in a research memory at the University of Strasbourg, it appears that the prohibition is necessary for several reasons. First, the EU calls for a leading position on the environment and this cannot be complete if the EU exports the harmful consequences of pesticides outside these territories. Secondly, these pesticides have harmful consequences for human health and the environment. The destruction of biodiversity and the taxing of African farmers through these pesticides should come to an end. These pesticides undermine the right to the environment “per se”, but also many human rights indirectly. It should also be borne in mind that the HRC rapporteur stressed in 2018 that it is not true that these pesticides contribute to food security. Thirdly, it should be noted that the EU imports many products from countries importing chemicals. These products banned in Europe in their unprocessed state therefore return in one way or another to European territories in the form of ‘fruit and vegetables’. This contributes indirectly to damage to the health of European citizens. Even if measures are taken to limit traces of insecticides in imported products, it should be noted that European citizens are not exempt from infringement. The EU should stop the lobbying of pesticide producing industries and adopt very strong rules to protect the environment and the global population.

feedback: Favorable
englishfeedback: In favour

feedback: Hazardous chemicals I favor prohibiting production for export of chemicals banned in the European Union

To some extent it is hypocritical that companies in the EU produce chemicals that aren't allowed to be sold to the domestic market. Not only that, it also risks spills, leakage and illegal usage via black markets since the product is already in the EU. So there is some residual risk left, but this risk is counteracted by regulation and strict supervision which makes the production environment of these chemicals safe and transparent. The immediate consequence of banning exports of these chemicals would lead to production in other countries or even the ones most affected. Such installations might not be as safe, potentially leading to severe environmental and health damage. And the other side is a country that doesn't see these risks or cannot do something about these risks during production and consumption of these chemicals. It might therefore be more effective to go into talks with those countries to support them in their actions to reduce their consumption. All in all, the ban is a good start, but it must be accompanied by other measures to either reduce consumption or extend the ban such that no new production facilities just take our place, making the whole process more unsafe.

The January 2017 Report of the Special Rapporteur on the right to food report to the UN Human Rights Council concluded that pesticides are responsible for an estimated 200,000 acute poisoning deaths each year, 99 per cent of which occur in developing countries but that Approximately 25 per cent of developing countries lack effective laws on distribution and use, while about 80 per cent lack sufficient resources to enforce existing pesticide-related laws. In addition to human health concerns there are global concerns about the release of persistent pesticides harmful to biodiversity into the environment. With regard to chemicals banned in the EU due to the harm they cause to pollinators there is a high risk that their use in countries near the EU will damage EU pollination services and food security as populations of pollinating hoverflies and moths in particular are often migratory in nature, hence would be vulnerable to harm while in countries outside the EU https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0960982219306050 Regulating to prevent the export of chemicals where we know the intended use is likely to damage human health and the environment would be a sensible and proportionate measure that would apply the fundamental EU environmental principle of preventing harm.

La Coordination Rurale (CR) remercie la Commission européenne de sa consultation sur linitiative visant à mettre en place un mécanisme interdisant la production et/ou lexportation de certains produits chimiques dangereux interdits dans lUE, et souligne avec satisfaction que les documents sont disponibles dans toutes les langues de lUE. La CR salue la volonté de la Commission de prendre une initiative visant à « accroître la protection de la santé humaine et de lenvironnement à léchelle mondiale et dappliquer des mesures uniformes dans tous les pays de lUnion ». Vouloir montrer lexemple est une chose, mais si cette initiative ne saccompagne pas de mesures fortes sur les importations, sa portée sera très limitée et entraînera la délocalisation de la production. On ne peut s'ériger en parangon de vertu et fermer les usines produisant des produits phytopharmaceutiques (PPP) dangereux interdits dans lUE, tout en laissant les denrées obtenues avec ces mêmes PPP entrer sur le territoire de l'UE. Cette démarche n'a rien d'exemplaire. Elle suscitera la moquerie plus que l'admiration. Notons que : - des PPP interdits dans lUE ont été récemment détectées dans du blé en provenance dUkraine (1500 tonnes contenant du chlorpyrifos en Slovaquie) ; - que selon Europol, les PPP de contrefaçon sont en hausse dans lUE ; - et enfin, quen 2018, lUkraine était un des 3 plus gros importateurs de PPP interdits dans lUE. Si des substances ont des effets négatifs sur la santé humaine ou sur lenvironnement, il est donc justifié de restreindre ou de ne pas autoriser leur usage. Et bien sûr que les effets ayant motivé cette décision dans lUE sont préoccupants dans dautres pays, voire à léchelle mondiale. Mais interdire la production dans lUE nempêche pas la production hors de lUE, et nempêche pas les pays tiers de sapprovisionner hors UE, ce qui peut entraîner et la Commission la identifié des incidences économiques directes sur les entreprises de lUnion (pertes de ventes et de parts de marché), ainsi quune délocalisation de la production hors de lUE. La CR salue la lucidité de la Commission à légard des entreprises et le probable impact sur celles-ci, mais regrette que la Commission ne fasse pas preuve de la même considération pour les distorsions de concurrence dont sont victimes les agriculteurs. En effet, pour ne pas importer de la pollution, pour ne pas mettre en danger ses citoyens, et pour ne pas soumettre ses agriculteurs à une concurrence déloyale, l'UE ne devrait pas autoriser l'importation de denrées en provenance de pays tiers utilisant des substances interdites en UE, substances dont la Limite maximale de résidus (LMR) n'a souvent même pas été rabaissée à la limite de détection. Car l'absence de résidu détectable, ou la non atteinte du seuil de détection, ne règle pas la problématique de l'utilisation par les agriculteurs du pays tiers de la substance interdite dans l'UE et donc de la distorsion de concurrence en plus de l'absence de cohérence politique. Enfin, la Commission estime qu « à long terme, cette évolution devrait renforcer la fiabilité des produits de lUnion en ce qui concerne la sécurité et la qualité et, partant, leur image sur le marché mondial ». La CR estime au contraire que cette initiative ne modifie pas la sécurité ni la qualité, ni limage des produits de lUE sur le marché mondial, puisquelle nintervient pas sur les conditions de production de ceux-ci. Les produits de lUE sont déjà fiables, et compte tenu du cadre réglementaire strict de lUE, le sont certainement plus que ceux des pays tiers. Donc si la Commission européenne entend protéger la santé du citoyen européen, lenvironnement, et la compétitivité des entreprises et de lagriculture de lUE, elle doit interdire les importations en provenance de pays tiers ne respectant pas les conditions sanitaires, environnementales et sociales de lUE.
englishfeedback: The Rural Coordination (CR) thanked the European Commission for its consultation on the initiative to establish a mechanism prohibiting the production and/or export of certain hazardous chemicals banned in the EU, and stressed with satisfaction that the documents were available in all EU languages. The BoA welcomes the Commission’s commitment to take an initiative to “increase the protection of human health and the environment globally and to apply uniform measures in all EU countries”. To show lexemple is one thing, but if this initiative does not go hand in hand with strong measures on imports, its scope will be very limited and will lead to the relocation of production. Factories producing dangerous plant protection products (PPPs) banned in the EU cannot be built up as a parangon, while leaving the same PPPs to enter the EU. There is nothing to do with this approach. It will trigger mockery rather than admiration. It should be noted that: — PPPs banned in the EU have recently been detected in wheat from Ukraine (1500 tonnes containing chlorpyrifos in Slovakia); — according to Europol, counterfeit PPPs are on the rise in the EU; — and finally, that in 2018 Ukraine was one of the 3 largest importers of PPPs banned in the EU. If substances have adverse effects on human health or the environment, it is therefore justified to restrict or not to authorise their use. And, of course, the effects that led to this decision in the EU are of concern in other countries or even globally. But banning production in the EU does not prevent production outside the EU, and does not prevent third countries from supplying outside the EU, which may lead to and the Commission identifies direct economic impacts on EU companies (loss of sales and market share), as well as relocation of production outside the EU. The BoA welcomes the Commission’s legcidity and likely impact on businesses, but regrets that the Commission does not show the same consideration for the distortions of competition suffered by farmers. Indeed, in order not to import pollution, to avoid endangering its citizens, and to avoid unfair competition for its farmers, the EU should not allow the import of food from third countries using substances banned in the EU, for which the Maximum Residue Limit (MRL) has often not even been lowered to the limit of detection. Because the absence of detectable residue, or the failure to reach the limit of detection, does not solve the problem of the use by farmers in the third country of the substance banned in the EU and thus the distortion of competition in addition to the lack of policy coherence. Finally, the Commission considers that “in the long term, this development should enhance the reliability of Union products in terms of safety and quality and thus their image on the world market”. On the contrary, the BoA considers that this initiative does not alter the safety, quality or size of EU products on the world market, which does not affect the production conditions of the products. EU products are already reliable, and given the EU’s strict regulatory framework, they are certainly more reliable than those in third countries. So if the European Commission wants to protect the health of European citizens, the environment and the competitiveness of EU businesses and agriculture, it must ban imports from third countries that do not comply with the EU’s health, environmental and social conditions.

feedback: Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, die letzten Jahre haben gezeigt, dass viele Drittstaaten nicht über entsprechende Stellen verfügen oder es extrem lange dauert, bis sich die entsprechenden Behörden der Drittstaaten melden. Die Kunden sind verärgert und kaufen oftmals die Waren in anderen Ländern, die diese Notifizierung nicht implementiert haben. Darüber hinaus stelle ich mir oft die Frage, ob wir die Bürger der EU und die EU als Behörde mit diesem Verfahren der Notifizierungen, den Eindruck eines überheblichen, arroganten und besserwisserischem Erdteil vermittelt. Viele der anderen Länder ist sehr wohl bewusst, was für Substanzen sie in ihrem Land haben möchten und welche nicht. Wenn diese nicht erwünscht sind, dann werden entsprechende Zollvorschriften erlassen und der eigene Zoll weißt die Waren ab. Aber das was die EU macht, ist ein bevormunden! Auch wenn die Absicht gut ist, sollte man lieber auf anderen Wegen den Ländern helfen, Fehler die wir in unserer Geschichte gemacht haben, nicht selbst zu machen. Kaum 40 Jahre her und es gab noch im Ruhrpot regelmäßig Smog-Alarm. Wir Menschen vergessen leider viel zu oft zu viel! Mit freundlichen Grüßen Steffen Tropitzsch
englishfeedback: Ladies and gentlemen, the last few years have shown that many third countries do not have such bodies or that it takes extremely long for third countries’ authorities to come forward. Customers are angry and often buy the goods in other countries that have not implemented this notification. In addition, I often ask whether through this notification procedure we give the EU citizens and the EU, as an authority, the impression of an upright, arrogant and better-white part of the world. Many of the other countries are well aware of what they want to have for substances in their country and which are not. If they are not desirable, then customs regulations are adopted and the goods are cleared by their own customs authorities. But what the EU does is a patronage! Even if the intention is good, other ways should be used to help countries not to make mistakes in our history. Barely 40 years ago and there were still regular Smog alarms in the Ruhrpot. Unfortunately, we are forgotten too often too much! Yours sincerely, Steffen Tropitzsch

feedback: Bonjour, C'est une très bonne initiative d'interdire la production pour export de produits chimiques interdits dans l'UE. Attention à ce que la production ne soit pas externalisée hors UE par les entreprises qui auraient leur siège dans l'UE / des entreprises détenues en majorité par des sociétés européennes - élargir l'interdiction pour prévenir ce type de situation ? La prévision de sanctions en cas de non-respect est nécessaire, j'espère que vous l'avez intégrée. Bien cordialement
englishfeedback: Hello, it is a very good initiative to ban the production for export of chemicals banned in the EU. Be aware that production is not outsourced outside the EU by companies that would have their headquarters in the EU/companies that are mostly owned by European companies – broaden the prohibition to prevent such situations? It is necessary to provide for penalties for non-compliance, I hope you have included it. Warmly

feedback: no ked sa uz chceme bavit o zakaze chemikalii, tak by ste sa konecne mohli vyjadrit k tomu hnusu ktorym nas kazdy den posypujete a hnusu co sa predava v obchodoch o nase zdravie vam nejde ani nikdy neslo ziadam preverit cim nas praskujete
englishfeedback: however, we want a bavit to ban chemistry, so you could end up saying about the hnus that you don’t burn with the cassettes den sand, and hnus co is sold in shops about the health of myself, and you never got a check with the scratch.

feedback: Il me paraît aussi évident qu'indispensable d'interdire toute forme de production et d'exportation de produits chimiques reconnus comme toxiques/dangereux pour l'environnement, et donc pour l'homme, dès lors que leur utilisation est prohibée en Europe, et ceci pour de multiples raisons: - éthique-déontologiques: les êtres vivants (et donc également les humains) doivent être traités de manière identique/similaire quelle que soit leur localisation. La santé, la bien-être et la vie d'un Africain, d'un Brésilien ou d'un Vietnamien doivent être respectés au même titre que pour les Européens. - impact global sur la biosphère: l'impact de ces produits sur l'environnement est de facto global - pragmatisme égoïste: les éventuels produits (agricoles, mais pas uniquement) qui seraient issus des filières qui utiliseraient des produits chimiques interdits en Europe ont beaucoup de chance de nous revenir au travers de mécanismes d'échanges commerciaux mondialisés - concurrence déloyale, agrobusiness économiquement destructeur d'autonomie: l'utilisation de pesticides interdits dans les pays du sud, contribue à une agriculture "productiviste", qui confisque les terres locales au profit des cultures d'exportation, induisant des dépendances alimentaires de pays qui seraient auto-suffisants si les petits producteurs locaux avaient accès à la terre, et si leur production n'était pas mise en concurrence avec des produits importés.
englishfeedback: It is also clear to me that it is essential to prohibit all forms of production and export of chemicals recognised as toxic/dangerous to the environment, and thus to humans, since their use is prohibited in Europe, for a number of reasons: ethic-ethics: living beings (and thus also humans) must be treated in the same/similar way regardless of their location. The health, well-being and life of an African, Brazilian or Vietnamese must be respected in the same way as for Europeans. — overall impact on the biosphere: the impact of these products on the environment is de facto global – egoist pragmatism: any products (agricultural, but not limited to) from sectors using chemicals banned in Europe have a great chance of returning through globalised trade mechanisms – unfair competition, economically destructive agro-business of autonomy: the use of pesticides banned in southern countries contributes to ‘productive’ agriculture, which confiscates local land for export crops, leading to food dependencies in countries that would be self-sufficient if small local producers had access to the land, and if their production was not put into competition with imported products.

feedback: Halte ich für Blödsinn. Zur Chemie gehören schon seit Urzeiten auch Chemikalien, die eben mal gefährlich sind, aber oft sehr nützlich für die Produktion sind. Wenn nicht wir, dann machen es eben die Asiaten, wie schon so oft in den letzten Jahren. Wollen wir die Produktion chemischer Produkte immer noch weiter verdrängen uns immer abhängiger von den Chinesen und anderen Asiaten machen?
englishfeedback: I think I am bright. Since then, chemistry has also included chemicals that are already dangerous but often very useful for production. If we are not, the Asians are doing it, as has happened so many times in recent years. Do we still want to make the production of chemical products more dependent on the Chinese and other Asians?

feedback: Como ciudadana europea solicito que se prohiban las exportaciones de los productos químicos peligrosos que en Europa ya están prohibidos, ya que luego regresan otra vez a Europa con la importación de productos foráneos a los que se los vendemos.
englishfeedback: As a European citizen, I call for a ban on exports of dangerous chemicals that are already banned in Europe, as they then return to Europe again with the import of foreign products to which we sell them.

feedback: Die AllessaProduktion GmbH unterstützt das Schutzziel der PIC-Verordnung in jeder Hinsicht. Stoffe, die dort gelistet sind, sollten nicht in die Umwelt gelangen. Der vorliegende Entwurf schießt aber in der Wahl der Mittel über das Ziel hinaus und berücksichtigt nicht, dass PIC-Stoffe auch als Zwischenprodukte zur Herstellung anderer wichtiger Chemikalien verwendet werden. Zwischenprodukt ist hier gemäß der Definition Art. 3(15) REACH gemeint. Die PIC-Verordnung unterscheidet nicht nach der jeweiligen Verwendung. Ein Beispiel ist Diphenylamin, welches Rohstoff für den Stoff Phenothiazin ist, welcher zur Stabilisierung von Acrylsäure und anderen Monomeren verwendet wird und dort eine sicherheitstechnisch sehr relevante Funktion einnimmt. Auch etliche wichtige pharmazeutische Wirkstoffe basieren darauf. Diphenylamin wird in der EU nicht mehr hergestellt, aber die Verwendung als Zwischenprodukt und der Import des Stoffs ist derzeit möglich. Ein Stoff, der als Zwischenprodukt verwendet wird, ist nicht dazu gedacht und darf auch per Definition nicht in die Umwelt gelangen. Daher wäre eine Ausnahme für derartige verwendete PIC-Stoffe nicht gegen das Schutzziel gerichtet. Auf keinen Fall darf daher zusätzlich ein einseitiges Importverbot für PIC-Stoffe verhängt werden, welches die europäische Industrie von solchen Zwischenprodukten abschneidet. Was für den Bedarf an PIC-Stoffen als Zwischenprodukte in der EU gilt, gilt im Umkehrschluss auch für die Verwendung im nicht-EU-Ausland. Würden sich nun alle Länder ein gleichartiges Herstellverbot auferlegen, so wäre die Verwendung als Zwischenprodukt faktisch nicht mehr möglich. Wenn sich nicht alle Länder eine gleichartige Verordnung auferlegen, sondern die EU auch hier eine Sonderrolle einnimmt, dann stellt das eine Wettbewerbsverzerrung im internationalen Markt und einen weiteren einseitiger Angriff auf die chemisch-/pharmazeutische Industrie in Europa dar, ohne dass dem Schutzziel auch nur im geringsten gedient ist. Die Abhängigkeit vom nicht EU-Ausland, insbesondere von China würde sich weiter stark erhöhen.
englishfeedback: Allessa Produktion GmbH fully supports the protection objective of the PIC Regulation. Substances listed therein should not enter the environment. However, the present draft goes beyond the objective in the choice of means and does not take into account the fact that PIC substances are also used as intermediates for the production of other important chemicals. Intermediate is meant here in accordance with the definition of Article 3(15) REACH. The PIC Regulation makes no distinction according to the use in question. An example is diphenylamine, which is the raw material for the substance phenothiazine, which is used to stabilise acrylic acid and other monomers and has a very safety-relevant function there. A number of key active pharmaceutical ingredients are also based on this. Diphenylamine is no longer produced in the EU, but use as an intermediate and import of the substance is currently possible. A substance used as an intermediate is not intended to do so and must not, by definition, enter the environment. Therefore, an exemption for such PIC substances used would not be directed against the objective of protection. Under no circumstances should a unilateral import ban be imposed on PIC substances, which will cut off the European industry from such intermediate products. What applies to the need for PIC substances as intermediates in the EU also applies a contrario to non-EU uses. If all countries were to impose a similar production ban, use as an intermediate would in fact no longer be possible. If not all countries impose a similar regulation, but the EU plays a special role here too, this constitutes a distortion of competition in the international market and a further unilateral attack on the chemical/pharmaceutical industry in Europe, without even the least serving the objective of protection. Dependence on non-EU countries, in particular on China, would continue to increase significantly.

feedback: Euro Coop represents 20 members across Europe (15 in the EU) that are owned by some some 30 millions members of consumers' cooperatives. As Consumers' cooperatives, we share principles and values that are aimed to ensuring the highest level of safeguard for humans and environmental health. For that reason, we cannot accept that double standards are applied when it comes to dangerous substances that are banned for use in the EU but still produced for the export market. We do think that a fair approach should be one banning the production of chemicals whose use is forbidden within the EU .

Le sostanze chimiche hanno caratteristiche di pericolosità dovuta alla loro struttura ma proprio per questo vengono utilizzate per ottenere materiali che possono avere degli impeghi importantio per la qualità della vita delle persone. Proprio per questo ogni intervento deve tenere conto dell'effettivo rischio per ambiente e persone. Un semplice divieto di esportazione è solo demagogia che non tiene conto di questo. Quindi è giusto proporre delle misure di riduzione di rischio condivise a livello internazionale per promuovere modelli di rischio/beneficio, con lo scopo di modificare processi e prodotti pericolosi ma attraverso percorsi comuni e condivisi (per esempio Pop's regulation)
englishfeedback: Chemicals have hazardous properties due to their structure, but are therefore used to obtain materials that may have major obstacles to people’s quality of life. This is why any action must take account of the real risk to the environment and people. A simple export ban is only demagogia which does not take this into account. It is therefore right to propose internationally agreed risk reduction measures to promote risk-benefit models, with the aim of changing dangerous processes and products, but through common and shared pathways (e.g. POP’s regulation).

feedback: The adoption of this proposed measure is just a matter of coherence. We are all aware that very often the use of hazardous chemicals in developing countries is not properly regulated or controlled; consequently, they pose an even more serious threat to the users and consumers of agricultural produce in those countries, as well as to the environment.
Stop exportations produits toxiques
englishfeedback: Stop exports toxic products

feedback: Bin für diese Initiative. Schliesslich soll unsere Gesundheit geschützt werden.
englishfeedback: I am in favour of this initiative. Finally, we want to protect our health.

feedback: I support this important initiative, and only wish that it had come sooner. The Chemicals Strategy for Sustainability adopted in 2020 committed the EU to lead by example, and, in line with international commitments, ensure that hazardous chemicals banned in the European Union are not produced for export, including by amending relevant legislation if and as needed. There's no time to waste!
I agree with the initiative
englishfeedback: I agree with the initiative

feedback: Deberían de prohibirse la producción y exportación de herbicidas y químicos prohibidos en la UE porque sabemos que hay alternativas naturales y amistosas con el medioambiente. Está más que demostrado que el uso de dichos productos produce innumerables enfermedades graves al ser humano, así como a todo tipo de animales ya sea por exposición en el entorno o por toda clase de vertidos.
englishfeedback: The production and export of herbicides and chemicals banned in the EU should be banned because we know that there are natural and environmentally friendly alternatives. It is more than proven that the use of these products causes countless serious diseases to humans and to all types of animals, either by exposure in the environment or by all types of spills.
